campaign.story:
As agreed, you wait upon the hill. You intended to come alone, but a red fawn has taken to following you for the past few days. It chews on the grass at your feet. As always, your beloved is never late, although you have been waiting since dawn. Their arrival is heralded by the call of a large black raven and the wind seems to pause; a moment of calm descends. They always had a flair for drama.
They wear the traditional robes, freshly dyed in the deep blue of a plant that you do not yet know, and lean on an almost perfectly straight and uniform branch as a staff. There is a colourful spray of flowers that seems to be growing in their beard, and a bright green vine holds back their hair. They always had the ear of the plants. 
You eschewed robes many seasons ago. You wear only the skin of a large brown bear, and carry only a smooth rock. You had suggested bowers in the woods for this meeting, but they suggested this place. You can see much of your land from here. They always had a knack for choosing.
You smile at them, perhaps showing a bit too many teeth. They nod back, but there is some warmth in their eyes. There are no greeting words in this ritual. You hear raven squawks again, and you look up to see a small murder circling above you. You sense it is time to begin, but you wait. They always go first.
A Divorce of Druids and the Division of their Domains is an I-Cut, You-Choose. Print-And-Destroy, Craft-RPG-Game Subscription Web Zine for exactly 2 players. It takes about an hour to play. 
A Divorce of Druids and the Division of the Domains is a game about a druidic dyad splitting up and dividing their domain, which includes a variety of creatures and plants. The druids are torn between taking what they need to form a harmonious land for themselves and leaving their once beloved partner druid with enough to create a harmonious land as well. 
It is a game about endings and beginnings, about being fair and about getting what you want.
I-Cut, You-Choose
You and another player will divide your once-shared domain, including the plants and creatures within it. This requires literally cutting printed sheets of the land into two pieces. Each turn, one player cuts the land and the other gets the first choice of which piece to take.
Print-and-Destroy
As part of playing the game, you will destroy the game. Each issue also has an element of discovery, and has been designed to be played only once by each druid. That's why we intend to make four issues available - one delivered each season.
Hybrid Craft-RPG-Game
The game asks you to inhabit the role of a druid undergoing a ritual of separation from their beloved, and also asks you to consider how to win, as part of the experience. It blends the line between player and character more than traditional board games, but has more structure and less preparation than a roleplaying game. Also: you get to cut things, glue things, and colour in woodland creatures.
Subscription Web Zine
Inspired by the spirit of Zine Quest, we’ve designed this as a physical zine product but also as a digital product that you can make physical with the magic of a home printer. We're taking things one extra step and going magazine-style, with a subscription option to keep the spirit alive all year long.
This is a game for two druids about the end of their dyad and the transformation of a diminished land into two new lands. It takes about an hour to play. Players want to divide their land so that each of them has enough to form a harmonious new domain... but they also want their new land to be more harmonious.
The rules provide prompts and instruct players to speak. You don’t need to use the exact words (you’re not some wizard-by-memorisation), so have a little fun with it. Let the spirit of the ritual flow through you.
Modes
Before starting the game, you choose which mode you will play. True Neutral is the intended default mode, but Neutral Good offers a true cooperative experience.
Neutral Good
Druids aim to create the best outcomes for both themselves and their beloved. At the end of the ritual, your shared destiny is determined by the druid with the lowest score.
True Neutral
Druids place a greater emphasis on their own destiny, but still care about their beloved. At the end of ritual, your destiny will be determined by your score, and influenced by your partner.
Neutral Evil
You play antagonistically against your beloved, with your destiny determined by the difference between your score and your partner. 
The Characters
The game starts by establishing the characters you will each play. 
Choose one trait for yourself and one for your beloved, while they do the same. Traits provide ways to manipulate the game.
You also collaborate with your beloved to establish names for yourselves and your dyad based on your traits. Finally, you declare a reason to end your union. The ritual of separation isn't about blame.
The Division of Lands
Each turn, one player is the Divider while the other is the Decider. The Divider literally cuts the land into two distinct fragments, and then the Decider chooses which to take first. 
Each player forms their new domain by gluing these land fragments onto a blank map. Fragments may be divided again using a limited number of additional cuts. After you glue things onto your land, you can colour them in.
The Laws
Druids typically co-steward lands with a circle of several other druids, each with separate but overlapping responsibilities. A dyad is an uncommon circle configuration, as it tends to be quite fragile. In dyads, druids steward the land in almost binary fashion, without overlapping responsibilities. 
Every living thing within your land has a Law determining how it scores at the end of the game. As a half of a druidic dyad, you have been responsible for half of the things within your land, so you only know half of the laws of your land. Your beloved knows the other half. 
Throughout the game, you will question your beloved about the other Laws, gaining knowledge about how to score.
Determining your Destiny
When the druids have formed their new domains, end the game and your dyad by calculating your score and referencing the score of both druids to a table of outcomes. This gives you an outcome and some dialogue prompts to help you and your beloved narrate the ending of your story.
Finally, you have a few moments of quiet time to name your land and finish colouring it in.
A completed, coloured and named game
We're trying something a bit experimental with this project. We'll be doing a quarterly subscription to deliver a fresh seasonal issue of the game  every three months throughout 2021. 
Each issue will be a standalone experience, with new mechanics, content, and illustrations. We hope people will appreciate receiving these experiences delivered as the seasons change throughout a year.
Our goal is to ship (whether digital or physical) at the peak of each season: 
Ostara (Vernal Equinox) - March 20
Litha (Summer Solstice) - June 21
Mabon (Autumnal Equinox) - September 23
Yule (Winter Solstice) - December 22
Although this project isn't about juicy Kickstarter *bling* we do have some stretch goals in mind... 
Designer’s note
First of all, I would like to acknowledge the First Nations people as the Traditional Owners of Brisbane, the land where this game was designed. I recognise the country north and south of the Brisbane River, as the home of both the Turrbul and Jagera nations. I pay deep respects to all Elders past and present and future.
Secondly, and within the context of the above acknowledgement, when I started designing a game about connection to land and creatures, I needed to make a choice about which land and which creatures. I made the choice to take the traditions of the only living culture that I have any right to, that of the world’s most popular roleplaying game. 
The druids you play in this game are not intended to be references to the Celts or other pagan traditions which continue today. They are the druids that stayed behind, when their peers left to beat up rats in taverns and buddy up with religious zealots for fame and experience points. They are the druids that actually care for the land and each form. They are True Neutral, and they are a metaphor for you and your relationships and your connection to your past via the objects in the life that give you joy and bind you in place.
I’ve specifically avoided any specific reference to traditions that aren’t just fantasy nonsense, as they are not mine to make. We're syncing up the seasons to the northern hemisphere to fit in with the chosen creatures depicted in the game. 
Have fun, be cool, spend time in nature, and tend your forests and your friendships. 
- Jason 
Jason has been wandering the forest of game design and development for a while now. As a studio unto himself, he made Hedron and almost Ragnaroll (sorry, no, I’m not currently planning on revisiting it), and was a developer for Rule & Make on Hand of Fate: Ordeals. He can also be found frolicking in the digital fields with his Living Rules system.
Ash has been working full-time on boardgames for almost four years (mostly on Vampire: the Masquerade - Heritage). This is the first project from Long Tail Games, an experimental tabletop games publisher. He wants chickens. 
Kier is a former webcomic artist and current law librarian. She draws funny animals and spooky ghosts in her spare time.
Tom is a writer and editor who sometimes designs and translates roleplaying games. He also co-hosts podcasts about RPG scenarios and the 2004 Lindsay Lohan-starring teen comedy Mean Girls. 
Special thanks to Brendan Evans
This game is actually an elaborate and long-running joke that his game Splitsville (now Skyward) should have been about divorce.

campaign.story:
Thank you for enrolling your little hero at Camp Tenderpeak, a summer camp nestled in a pocket dimension for young heroes-in-training! We teach the fundamental skills needed to become a great hero. From creating your first buddy drone to summoning your first battle spirit, Camp Tenderpeak has it all!
But being a hero isn’t just about knowing the right skill or having cool powers. It’s also about leadership, friendship, and empathy. That’s why we have the Tenderpeak Pals system! With the help of our camp’s artificial intelligence Digital Organization Tool for Teaching/Tethering Youths (DOTT/TY, for short), we organize campers into small groups to improve their educational opportunities and performance! Some groups may not get along, but DOTT/TY has assured us that disagreement can help campers bond and learn the benefits of cooperation!
Every day is full of adventure! Learn exciting new skills at camp, like hydron reactor maintenance, summoning ogre dogs, and woodworking! Explore the realms surrounding the grounds, such as the deep underwater kingdom of Nimerea or the robot-filled stronghold of the Fortress Technica. They may find local denizens that need help, jerks that need a whoopin’, or a new experience that needs trying! Camp Tenderpeak is a world of constant discovery!
Again, thank you for entrusting your young hero with our camp! And, if you’re reading this portion, thank you for signing the liability waiver! Your kids are in our safe limbs. We have a 99% success rate with those children that make it home!
The Heroes of Radness: Camp Tenderpeak is an RPG inspired by many animated adventure series, such as Adventure Time, The Bravest Warriors, Infinity Train, and Summer Camp Island. The story is guided by a player who takes on the role of the Head Counselor at Camp Tenderpeak. The other players are campers, learning how to become great heroes.
The camp’s “bunks” are actually small one-person bungalows that are lined up in three rows, which represent the three heroic disciplines:
 the Arcane -- heroes that focus on magic
 the Technical -- heroes that focus on science
 the Innate -- heroes born with innate abilities
Each camper is assigned a specific row based upon their talents and given a bungalow on that row.
As campers learn new skills, they’ll earn the most coveted relics of all: MERIT BADGES! Each badge has specific requirements to earn, such as specific tasks or displaying proficiency. They’re all tracked in the Camp Tenderpeak Merit Badge Guide and Manual, which is kept by every camper. At the end of each week, campers gather at the Bonfire, where they will regale the camp with their adventures, determining if merit badge progress has been made. If the Lead Counselor agrees, the task is marked in the guide. When the required tasks are completed, the merit badge is awarded by the Head Counselor during the Ceremony of Merit during the Bonfire.
The Heroes of Radness: Camp Tenderpeak runs on an experimental evolution of the Story Pillar system used in Home by Dark, allowing for campaign-style play and character improvement. It still focuses on relationships and character interactions while introducing skill resolution and growth paths found in traditional tabletop RPGs.
Character growth and story arc completion are the primary ways to “level up” in this game.  Learning how to work better with your friends will improve your ability to overcome obstacles, while resolving character plots and flaws will improve your character’s capability.
This exploration is something we’ve wanted to do for a while and Kickstarter’s ZineQuest 3 event is giving us an opportunity to bring you along with us on the journey!
The Heroes of Radness: Camp Tenderpeak contains everything you need to have adventures in Camp Tenderpeak’s pocket dimension:
 Campers’ Guide -- Information on Camp Tenderpeak, the staff, and its traditions. It also contains details on the neighboring lands that surround the campgrounds.
   The Rules -- Details on building your camper, how to resolve interactions and obstacles, and what to expect from adventures at camp.
   Head Counselor Manual -- All the information that a Head Counselor needs to run an adventure and how to host a Bonfire and the Ceremony of Merit.
   Camp Tenderpeak Merit Badge Guide and Manual -- A copyable booklet that acts as camper character sheet and merit badge progress guide.
   Sheet of Merit Badges -- The end of the book will contain a copyable sheet of merit badges that you can print and cut out for the Ceremony of Merit.
What do you get for backing each tier? Let’s find out:
 Day Camper -- This is our support tier for those who want to help out a bit. This tier will give you access to backer-only updates.
   New Camper -- A digital version of the zine, distributed through DriveThruRPG.
   Camp Counselor -- Both physical and digital versions of the zine, saddle-stitched with a full color cover and black-and-white interior.
   Camp Director -- Not only does it have physical and digital versions of the zine, but it also comes with two full color merit badge sticker sheets! Add a bit of color to your campers’ badge collection! NOTE: Extra sticker sheets will be available as an add-on in BackerKit after the Kickstarter ends.
Pledge Management will be fulfilled by BackerKit, one of the most popular pledge management systems out there. We’ve used them before and they were great! Only makes sense to use them again!
Shipping costs will be added to the pledge during the final preparation stages. This reduces our estimated budget, giving us a higher chance to meet our goal, and ensures that shipping will be more accurate when we ship the final product.
All of our digital products will be released via DriveThruRPG.
The focus of this project is the zine itself, but we do have a couple of stretch goals that we hope you’ll help us achieve:
 $2750 - More Illustrations -- If we reach this tier, we’ll be able to increase the art budget, bringing in more awesome illustrations for the book!
   $3250 - Camp Tenderpeak Merit Badge Guide and Manual Upgrade -- Instead of being part of the zine, the merit badge guide will be its own standalone booklet. It lists all of the merit badges, their requirements, and a spot to stick the earned badge; it’s part character sheet and part sticker book! It will give the camper a tangible artifact of their character’s progress! 5.5” x 4.25” (quarter letter page size). Available as a digital booklet for PDF backers and a physical booklet for physical backers.
Protagonist Industries is a small indie game publisher. Our games focus on characters development and relationships. Our first Kickstarter project, Home by Dark, was successfully backed in 2016 and had a follow-up release, Misfit Tales, in 2020.

Follow us on Twitter!
Like us on Facebook!
Chat with us on Discord!

Risks and challenges
The primary risk in this project is the handmade nature of it. We will be shipping our zine by hand across the globe, as opposed to shipping directly from the printer like we did for Home by Dark.
We're attempting to mitigate this risk by looking at ways to ship the zine in bulk to reduce costs and not adding our shipping costs until the BackerKit stage once we know how many zines we'll be producing and shipping.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hello, campers!
As you know by now, we didn't make our funding goal. It is unfortunate, but this project was experimental by design. From the start, this zine was intended to be a very simple project: create a small, fun RPG utilizing some of the new game mechanics from the ever-evolving Story Pillar system. We wouldn't add any backer tiers for features beyond the zine and it's basic components. Unfortunately, the high cost of the project and the low backer tier prices didn't match up in the end.

Hello, Campers!
As we draw into the final stretch of the Kickstarter, I wanted to share the second half of the inspirations behind The Heroes of Radness: Camp Tenderpeak! This game draws upon some of these cartoons as paragons for what I wanted to experience as a character -- and as a player. Each series had an important impact on the design in unique but important ways.

Greeting, Campers!
Thank you for backing The Heroes of Radness: Camp Tenderpeak! We appreciate your support!
As we wrap up our first week, I wanted to share a blog post I wrote on the Protagonist Industries website about the shows that inspired Camp Tenderpeak. It's a two parter, with part two coming next week.

campaign.story:
In the hyper-fantastical bronze age megalopolis of Pentola, there is little to no distinction between artisanal and magical items; anything created with sufficient passion and skill is magical by the very nature of the world. A multitude of factions in the city seek to purchase, discover, commission, and otherwise acquire a vast collection of items to be used, investigated, or traded.
A Catalogue Chimerical is a zine of one-hundred-and-forty-four items described and illustrated by an Aydinlar Cataloguer, a specialist in analyzing and describing these fantastic objects for later use. The zine is framed as a magical mail-order catalogue. Members of their University back home acquire items by spending votive ink, the currency of the Aydinlar Suzerainty.  
Every backer of this campaign will also get a digital copy of Lost and Found, a d36 zine of Pentolan magical items! 
What's inside the zine?
Each of the thirty-six pages in this zine includes four items and at least one sketch of the items on that page. There will also be an art-free version with half the page count, ideal for printing at home.
At the base level of funding, the art edition of the zine will have one illustration for each page, meaning one quarter of the items are given custom illustrations. At higher levels of funding, additional sketches will be added until all the items are illustrated.
Here are a few examples of the writing for such items:
Thimble of Bloodsweat Endeavors - Example Item
This small porcelain thimble is chased in scarlet and has a crimson silk slip cover. The markings on the thimble itself are minute and depict a cheerful but strained proprietor hawking various wares from a cart.
If the bearer spills enough of their own blood into the thimble to fill it, they are unable to use any magic for the day, though they find all mundane ventures one step easier. Each time the thimble is used, it seems to grow in size.
Frostgiver Pendant - Example Item
This lapis lazuli pendant is miraculously strung not with wire but with thin ironoak, mysteriously supple whilst held. The engraving on the pendant shows a woman offering her cloak while snow falls thick.
Anyone whom the wearer lends clothing to finds that they are utterly immune to the cold. Until the item is returned, the pendant wearer frosts everything they touch, though their extremeties slowly become frostbitten over the next several days unless the item is returned or they give away something else.
Moonberry Ring - Example Item
This thick ring is made of smoothly polished granite and topped with an ironoak relief of the watchful moon at its zenith over a berry bush. It smells of crushed raspberries.
The bearer of this ring is compelled to kiss it and to seek out fruits to satisfy their newfound sweet tooth; every day that circumstances keep them from eating such fruit they become bitterly selfish. All tastes become extraordinarily more potent, their tongue an order of magnitude more sensitive.
Marblewound Khopesh - Example Item
This olive-handled khopesh has a Pentolan marble blade, pale green veined with gray. The hilt is polished smooth and inlaid with tiny discs of gold which hum softly unless in moonlight.
When the curved blade inflicts a wound it calcifies the damaged flesh, leaving an obvious marble scar and preventing most forms of mundane healing without further surgery.
Flamekeeper Vambraces - Example Item
These puce drakeleather vambraces are tooled meticulously in the image of roiling flames, the heart of each of them embossed with bronze.
When worn, anything held in either hand shrinks to half its normal size in a flash of scorching light, returning to normal size when let go, but glowing-hot.
Let's talk about the Art for this Zine.
The Catalogue is not just a collection of written items, however. It's also going to feature at least one illustration for every four items (36 in total!) - and, if we unlock enough stretch goals, expand all the way to ONE HUNDRED AND FORTY FOUR illustrations, one for every last item in the Catalogue.
The art will be in the form of sketches by the Cataloguer themself (Aaron Radney being the artist on Earth pulling this off), meant to be quick illustrations of the item for the readers of the Catalogue to get a visual for. Each will be roughly A9 (1.5" x 2") in size.
Aaron has an extremely well developed sketch style that was much of the inspiration for this project - when we conceived of a catalogue of magical items, it was obvious there was only one choice for who to illustrate it.
Here are a couple examples of Aaron's work in the sketch style that will be in the zine:
Alt Text: An image sketched in brown pencil on white paper of a thin, relatively androgynous figure with kinky hair sweeping back from their head, again with distinctly African features and seen from the waist up. They wear a cloak that sweeps forward sa if blone in the wind. They carry two scimitars, one in each hand and are leanly muscular wearing a wrap of some sort across their chest, loose pants and a cloth wrap around their waist with their midriff bare.
Alt Text: A picture of a male elf, seen from the shoulders up and sketched with brown and white pencil on tan toned paper. He's looking out of the corner of his eyes. He has African features, a close cropped afro and high cheekbones. The ears are long, pointed and adorned with rings. The image is lightly crosshatched for its shading.
Notes on Accessibility
Both versions of the zine will fully meet the PDF/UA Standard, ensuring that they are as accessible as we can make them. We'll also publish an epub version of the item text for easier/more accessible reading on tablets and e-readers.
We will also be producing a WCAG 2.0 Accessible website for the magical items (no art included) which will include all of the items from the zine as well as bonus items - this site will have full text search, collection pages for both bonus items and Catalogue items, and random-item selector. 
You can find a preview of that website at catalogue-chimerical.netlify.app - we'll be updating it as writing and editing is complete, putting it out as soon as they are completed so you don't need to wait on the PDFs/epub. You can actually view the bonus items right now!
Backer Tiers - what they cost and what you get for them
$1 - Curious Onlooker Tier
This tier primarily provides support to the team - every single penny and pledge helps this project be successful. You'll get a digital copy of Lost & Found, a print-at-home zine with 36 magical items in it and have access to the community copies, physical and digital alike, before anyone outside of Kickstarter gets access.
$7 - Home Scrivener Tier
In addition to prior rewards, this tier gets you a copy of the artless PDF version of Catalogue Chimerical, enabling you to print a copy at home without using all of your ink.
$12 - Chronicler Tier
In addition to prior rewards, this tier gets you a copy of the illustrated PDF edition of Catalogue Chimerical so you can revel in the beautiful art. You also make a digital community copy of both editions of the Catalogue available!
$24 - Archivist Tier
In addition to the rewards from prior tiers, at this level you get a physical copy of the illustrated PDF edition of A Catalogue Chimerical. Every 5 pledges at this level makes a physical community copy of the zine available for other folks! 
$48 - Neighborhood Advocate Tier
In addition to the rewards from the Archivist tier, at this level you fund six digital community copies instead of one and every backer at this tier funds two physical community copies as well! This tier exists for those folks who have the funds and share the belief with our team that art should be made as widely available as possible.
$72 - Artisan Tier
In addition to the rewards from the Archivist tier, at this level you also get an hour consultation with Michael on an artisan NPC - he will then go on to create a print-at-home PDF for you that includes the NPC and six items made by them, just for you! Every backer at this tier also secures both a physical and digital community copy of the Catalogue.
$144 - Dozenal Dealer Tier
This tier is primarily intended for retailers; it includes a dozen copies of the print edition of A Catalogue Chimerical and funds 12 digital and 4 physical community copies as well!
Who's on the team for A Catalogue Chimerical?
The writing for this project is by Michael T. Lombardi, the illustrations are by Aaron Radney, editing is by Samuel Mui Shen Ern, layout is by Dai Shugars, worldbuilding consultancy for the Aydinlar Suzerainty is by Bee Scerri, and character consultancy, sensitivity consultancy, and voice acting is by Persephone. Finally, if the audio format is unlocked, Adil Leghari will join the team as our audio engineer.
Aaron Radney - Illustrator
 Aaron Radney is a fantasy illustrator who loves stories, world building and how the two intersect within the field of illustration. He grew up on a steady diet of fantasy books and shows as well as a healthy dose of mythology and dragons provided by his mother’s substantial book collection. He studied at Memphis College of Art in Memphis, Tennessee and is focused both on helping clients bring their ideas to life and illuminating the power of diverse heroes through drawing heavily from non-Eurocentric inspirations. 
He’s currently based out of St. Louis Missouri living there happy with his partner and tolerating her needy tuxedo cat. In his spare time he plays fantasy card and tabletop games as well as writes to feed the world building addiction and cooks to feed his belly.
Michael T Lombardi - Writer
Michael T. Lombardi is a kitbash enthusiast game designer and developer based in in the St. Louis region of the United States. He is interested in exploring procedural generation, gameable lore, and alternative models and modes of development. He splits his free time between game and open source development (currently working on Platen, digital tooling to make hosting accessible and interactive editions of digital games easier and cheaper).
Samuel Mui Shen Ern - Editor
Samuel Mui Shen Ernis a game designer, writer, editor, musician, and visual artist from Malaysia. Their works explore real-world topics like death, relationships, and emotional brokenness with an unwaveringly brutal honesty and a sense of fun(?)! When she’s not working on hir next big thing, he’s probably zoning out to k-pop, experimenting in the kitchen, or reading autobiographical comics.
Dai Shugars - Layout Artist
Dai Shugarsis a graphic designer and publisher out of Orlando, Florida known for such books as Libreté, The Demon Collective, Lorn Song, and Mystic Punks. He's also written several articles on PDF accessibility and how RPGs could stand to better utilize the medium.
Ben "Bee" Scerri - Worldbuilding
Ben "Bee" Scerri is a non-binary bisexual Maltese Australian tabletop- and video game producer, writer, designer, and community builder, living in Melbourne, Australia. Their work focuses on themes of diaspora, disability/critical illness, self-actualisation, and found family, often through the lenses of their ethnic and queer intersections. When not writing for or about games, they're likely talking about language, cooking, baking, folklore, and/or fashion.
Persephone - Consulting & Acting
Persephone is a writer, content creator, model and sensitivity consultant working in multiple fields. She is also an active Twitch streamer, working to build a platform that promotes inclusion and acceptance.
She is also the DM of her own actual play podcast, Fast Times at D&D High, and the creator of the upcoming 5th edition parody game, Critical Love. You can find her @Persephiroth on Twitter, Twitch, TikTok, and more. 
Adil Leghari - Audio Engineer
Adil Leghari enjoys creative pursuits, playing with audio, video, and images. When not working on DevOps and Automation, he enjoys long walks on the beach, candlelit dinners, and designing stickers.
What are the stretch goals for A Catalogue Chimerical?
$8550 - Expanded Illustrations Stretch Goal
At this level, the zine will include an additional 36 (total of 72) custom illustrations by Aaron Radney, covering half of the items in the zine. 
$10,500 - Expanded Illustrations II Stretch Goal
At this level, the zine will include an additional 36 (total of 108) custom illustrations by Aaron Radney, meaning 75% of the items get an illustration.
$12000 - FULLY ILLUSTRATED Stretch Goal
At this level, the zine will include an additional 36 custom illustrations by Aaron Radney, meaning every single item in the zine will have an accompanying illustration!
$18000 - Audio Format & Diaries Stretch Goal
At this level, we will pay Persephone to read each of the entries in A Catalogue Chimerical as the Cataloguer; in-world, the document itself can carry both written word and the diction of the Cataloguer. This means that the very act of reading the Catalogue puts the voice of the Cataloguer into your head, so you hear their diction and cadence and don't have to rely on the written word alone to grasp intent and nuance.
We'll also write 12 short diary entries from the perspective of the Cataloguer, making their written form available on the website.
Adil Leghari will be editing the audio for both the diary and item entries. After the kickstarter campaign wraps (and the work is done), this audio-format for both the items and the diary will be made available separately on bandcamp! Backers at any level will have access to the digital audio if we unlock this stretch goal!
Where is the budget for A Catalogue Chimerical going?
The breakdown of funding for this project includes:
Writing and Editing ($1,440) 
36 item sketches ($900)
Layout for 54 pages [36 with art, 18 for the condensed artless version] ($840)
Worldbuilding consultancy ($1200)
Character & Sensitivity consultancy ($1800) 
A pie chart showing the budgetary breakdown for the base goal
On top of these expense items, we are including a 25% overhead/emergency fund, which includes Kickstarter's own cut. That accounts for the $7,725 initial budget.
Additional funds beyond the budget and stretch goals will be split between the team members with the writing and publishing portion of the revenue split going into the general fund for the Gondolieri Cooperative.
What is the Gondolieri Cooperative?
This project is being organized under the Gondolieri Cooperative, a new creator-owned organization under which this and all future Pentola projects are being worked. We seek to change the industry by proving out a new model which remunerates everyone involved equitably for their labor, funds the creation of art and games, and reinvests in the community both directly (supporting projects and creators, buying equipment and software, etc) and indirectly (helping keep creators housed/fed through hard times, seeding funds for creative endeavors, establishing re-usable contracts and templates). Our members are international as is the scope of our impact.
At this time, the Gondolieri Cooperative consists of three members: Pam Punzalan, Viditya Voleti, and Michael T. Lombardi.
How is digital fulfillment for A Catalogue Chimerical being handled?
After successful funding and completion of this project, backers of the project will receive access to printable PDFs of the artless and full version of the zine, as well as the epub editon, via LeanPub, where future sales of the digital copies will be available.
Additionally, access to the writing only will be available for free on catalogue-chimerical.netlify.app. That site will be updated as the project writing is completed, meaning you won't need to wait for the final shippable product to start using these items in your games.
How is physical fulfillment for A Catalogue Chimerical being handled, and by whom?
Physical fulfillment will be handled by Spear Witch in the USA, Monkey's Paw Games in Canada, and Glaucus in Australia.
Backers at a physical level will be given an at-cost coupon for the physical copy in these stores and have shipping calculated at the time that they use the coupon, meaning backers will pay for shipping via these storefronts.
This should be overall safer and cheaper for everyone, especially international folks, who won't have to absorb the international shipping costs from the USA we would otherwise have to charge.
To be abundantly clear: YOUR BACKER PLEDGE DOES NOT COVER SHIPPING. YOU WILL NEED TO PAY FOR THAT LATER VIA THE FULLFILLER STOREFRONT OF YOUR CHOICE.
What are community copies and who is getting them?
Community copies are copies of the zine which are earmarked specifically for folks who for any reason cannot afford to purchase a copy for themselves, no questions asked. We will not be means-testing submissions for community copies nor will we be checking to see if you "need" one - if you think it's for you, it is. If you don't, it probably is anyway! We do not and will not vet the claims for these copies. We trust you and the community at large to know your own situation and we absolutely encourage that these copies be claimed.
Every pledge for a copy of the zine (physical or digital) will seed a digital community copy of the PDFs as well. Every five pledges for a physical copy of the zine will seed a physical community copy as well. Every retail-level pledge will similarly seed four physical copies and twelve digital copies.
There is additionally an Advocate tier that seeds even more community copies for anyone who wants to support the community but doesn't want to buy a dozen copies for themselves.
We will be making community copies, physical and digital alike, available first to backers of this campaign, even at the $1 level, before opening them up to the wider community (assuming any copies are left).
What sort of schedule for updates can we expect during and after the campaign?
We will be posting at least daily updates to this project during the campaign (each including a draft of a new magic item) as well as point-in-time updates when we reach any relevant milestones. We will commit to biweekly updates afterward, posting a status update every other Sunday to keep you in the loop.
A note on the icons used for this campaign page
We used several CC-BY icons on this campaign page - the icons for the items came from game-icons.net while the stretch goal and backer tier icons are FontAwesome.
The FontAwesome icons were all licensed CC-BY 4.0.
The icons for the items were:
 Pouring Chalice by Lorc under CC-BY 3.0  (The Thimble of Bloodsweat Endeavors)
 Gem Chain by Lorc under CC-BY 3.0 (The Frostgiver Pendant)
 Ring by Delapouite under CC-BY 3.0 (The Moonberry Ring)
 Sparkling Saber by Lorc under CC-BY 3.0 (The Marblewound Khopesh)
 Bracer by Delapouite under CC-BY 3.0 (The Flamekeeper Vambraces)
The only changes made to any of the icons were to make them purple-and-white to fit with the colors of this campaign.

Risks and challenges
We've run kickstarters which have successfully funded and delivered before. The primary risks are of timeline - as we fund more art, the art will take longer to complete - and of physical fulfillment which is harder in 2021 than ever before. We are confident in the abilities of our fulfillment team to help us deliver physical copies if we unlock the scoped print run and in the viability of a scoped run as a risk mitigation.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Pro Patria Mori is a micro-rpg for 2-6 players that examines the horrors of World War I. Designed as a one shot tabletop RPG experience in the vein of 1917,  All's Quiet on the Western Front, and A Farewell to Arms, Pro Patria Mori is  a tragic two to three hour narrative of hopelessness and loss in the context of war. 

Pro Patria Mori uses open copyright and creative common licensed art created by participants and witnesses of the war.
The game's title is taken from the poem Dulce et Decorum Est by Wilfred Owen. 
The full collection of works are attributed in the book and listed below: 
Under the hood, Pro Patria Mori was inspired by the following games and mechanics:
Quantum Load and Downtime from Blades in the Dark.
Bicameral Stat and Resolution mechanic from Honey Heist. 
Metanarrative Structure and Ruin Track from Trophy Dark. 
d66 random tables from our previous game, The Love Balloon. 
Players take on the role of British soldiers on the Western Front in the year is 1917, creating a character by generating a background and assigning a hope to their characters.
From there, the Commanding Office generates a mission using random tables.
The game then proceeds through a set metanarrative structure, with two additional Setting and Encounter tables to help prompt the fiction. 
Player Characters have two stats - Fear and Grit - which both begin at 3. To resolve actions, players choose which skill and roll a single d6 and succeed when they roll under their stat. If players fail a roll, their Fear increases by 1. If players succeed rolling Grit, their Grit goes up by 1. 

If either skill reaches 6, a specific end state is triggered: the character becomes either Hardened or Shellshocked. 
Characters can use Rations during interstitials to reflect on their journey thus far, moving 1 Fear to Grit or vice versa as they ponder their eventual fate.

Once again we are working with Pressman Printing based in Burbank, California to deliver a beautiful limited run saddle-stitched zine.
6x6", 40 sides, full color, offset print, 12 pt. cover + 60# interiors.
Pro Patria Mori is created by Vincenzo Ferriero & Ray Chou, with layouts by Vincenzo Ferriero under the banner of Mythopoeia. For more information, please visit: www.mythopoeia.us.

campaign.story:
09:36 : Ok it’s 09:36,I 'll start working at 10 O’clock.
14:00 : Fuuuuck
— Mario
It’s February 2nd and Mario has a project to finish before the end of the day. He's got it all sorted out. He can do it! However, something gets in his way...he starts procrastinating and the day is over with 0 minutes spent working on the project. Mario gives up, he finishes his beer, takes a few puffs and goes to sleep.
He wakes up with a smelly mouth, and he looks at his phone with 1% battery. 
It’s 11:24 am, February 2nd. Again. What the heck is happening???
Mario is stuck in an endless day. A procrastination loop where his only aim is to conclude his project...but he just can’t manage to finish it! He’s a serial procrastinator. Only the exact balance of leisure and motivation can get him through the day with his project concluded.
Procrastination Day is an RPG-choice-game where the player has to guide Mario through the temporal loop, in order to complete the main task: finish THE PROJECT.
Stuck between dream and reality, Mario needs to learn from his mistakes and avoid falling into a spiral of procrastination.
Procrastination Day is a Comic - Gamebook that uses the classic elements of an RPG Game Book, but it is humoristic and realistic at the same time.
When in Mario's shoes you'll have different stats, such as Motivation, Energy and Needs.
But also different items and allies can help you during your journey.
In order to play you will only need a pencil, a rubber and the zine.
Bandana = +1 Motivation each morning ; Thermo fan = +1 Energy during Toilet
Will you get the job done ?
Will you have the motivation needed ?
Will you forever be stuck in the loop ?

campaign.story:
Mockup of the Cover
Introduction
Combat is where heroes go to die. Whether it's a staple of your game or something you avoid, when it happens you'll need a weapon!
Fresh From The Forge presents a collection of rules for weapons and combat that can be dropped into and used in any fantasy adventure game! It has been designed first and foremost for use with the Old-School Essentials retro adventure games, but you should have no difficulty dropping it into any other RPG with a similar weapon damage range to the fifth edition of the worlds most popular fantasy RPG i.e. using the full range of standard polyhedral dice.
Mockup of the Front and Back Cover
Fun Instead Of Weapon Simulationism
The book doesn't aim to simulate all the intricacies of how weapons work. Armour has not been reworked to be more realistic. You won't find any intricate striking distance measures or precise weapon dimensions in this zine. 
The goal has been to prioritise something that meets the expectations of adventure game weaponry, while making all options equally valid. Players won't find themselves with one obvious choice of equipment that trumps all others, and these changes will be more meaningful than simply moving damage numbers around.
In addition to this, the book will provide examples of weapons, but by no means aims to be a complete collection of every possible weapon your players may wish to use. Instead, it aims to provide templates you can adjust to taste to fit the weapons you create or your players wish to use.
Mockup of Combat Rules
What's In The Book
Fresh From The Forge first and foremost provides a set of rules for you to understand the balance behind weapons and their various uses, both in and out of combat. It will explain the various benefits of each and allow you to better balance any custom weaponry you might design!
Introduction: Get to know the book
Optional Rules for Combat: An alternative to miniature combat
Optional Rules for War: Extending the dungeon combat system into a war system
Melee Weapon Types
Axes: powerful but imprecise
Blades: precise and consistent
Bludgeons: versatile at a cost
Simple: usable by all
Melee Weapon Classes
Light: throwable with dual weapon fighting
One-Handed: keep one free for a shield
Two-Handed: hit harder with more force
Polearm: distance is no obstacle
Missile Weapons
Bows: the standard weapon at range
Stones & Slings: quick and easy to use
Javelins: powerful shieldbreakers
Blowguns & Darts: subtle and precise
Crossbows & Firearms: primitive but deadly
Nets: to stop them from moving
Magic Weapons
Enhancement: simply better than the rest
Banes and Slayers: kill one thing really well
Spell Storage: weapons with magical properties
Special Effects: elements, aoe, and everything else
The Weapon Shop: Example prices and weights for common weapons
Mockup of the Axe Rules
How Much Is Done, What Still Needs Doing?
Shortly after Old-School Essentials released PDFs to Backers, I began using those rules as written to run a large westmarches style campaign. I quickly grew unhappy with the state of weapons, among other things axes being strictly inferior to swords and the clunkiness of "slow" weapons made me want to make adjustments.
Several spreadsheets and over a year of playtesting later, I've created something I'm quite proud of. The rules provide meaningful choices at character creation of which weapons you'll start out with, and make choosing which of the weapons you find in the wild you want to bring with you more impactful. That +1 sword you find on your first quest might not always be the best tool for every job anymore.
Though the rules are written, they could do with a lot of polish and presentation (all of the text you see in mockups on this page is non-final). I'll be focusing on making the layout accessible and easily usable for table reference. After that, it will need proofreading and finalising. Then, it will need to be sent to the printers (who have already been picked and have given a quote for this project). Finally, once it's printed, it will need shipping.
Because not everything is finalised yet, I can't give you exact dimensions, but the final product should be around 50 A5 pages in a stable bound booklet printed on at least 130gsm paper.
Mockup of Enhancement, Bane, and Slayer Rules

campaign.story:
The carriage coach is on fire and there’s no driver at the reins.
It is the Long Sixteenth Century, somewhere in Europe, or a place much like it. Plague stalks the land, people are rioting against widespread corruption while a monetary crisis is making the rich richer and the poor poorer. 
What is it?
Kriegsmesser is a tabletop RPG zine for #zinequest inspired by history (cca. 1453-1630) and roleplaying games named after medieval weapons.
It's focus are 36 backgrounds compatible with Troika by Melsonian Arts Council, but it comes with two pages of alternative custom rules and can be played standalone.
Also includes some commentary, random tables, rules for horrible injuries, some recommended media and a bunch of historical woodcut art.
What is it not?
It's not a historical game as such, it's anachronistic and sparse on detail.
It is not high fantasy with evil gods and orcs and wizards and pirate elves on lizard mounts.
Two sample backgrounds from the book.
A bit more about the project
The zine is almost complete, it needs some more text and some editing here and there. The pdf will be released immediately after the campaign ends. The print version will take a bit longer, especially since shipping is an issue right now. I'm currently aiming at mailing them out in April, but consider that the covid situation is still fairly unpredictable.
There are no stretch goals, if the goal is exceeded, the money will go towards a higher print quality and some additional content (but it's not paywalled). 
Note that if you purchased my 2021 Subscription Pack on itch, the pdf of this zine will be included in it.

campaign.story:
In a fantasy world where raw magic is extracted from the earth like a fossil fuel—
unsustainably, dangerously,  and for the profit of billionaire death cultists—you are a member of the Black Shields: an order of anti-extractionist resistance fighters. 
The Shields aren't afraid to get their hands dirty. You've blown up a pipeline before, and you'd gladly do it again because you care about the future of your world. It's not a question of if raw magic will spill from pipelines and freighters to transform local wildlife into bloodthirsty abominations—it's a question of when.
You thought the bloodthirsty abominations smelled bad on the Outside
Your enemies are not to be trifled with: there's the Magic Fund, a cabal of ultrarich (did you ever notice how "rich" rhymes with "lich"?) capitalists invested in magic extraction; the Office of Magic Licensing and Abuse, the powerful and secretive government organization that subsidizes magic extraction and regulates citizen magic use; and the Burning Bones, a growing necromantic citizen militia whose bootlegger extraction operations fuel their mission to fulfill an unhinged prophecy about a coming lich-messiah. You suspect unsavory links between the three.
That's why the Black Shields don't trifle: your order possesses secret knowledge of ancient, sustainable magic cultivation; the spells they can cast with this magic are uniquely well-suited to radical revolutionary action; and they care deeply about each other and humanity's collective well-being. The Shields envision a future in which magic is harvested without exploiting the land, the poor and working class, or future generations.
The Black Shields are planning their next assault: a raid on the Feystone Hex-L Pipeline, which is being constructed to exploit a new underground magic vein beneath Allegheny National Forest in Pennsylvania. But more than raw magic lies beneath these woods. 
I also want to punch rich extraction capitalists, but what is this?
This is a series of RPG modules crammed into zines! And when I say crammed, I mean we're talking straining staples with 50-60 pages per module. Brevity might be the soul of wit, but just check out how long I can keep this sentence going without even breaking a sweat; these zines will be thicc, or I'll eat my shorts.
The modules are system-agnostic, meaning that (with minimal-to-no number fiddling), they will work with your favorite dice-based TRPG system.
The zines will present a continuous storyline, but I'm designing the content to be totally cannibalizable for one-shots, sandbox environments, creatures, and so on. Strip my carefully constructed fantasy epic for parts, you beautiful junkyard jackals.
 OK, take me on a fantasy journey. 
Crawler is set on an alternate Earth with a few key differences from ours:
It's populated by Humans and Elves and Dwarves and Orcs and all the fun fantasy friends are invited (but none of the racist fantasy tropes)
Magic exists as a raw natural resource that is fracked, drilled, and mined out of the earth at massive scale, then refined to power society and produce consumer commodities; individual magic use is very strictly regulated, which makes you and your fantasy pipeline-hating comrades a band of charismatic outlaws 
Instead of warming, the planet is cooling dangerously quickly towards a catastrophic ice-age. This is indeed linked to human magic extraction, but the industry is super great at lying about it
Instead of fascists and idiot militias, Crawler's got liches and necromancy gangs 
The story begins on the surface world, and then follows a foul plot deep below the earth. Adventurers will descend (and descend, and descend) and discover that the source of magic is inextricably linked to earth's past mass extinctions, and to a dark secret in the Black Shields' history. Oh, and giant fantasy insects from space.
Don't judge a space bug by its gigantic cover
The Zines
Over the next yearish, I will create four Crawler zines to lay out this campaign arc.
1. Extraction | In the first Crawler zine, you'll live out the fantasy of foiling the greedy magic extraction industry's plans with cunning spells, creative violence, and collective action. Plan attacks on multiple magic extraction sites while dreaming up a better future! But you know what they say about best-laid plans: sometimes, they go sideways when a bunch of necromancers show up to fight you. What? No one says that? Well, it's true.
2. Extinction | Follow the Feystone Hex-L Pipeline underground and discover a devastating secret. Vent your rage and despair by bludgeoning the reanimated fossils of animals that early humans ushered towards extinction as we discovered how smart and cool and violent we have the potential to be. Also, this one's got liches.
3. Chicxulub | The angry spacerock that squad-wiped the dinosaurs 65 million years ago touched down in Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, near the present-day town of Chicxulub (which loosely translates from the Yucatec Maya to, "demon flea"). Because of this, that dino-hating rock is called "the Chicxulub impactor." This zine asks the totally normal question, "what if instead of an asteroid, this had been a gargantuan bug from space crawling with smaller bugs (also from space) that crash-landed because it was riddled with necro-parasites, and also this was the origin of necromancy on earth?" Nailed it.
 4. The Great Dying |  The party learns some hard truths about fantasy bug history, then faces some hard choices about fantasy bug futures. As in our world (in which insects are disappearing at an alarming rate), bugs are a key part of every ecosystem, so threats to them threaten everything. This terrifies me. Can the party save the day and prevent icy cataclysm? That might depend on how they feel about crawling through the innards of a humongous spacebug, confronting a parasitic space-lich, and sacrificing their own ability to use magic forever.
What will these zines look like?
Please note that NONE of the concept art on this campaign page is final and I'll be whipping up fresh inky nightmares from scratch. These zines will be in black and white, and look somewhere between the art that I made for Bunker and a webcomic I'm working on.
Maybe something like this!
Planning to print on earth-tone + earth-friendly paper!
This is weird. You sound weird.
Thank you! You're sweet. I'm Michael, A.K.A. Haunted Meat, an artist and game boi who loves nature and being an organism on a healthy planet. My first career goal was to be a dinosaur; soon after, it shifted to entomologist; somehow, I ended up a filmmaker and a community organizer for the Sunrise Movement.
What I do have are a very particular set of skills; skills I have acquired over a very long career.
My dream is to make nature documentaries; as I've pursued that dream, I've learned too many details about the extinction and environmental injustice crises we face. I started building the world for Crawler in 2015 as an outlet for this accumulating sobering knowledge, mostly via drawing the concept art on this page (which you might recognize from my first-ever game zine). 
Later, I started a homebrew D&D campaign set in the Crawlerverse to help refine a plotline. We played every other week for over a year, during which time we got to explore many different storylines (and laugh many fantasy laughs, and savage many a pizza) together! Success.
The Crawler story arc planned for these four zines is a finely distilled v2.0 of that homebrew campaign, updated with lessons from co-creating Bunker and with all the ways that 2020 radicalized me into an even filthier ecosocialist.
I secretly (um?) hope that playing this game inspires a handful of folks to celebrate the interconnected beauty of our planet, and to investigate how they might help to protect our home.
 Is there someone else I can talk to?
Of course. The friendly folks at Exalted Funeral (your online home for weird literature including indie RPGs, heavy metal zines, and occult texts) will handle fulfillment, so please do direct all of your important, non-fantasy-insect-related questions to them. Speaking of which, let's talk about...
Shipping!
Domestic Shipping & Handling will differ by tier, but it'll work out to around $4 - $5 per physical zine. You'll sort this all out in pledgemanager after the campaign. See Timeline? right below for the projected shipping schedule.
Between COVID and Brexit and who-knows-what's-coming-next, International shipping is currently obstacle-ridden and outta-whack. We hope that things will be moving more smoothly by the time that Crawler is printed. With that in mind, if you're from outside the U.S.A. but would like Crawler in print, please back at a PDF-only level for now; there'll be an option to upgrade to print copies at these Kickstarter-exclusive prices via Exalted Funeral later.
Timeline?
I'm starting with an outline that cherrypicks player-approved encounters, creatures, dungeons, and magical mysteries from 200+ pages of Crawler worldbuilding notes and campaign narrative. Also, a few sketchbooks full of concept art and dungeon maps.
From March --> May, I'll write a first draft of Extraction and Extinction.
May --> July, I'll playtest and I'll make art for both zines.
July --> August, I'll revise and lay out and deliver the PDF of Extraction. I'll also be drafting Chicxulub and The Great Dying.
August --> September, I'll revise and lay out and deliver the PDF of Extinction. I'll also be playtesting and illustrating Chicxulub and The Great Dying.
September --> November, I'll revise and lay out and deliver the PDF of Chicxulub. We'll get Extinction and Extraction printed and shipped.
November --> December, I'll revise and lay out and deliver the PDF of The Great Dying. I'll also begin working with the printer to print all four zines.
December 2021 --> January 2022, we'll print and ship physical copies of the final two zines.
Stretch Goals?
$3.5K Every backer gets a bonus PDF content pack akin to this one for Bunker. It'll include Welcome Packets for your players, pregenerated characters, and higher-res illustrations & maps.
$5K Every backer gets a PDF Crawlerverse Bestiary x Minigame. This'll contain all the sludgy skeletons and interstellar insectoids from Crawler, and also a solo game (kinda like my old zines Ranger Danger and Crawler: Monster Manual #1).
$7K Every backer gets a Dungeon Generator PDF that'll guide you through making Crawlerverse crawls on the fly!
$12K Every backer gets a PDF of the Crawler Grimoire, which'll detail custom schools of magic and spells to replace/augment your system's offerings.
At the Crawler School of Lichcraft and Wizardry, you'll learn such fundamentals as demonology, necromancy, and fungal berserking
If the unthinkable happens and we blast past that, I'll add some stuff here as soon as I stop joy-sobbing.

campaign.story:
Your god has died, but nobody needs to know that! Our God Is Dead is an ultra-light comedy RPG about playing as a group of fantasy devotees who wake up to discover their god has unexpectedly died. Nobody respects the cleric of a dead god and you aren't particularly ready to give up that distinction, the only solution is to create a ruse and fool everyone!
The game is completely GM-less, requires no prep at all, and is played in a single session. So grab your friends, some dice, and a desire for mischief, then prepare to fool everyone into thinking that you're all very respectable people service a god that is very much alive.
Our God Is Dead is played out in a series of 3 acts. The first act is about setting the scene and making up a bunch of strange details to fill in who your god is... or rather was. You'll work as a group to show a day in the life as a devotee to your god with all of the players adding ever stranger details about your god's domains and tenants.
After you've set the scene it's onto the scheming. Hatch plans together and put them into action because at any moment your ruse could come falling apart. Unfortunately, none of you are particularly deceptive and will inevitably find yourself getting into trouble as your plans go awry. The game uses a simple d6 and success or failure is determined by trying to beat your previous roll. This means that you're bound to roll both successes and failures, creating all kinds of complications and trouble in preparation for the third act.
The final act is where everything catches up with you. All of the lies you've told come back to haunt you while you're left scrambling to cover up the mess you've made. How far are you willing to go to keep the truth from coming out and what will it cost you? Each player takes turns in the spotlight, narrating either lucky breaks or comically unfortunate outcomes based on your rolls. The game is finished when your group lands on the best ending to their story with prompts and guidelines to help you wrap things up.

The sheriff's tin star glinted as he threw open the doors to the saloon. A silence spread across the room as the sheriff walked to the bar, all eyes drifted to the black clad elf with the pointed boots. As the sheriff ordered a drink, the elf’s hand slid to the holster on his hip.
Without turning around the sheriff responded, “Elgor, we both know this is gonna end with one, or both, of us dead." 
The room collectively held its breath.
"So how ‘bout we skip to the end and finish this before anyone else gets hurt.”
The sheriff threw back his drink and turned for the door. “I’ll be outside,” he stepped back into the midday sun, “best not keep me waiting.”
Outlaws ‘N’ Owlbears takes place in a fantasy wild west that never was. Elementals bound to the hearts steam engines opened the new frontier as train tracks spread across the map. Dangerous creatures and locations dot the rugged landscapes. Sorcerers and wizards claim a nexus of their own to harness the wild magic. Prospectors hunt for rare and exotic materials. Bandits prey on the vulnerable for easy money. Snake oil actually works. 
Outlaws ‘N’ Owlbears is a d6 roll under system. The rules are simple and intended to make play fast. Fights can be brutal though, leaving characters seriously injured or dead after only a few rounds.
OnO has no classes, build the character you want by choosing talents. Want to be a mage, choose magical talents. Want to be a gunslinger or a brawler, choose those talents. Want to mix and match, you can do that too. 

There are 4 species in OnO, each with their own unique species trait.
 Elves are naturally intoned with magic, and can more easily learn how to use it.
 Dwarves are slow and steady, they don't move fast but are hard to slow down.
 Humans are deterministic, and sometimes can choose not to die.
 Goblins are naturally sneaky, and can be hard to spot.
In OnO your equipment can mean the difference between life and death. You have decisions to make about weapons, armor, ammo, upgrades, and magic items. Use guns, explosives, melee weapons, and other equipment to survive the world. 
The plan is:
Print at 5 ½ x 8 ½
Pages will be black ink on white copy paper, maybe slightly off-white
The cover will be black ink on a cream colored cardstock, and have helpful references printed on the inside
We're looking at 32 pages right now
There will be the full rules for playing, including a GM advice section, and bestiary
An introductory adventure (not currently written, but ideas about a snake cult stealing a town's water supply come to mind)
$400 More playable species. The Revenant and Beastmen species will be added.

$600 An advanced equipment guide will be added as a digital reward to all digital editions.
$700 Another adventure will be included with all digital editions. I'm thinking something about rustlers, as it gives an excuse to add more rules about mounts.
$800 A world guide will be added to digital editions. It will be a look at the world of the fantasy west and more information on the people that live there and what their life is like, maybe include some more talents.
$900 One more adventure in digital editions. I like the idea of a hunted mine, maybe the pioneers unearthed something that was best left berried. 
$1000 All the digital extras will be collected in one volume, a digital copy included with digital editions, and a physical copy to be sent to physical edition backers.

This project started it’s life as something else, but from what I’ve heard most projects like this do.
I like RPG’s and comics, I like making both, I also like painting minis. I have another job that is currently my “full time” job so this is one of my "side" projects. Follow me on twitter to see my stupid tweets and pictures of minis I’ve painted,  @Corbzor .

campaign.story:
The Wizard's Grimoire
A few years ago now, I designed a game called The Wizard's Grimoire. In it, you play an ambitious minor wizard who's come into possession of a grimoire beyond your arts. Can you study and unlock it? What wizardries does it contain? Into what troubles and adventures will your ambitions lead you?
Since then, I've written several more games set in the same world -- The Barbarian's Bloody Quest, The Last Adventure, The Thief & the Necromancer -- and also additional grimoires for the original game. Each offers new characters to play or new wizardries to unlock and master.
I'd like to bring these games to a wider audience. In all, I've already written enough material to publish 7 issues of a zine, so that's what I'm going to do!
Gameplay: the Grimoire
At the heart of the game is the grimoire: a text of many sections and its own set of rules. Each section represents a wizardous advancement you can achieve, a new spell you can learn or act of wizardry you can undertake, but each also has its own rules for unlocking and studying them. Don't read ahead! You can only read the sections you've unlocked and studied.
Most wizards' grimoires also include "safeguards," sections you unlock by improper study. These include magical curses, setbacks, and disasters. Trigger a safeguard and the spellbook may rewrite itself, summon a destructive creature from another world, or even send you reeling 10 minutes back into the past. Keep trying to study it without disarming the safeguard, and it'll keep sending you back!
Your first grimoire is a challenging 1st-level text called "The Signature of Aibesta of the Two Courts." Aibesta of the Two Courts was a powerful wizard of an age some four centuries past. Her grimoire includes the techniques to summon an Impeccable Servant, a powerful familiar and bodyguard, an act of wizardry that Aibesta undertook but never accomplished.
Work your way through the entire grimoire, and not only will you learn powerful new spells, you'll establish your workroom, the foundation of your future seclusium; you'll learn techniques to better subdue and study future grimoires; and you'll accomplish what Aibesta herself couldn't: the summoning of an Impeccable Servant!
Gameplay: You and Your Volunteers
To play The Wizard's Grimoire, you need two volunteers (or three works fine) to play against you. Only you, the wizard player, need to know the rules. You're responsible for knowing your own rules and making your own calls. You're also responsible for telling your volunteers any points of continuity that you want them to know.
In this way, the game upends the normal player-GM relationship. Instead of a GM saying, "hey, I have this game I'd like to run, who's in?" you say, "hey, I'm trying to get my wizard through this spellbook, do you have a minute?"
Each session that you play is an episode in your wizard's study and adventures. They can be as short or as long as you like, you can play as often or rarely as you like, and you can have different volunteers, or the same ones, every time you play.
Gameplay: System & Dice
The Wizard's Grimoire uses a dice pool version of the good old PbtA moves.
You have ratings for your moves based on your qualities -- for instance, your rating to exert yourself subtly to take surreptitious action is equal to your Ambitious + your Cunning, while your rating to exert yourself violently against an enemy is equal to your Bold + your Cunning. Roll that many dice, count the 4s, 5s and 6s as hits, and if you roll no hits, it's a miss. Usually, you get to spend your hits on things you want to happen or questions you want to ask, but you know how it is with moves, they each work a little differently.
Since you both call for your own rolls and interpret their results for yourself, the moves answer to different design concerns than they do in a conventional PbtA game. I think they're pretty interesting, and if you're a PbtA-head like me, I think you will too.
Future Issues (Spoilers!)
 The Dictum of Polume the Farer: An easy and useful 1st-level grimoire, including such spells as creating a scampering lantern and summoning a jarful of plasmic hornets. You can study it alongside Aibesta's Signature for very good results.
 The Barbarian's Bloody Quest: Can you find and slay the wizard who butchered and subjugated your family? Includes "The Book of Doomed Wizards." 
 The Three Scrolls of Jorvelte Wild-Crowned: A 2nd-level grimoire, including the wizardous techniques to enchant magical items, including a useful and dangerous staff of glimmering menace.
 The Last Adventure: In your youth, you were a warrior and a hero. Now you're dead, but no one brought you the sup of oblivion. Take up the memory of your old sword, the memory of your old helmet, and make your last adventure here in the land of death. Includes "In the Land of Death" and "Answering the Calling Voice." 
 The Red Tome of Salabrusto the Wise: A 2nd-level grimoire, including an almanac of alien worlds and planes, and wizardous techniques both to travel to them and summon entities from them.
 The Thief & the Necromancer: You're friends, a gifted necromancer and a thief and street performer. You've both escaped bad situations and you've thrown in together to take on the world. Includes "Goerne, a Ghostly Tutor." 
Attention: Patrons
If you support lumpley games on Patreon, you'll already get the digital version of The Wizard's Grimoire as a patron reward. Don't sign up for it here!
If you'd like a copy in print, though, this is the best way to get one.
Reduced Price Level & Community Copies
Times are tight!
If you want to support the project but the full price is a stretch, or if you're curious about the game but can't justify paying full price sight unseen, we've been there! Please feel free to join in at the reduced price level.
When we publish, we'll also make a number of free, community-supported copies available, no questions asked. If you can't join in now, please reshare the project and pick up a community copy when they come out.
Thanks!

campaign.story:
Life was rad. Magical heroes and villains used to zip through the skies and streets of Pacifica City. Their clashes were never deadly but always awesome.

Then the Unkind showed up. It took one day for this otherworldly evil to eliminate the heroes and strip the villains of most of their magic. As the last hero died, they reached to the sky and cast a spell. It bound all magical beings in the city to a pact: “Kill no one of this world, protect Pacifica City, and defeat the Unkind.”

The villains’ magic was not lost. It was fused with random objects around the city, turning those objects into monsters. Pacifica City needs new heroes. Unfortunately, they’ve got are a bunch of Necrojerks.


Necrojerks is a d10-based game ideal for 2-6 players with a GM. It is run like an episodic television show where you, the villains, must punch the magic out of monsters and defend the city you used to torment. Each episode starts with players taking on the role of “red-shirt” NPCs who exist as human happy meals for that week’s monster.

Characters, or Jerks, are created by answering a series of background-generating questions, assigning points to Traits, picking Powers and starting possessions. Necrojerks is a classless system where you can either build your character from scratch or use and modify one of the six archetypes; see below. Once you’ve build your Jerk, the book details how to build your group’s lair.

Archetypal Jerks
 Flextanks: musclebound beeftatoes covered in Roidrunes. They start jacked and become stupid-jacked.
 Puzzlefaces: some folks carefully perform rituals to bring infernal magic into the world. Puzzlefaces skip steps.
 Boogen: some are tall, some are small, but you should avoid them all. Twisted faces, extra limbs, the Boogen are gangly nightmares.
 Hextronicons: Mash a Megaman villain and Decepticon together then scrawl Sigil Circuits across them, you've got a Hextronicon.
 Geist: Brooding, loner-type masked vigilantes who use fighting sticks for wands that, through magic, are turned into grappling hooks, ricocheting weapons and other awesome tools.
 Werebuddies: They were once inanimate objects that soaked up evil magic radiation. Think of a kawaii cute can with fur sprouting out of the top like mold. It wants to hug your face with its teeth. 
A Werebuddy is the cute, inanimate object with lycanthropy that you've always wanted to play. Here's one before they get all snarly.

Jerks can amplify their abilities at a cost. Here we have an amped up Puzzleface bursting with squiggly bits.

How does it play? First off, $1 donations get you a copy of the playtest in April so you can find out for yourself! It is light on rules and the GM should both challenge and cheer for the players. Combat is designed to leave Jerks panting and bruised and tag-team attacks are rewarded; Fastball Special. Non-combat challenges are easy to run and failure is treated as an opportunity for creativity.

Everyone who donates $1 is included in the April playtest. The playtest will be a one-shot adventure featuring three archetypal jerks. I am very eager for your feedback!

The base zine is black and white, over 30 pages and will be printed by Mixam. In addition to character creation rules, there will be a list of enemies, details about Pacifica City for setting a scene, a plot generator, guidance for GMs, and more.

All order over $10 will receive a pack of stickers!

The special edition version of the game will be 40+ pages, feature a color cover, more art, more info on Pacifica City, an adventure, and additional material. The physical copy of the special edition will be a higher quality production overall. The adventure will be voted upon by special edition backers but one option will feature a kaiju-sized, bipedal high school building that eats students.

The game is written, the art and layout are in progress. I will send play test copies out at that point, looking for feedback. In May and June I'll incorporate feedback.

February - Kickstarter
March - Layout work
April - Playtests
May - final art complete, implement feedback
June - polish
July - released into the world!


Follow the progress of the game on Instagram and at www.necrojerks.com

campaign.story:
Aether Operations is a tabletop roleplaying game where players embody a Manipulator from one of the four Quantum Realms (Spirit, Brain, Bone, and Meat) in an attempt to thwart vicious Keepers and maintain balance.
folded zine mockup
Traverse the realms in a forever struggle of imbalance, defeating powerful warlords and cleansing corrupted artifacts. Brutal and dangerous, even the most routine beasts spew damnation at the mere presence of you: the Manipulators. The unique denizens of each realm aspire to purge you in whatever malicious possible ways available in an effort to gain more power and bring the imbalance of reality towards a coming doom.

Aether Operations is a unique self-contained tabletop RPG system. Leaning into the  unique art-heavy physicality of the zine, it is designed as both a streamlined, collaborative, and creative conflict-focused roleplaying game and an intense and special art object. 
AeOps is for 2-5 players including a gamemaster with optional rules for gm-less play. Players, as Manipulators embodying Spirit, Brain, Bone, or Meat, use up to seven six-sided dice (7d6) to 
Traverse the Quantum Realms
Annihilate Keepers, creatures and denizens
Cleanse powerful Relics
while the GM uses a diminishing Balance Die, downgrading from d12 to d4 with each stage representing further destabilization of the Realms and a quickly approaching reality cataclysm.
The game encourages players to creatively interpret their list of Skills, determined at the start of play by the Realm you embody and expanding over the course of the game. Each Stat has a number of d6 you may gamble on any given check. The highest value rolled determines your success but every 1 result is a problem, regardless of success. If you roll really poorly, you can lose all of the dice wagered, whittling down your Skill list and vitality with repeated defeat. 
Manipulators travel between the Realms on their whim, expanding the canon of your setting as you explore the landscapes and are punished by the unique denizens of each.
The Aether Operations printed zine is approximately 125x175mm (about 5x7") when completely folded and 500x700mm (about 19x27") when completely unfolded, featuring unique graphic spreads on each growing "page" as you unfold. The completely unfolded form is a large format poster. It is printed on broadsheet-sized newsprint, creating a unique feel and presentation. 
how the zine works
Watch a session of play hosted by +1XP below that starts right around 0:04:25, and listen to an interview  about the design in the same video starting around 1:47:00.
We've crafted a playlist for you to get in the vibe of the setting and visuals, listen to the unofficial AeOps playlist on Spotify or Apple Music.
Rewards
This campaign is kept simple to keep our focus on making the best zine we can with our budget and time. As such, there are no stretch goals and only these simple pledge levels:
 Digital Edition: the illustrated PDF and RTF (rich text format) files of the game.
 Physical Edition: full unfolding broadsheet sized zine, approximately 700mm x 500mm unfolded and 125mm x 175mm when folded, with complete rules and artwork by Adam Vass. Also includes the digital edition above! 
Shipping
Floating Chair Club will be fulfilling all physical pledges when the print edition is finished.  Orders will ship weekly in batches per received surveys until they're all out the door. We expect delivery to begin in March 2021.
Domestic orders of the zine will ship USPS First Class (current estimate is $5).
International shipping is also available but to keep the cost down it will be sent as a letter and so it will not be trackable and will be slightly less padded. But we figure this is the best option to get the zine out to as many people at the most affordable rate.  
Digital editions will be distributed via itch.io where World Champ Game Co hosts all their game PDFs.
Adam Vass (he/they) - designer &  publisher. Adam has been designing & publishing tabletop rpgs as World Champ Game Co. for the past four years, including the recent Babes in the Wood, science fantasy Necronautilus, conspiracy horror Cobwebs, hopepunk Aurora, and many more. Find more of their games in print at www.worldchamp.io and digital at worldchampgameco.itch.io.
Samuel Mendez (he/him) - Floating Chair Club  - shipping, fulfillment, publishing, kickstarter management. Floating Chair Club started in 2020 to promote and lift up indie creators and as a place to share our interests. As the shop has grown, we are now venturing into larger projects and helping out with Kickstarters, publishing, and fulfillment. Find rad zines, games, pencils, cameras and more at floatingchair.club
