THANK YOU, EVERYONE!!!
This campaign exceeded our wildest expectations. We’re thrilled beyond belief that so many of you joined us in White Ash to get to know Glarien. If you missed this kickstarter, we’ll be back again soon with more White Ash.

Hello everyone, we're thrilled to be back on Kickstarter for the 8th time to launch GLARIEN, an all-new comic book miniseries for mature readers set in the White Ash Universe. 
Written by Charlie Stickney, with art by Romina Moranelli, colors by Fin Cramb and letters by Conor Hughes, the 40 Page first issue of Glarien follows the early days of White Ash's most dangerous elf, as told through the eyes of Rachel, a young woman living in 1970's New York City.  Think Red Sonja meets Taxi Driver... but with Elves and demons.
Glarien: Chapter One cover by series artist, Romina Moranelli
If you’re returning to the White Ash Universe, THANK YOU so much. We owe everything to our Kickstarter community. If you're new to White Ash, WELCOME.  Glarien is a stand alone miniseries where you don't have to be well-versed in White Ash lore to enjoy the ride. But, if you want to get caught up on all things White Ash, we'll have tiers for that, or you can grab the single issues directly from Scout Comics. 
So beyond the tagline, what's Glarien about?  
Glarien follows the stories of two women and the different paths they take to overcome life-altering tragedies. Jumping from the elf realm of ancient Alfheim to the gritty streets of New York City circa 1971, two seemingly-unrelated tales will slowly weave together to reveal a critical piece of White Ash's complicated past. Oh, and because Glarien is involved, expect carnage... lots and LOTS of carnage. 
For those readers coming from White Ash, we do want to reiterate, Glarien is a more MATURE book.  White Ash follows Aleck and Lillian, two PG-13 characters in an R-rated world.  Glarien is an R-Rated character... in an R-rated world.  And as such, to appropriately tell that story, there are themes that are intrinsic to her character that need to be explored. But perhaps the best way of showing you all what Glarien is all about is to jump right into an...
 EPIC 15 PAGE PREVIEW 
 That's a good question.  And you'll find that answer inside...
We appreciate the motto, "Go big or go home." All of our books are solid reads.  Not wanting to buck that trend, Glarien: Chapter One clocks in at --  FORTY-FREAKING-PAGES.  And that kind of content deserves a premium paper weight.
We print DOMESTICALLY (so you get your books quicker) on a heavy 80 lb glossy paper stock with a cover on 100 lb glossy cover stock. When you pick up one of our books, you'll feel the  difference.
To help introduce Glarien to a larger audience, we've brought in a slew of talented women (and White Ash's Conor Hughes) to do variant covers for us to showcase her stylings. 
The first variant cover is a virgin variant from Rosi Kämpe (Spider Gwen, Extraordinary X-Men, Destiny NY) focusing on the dual worlds narrative of the Glarien storyline. 
Rosi Kämpe Variant Cover
Our second variant comes from the jaw-dropping color pallet of Liana Kangas (Star Wars Adventures, 2000 AD, TRVE KVLT, She Said Destroy).
Liana Kangas Variant Cover
Up third, we have a haunting, Rachel-centric cover from White Ash's Conor Hughes. 
Conor Hughes Variant Cover
And last, but certainly not least, from Yishan Li (Hellboy, Buffy, Swing), a virgin variant of Glarien in action.
Yishan Li Variant Cover
JUST UNLOCKED.  A COVER BY IVAN TAO
Ivan Tao Variant Cover
This stretch goal cover is even more limited.  We only have 35 available to backers as a reward tier.  However it CAN be selected as part of the Pick Two reward and comes as part of the ALL FIVE (now six) COVERS reward.
We love packing our campaigns with extra goodness.  IN ADDITION to Glarien: Chapter one, our reward tiers are filled with goodies.  Here's what you can get this time around.
All backers receiving physical rewards will get a 6" x11" print of our kickstarter page banner image on glossy card-stock.  On top of that, Conor will sign & number copies for the first 300 print backers.
Get to know Glarien.  All backers will receive this digital bundle of Glarien's previous appearances (White Ash 1/2, Glarien 1220, and Glarien 1880).
Heads, NYC. Tails you're in Alfheim. No matter how it lands, you win, as ALL physical backers in the Variant Cover Tier (or higher) will receive this limited edition, 1.5" commemorative Two Worlds Coin. It can also be added on to any physical tier.
New to White Ash?  Catch up in style with our 200 page, oversized (7.75" x11.25") hardcover collecting the first arc of White Ash.  That's over 2lbs of White Ash goodness delivered straight to your door.  This is a beautiful book you'll be happy to have on your coffee table or adorning your shelf. 
Get a sketch cover of Glarien: Chapter One  drawn by White Ash series artist, Conor Hughes.  Conor will take (reasonable) requests as to the subject mater. There are ONLY 20 of these available. A must have for collectors.
We know what it's like to open up a package and find a mangled Kickstarter comic inside. We pack our books with the care that we used in making the comic and the love that we have for our backers.
Each comic is bagged, boarded front and back and sent in stay-flat packaging. Multiple issue orders will be mailed in our custom-made, comic boxes. Made in White Ash means everything from the content, to the mailers we use, meets our standards of quality.
We LOVE stretch goals.  And if we're lucky enough to reach our initial funding goal, we'll unlock a slew of really cool mystery extra rewards for our backers.
Stretch Goal #1 ($15,000) Thank you, thank you very much UNLOCKED
Every physical blacker will receive a 6x9, custom Glarien Pin-up by Yasmín Flores Montañez commemorating the campaign reaching its funding goal. 
Stretch Goal #2 ($20,000) Stuck though you UNLOCKED
Every physical backer will be receiving a contour-cut sticker based on Glarien as she’s featured on the cover of the Scout one-shot.
Stretch Goal #3 ($25,000) Step by Step UNLOCKED
This one is for all the process junkies. Every backer will receive a behind-the-scenes PDF showing the different stages of 16 curated pages from Glarien as they go from script, to layout, to inks and finally to color.
Stretch Goal #4 ($30,000) Might I Have Some More, Sir UNLOCKED
Every backer will receive an extra, all-new, digital Glarien short story drawn by the incredible Emily Pearson. This will be added to the haul you’re already taking home. 
Stretch Goal #5 ($36,500) Cover Upgrade, UNLOCKED. 
We are adding a spot UV finish to to the main Romina Moranelli cover.
Stretch Goal #6 $40,000 Get to know us faster UNLOCKED
If you back at a catch up tier, we will be mailing those books out first.  That way, you can dive into the White Ash universe and have something to read while we're getting Glarien ready for print.
Stretch Goal #7 $46,000 Who wants another cover UNLOCKED
A new cover by Ivan Tao has been unlocked.  You can select this as a reward.  It also can be selected as part of the pick two package.  And our ALL FIVE covers is now our ALL SIX.  Anyone who pledges at the ALL FIVE COVERS Tier will automatically get this one as well. 
Stretch Goal #8 $52,000 MYSTERY STRETCH GOAL
Will This Series Be Available Through Stores?
Yes!  But not for a while (at least until mid-2022).  We LOVE our partnership with Scout Comics.  Scout has expanded the reach of White Ash, putting us into shops across the country.  In fact, we're betting some of you reading this now, may have just picked up the Scout Glarien one-shot last week. (NOTE: THIS SERIES is all new) But we also have a very loyal audience here on Kickstarter that's been with us since the beginning.  And we want to honor that legacy by bringing new White-Ash related content to you first.  
Through limited-runs and exclusive-editions on this platform, we're able to put together the high-quality content that our fans are used to, and make sure our collaborators are paid wages commensurate with their talent.  Simply put, without Kickstarter, we (and many other creators working today) couldn't afford to make these issues at the level of quality the story deserves.  
Meet the team.
Charlie Stickney is Co-Publisher of Scout Comics, and writer of comic books like White Ash, The Game and The Adept.  A twenty-year veteran of the non-comic Entertainment Industry, Charlie produced the award-winning documentary The Entertainers and helped create the animated series Horrible Histories and Cosmic Quantum Ray. 
Charlie’s career in comics started with an internship in the editorial offices of Marvel.  After a prolonged dalliance creating stories with pictures that move, Stickney has happily returned to his favorite medium. Charlie lives in Los Angeles with his amazing wife and two (mostly) lovely children. 
Romina Moranelli is an Italian comic artist. First published in France by Editions Clair de Lune (the one-shot volume Jade), then she started working for US publishers as interior and cover artist. Recently she illustrated the first issue of Siria Underworld Pimp Hustla written by Vince Hernandez. Also, she collaborated with PaperFilms, Aspen Comics, Disney, Space between Entertainment, Action Lab. She has contributed to the series White Ash before, with a variant cover for chapter three and a short story for the White Ash one-shot Glarien.
Fin loves all things comics and can usually be found happily working into the wee, small hours in his studio in Edinburgh, Scotland. Fin's previous credits include working on Savant(Dark Horse), Planet of the Apes (Madefire), Peter Pan the Graphic Novel (Birlinn) and the Johnny Cash Project.
Give Fin a shout on Twitter @Finsomniac.  
Malissa White is a writer, editor and producer from Los Angeles, CA. Her credits include co-producing Comics Creators Club on YouTube, editing Stake Presents: Jessamy and Chase the Moon. Her works include Vessel, Nightmare, and The Wood In The Reeds: A Wailing Blade Tale. She loves bringing queer women of color to the forefront of horror, science fiction and fantasy, black coffee, and singing too loudly in the shower.
Conor Hughes likes to draw comics and his breakout work has been the popular Kickstarter comic White Ash and The Game.    
You can troll him on twitch at twitch.tv/conorhughes where he can often be found making comics as well as Hopewell NJ, with his amazing wife and giggle monster baby girl.

Our amazing GLARIEN SCORE was composed by the incomperable  Seth Podowitz.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is our EIGHTH Kickstarter. We've always delivered, and if we're ever delayed, we find ways to make it up to our backers. If you look at our backer numbers and comments, you'll see a happy and growing bunch. We also PRINT DOMESTICALLY to ensure that there are less ways for unexpected delays to arise. And sure, things can ALWAYS go wrong. But if they do, and there are any problems or delays, we'll be in touch and we'll find a way to make it right.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hey Everyone, 
Just wanted to post a quick update and say thank you for filling out your surveys so quickly.  In less than a week, 86% of you have already turned yours in.  So to hold up our end of things, we've sent out out your Glarien Digital Shorts bundle and White Ash Volume One PDFs (for those of you who backed at the catch-up  level).  
We have also begun mailing out the White Ash hardcovers.  The first 40 hit the mail today.  We hope to get the rest of those (and the single issue, catch-up bundles) out by the end of next week.  That way, it won't be that long of a wait for those of you who'd perfer to read a print copy.

updates.update_userinfo: Catch up materials and PDFs are on their way.
updates.update_content:
Hello everyone,
Our Glarien surveys should be on their way to your inbox now. If they don't reach you by tomorrow am, feel free to shoot us a DM and we'll send you a direct link.  They should be reasonably straight forward, but let us know if you hit any bumps when filling them out. We're planing on sending out the catch-up portion of the rewards as soon as we have most of the address in.  So please answer the survey as soon as you have a chance.

Hello everyone,
Surveys should be out in the next day or so.  We're just waiting on Backerkit to give the approval.  This process used to be a couple of hours.  But now it seems to take a couple of days.
*sigh*
Hello White Ashians/ Glarien fans.

updates.update_userinfo: Where Do We Go From here?
updates.update_content:
WOW!  Thank you White Ashians and Glarien fans,
This campaign blew the doors off any expectations we could have reasonably had. We can't tell you how much this outpouring of support on Kickstarter and on social media has meant to us.  We'll be back tomorrow with a substantial update, laying out our timeline and production workflow going forward. 
But today, we just wanted to post a quick note of appreciation... and a reminder to check your credit cards in case they didn't go through:)

Happy Monday White Ash/ Glarien fans,
We've got just two days left in this incredible campaign. Thank you so much for all the amazing support.  This has been and continues to be such a wild ride.
Just a couple reminders as the campaign draws to a close. The GLARIEN (all caps) 20% off discount code, applicable for any comics or trades at Scout Comics, will expire when the campaign ends. This was Scout's way of saying thank you to any of the Scout fans who'd come aboard this campaign.  So feel free to take advantage of that if it's of interest to you. (Reminder: the Glarien one-shot Scout has on sale is comprised of 3 shorts that you'll all be getting digitally as part of this campaign.  It is not the new series you all have just backed.)

Hello White Ashians/ Glarien fans,
We ran out of the capacity to be blown away about three updates ago.  If we did still have that ability, we'd be spending the afternoon picking our collective jaws up off the floor.  The insane pace of backers both returning and new, that continue to flood to the Glarien campaign is truly special.  We're on pace to be one of the most backed single-issue (non-trade) comic book kickstarters of all time.  So again, thank you so much.

updates.update_userinfo: Another Stretch Goal down and a LIVE EVENT coming up
updates.update_content:
Hello White Ashians/ Glarien fans.
We hope you're all having an incredible weekend.  This campaign continues to blow away all our expectations.  So much so, that we're just about out of our Hardcovers we had allotted for this campaign. (We will have a couple available post-campaign in backerkit, but only a couple.) campaign.story:
Mars has perished. A red sea of dust is broken by jagged mountains dotted with the ruins of ancient pyramids. Evil sorcerers rule supreme. You play Knights of the House of Mars. The only ones who can bring life back to this planet.
 What is This?
Knights of the House of Mars is a role-playing game where players take on the role of knights who accompany the Last Seer eastward to the Pyramid of Tharsis. The world is dead; the way it became so and the reason you journey eastward are questions to discover the answers to through play with your friends at the table.

Knights of the House of Mars was a project I first started in 2018 as part of the 200 Word RPG Design Challenge. It ended up placing as a finalist that year. This zine edition is a fully re-imagined re-designed table top game for 2 - 4 players. It makes use of a single deck of ordinary playing cards. 

KotHoM is a GM-less cooperative game where each player in turn sets a scene about their knight as they journey eastward, answering questions and determining their character's fates.  Play resolves these scenes using a deck of cards and player detailed characteristics. 
A Doom That You Shall Never Escape
Each character is made up of Traits, Gifts, a Duty & a Doom. Each of these are player determined and act as ways to fictionally position the character in scenarios determined during play. They act mechanically also and are assigned card values that form the players' hands, drawn from the deck of playing cards. These characteristics are used in the conflict resolution system. 

When it is not your turn or scene, you play as the NPCs or antagonists. When conflicts arise you play cards sifted from the Seer's Scrying Pool. The Scrying Pool is a spread of cards determined at the start of play that remain face up until they are pulled and played. Watch as the portents of your fate slowly fade from in front of you. 

At the end of play, once the Seer safely arrives at the pyramid, players shuffle cards they have earned from succeeding at conflicts and draw one final card from that shuffled spread. This card determines their final fate. What happens to these knights once they reach their goal? Their ultimate fate lays between the stars at night. 
A Point-Crawl of Role-playing Scenes
From the Forest of Broken Dreams, to the Doom Prism of Exalted Light, all the way to the Pyramid of Tharsis each scene you choose to play out leads you closer to your fate, and the end of your journey. Whether it be an intimate conversations by the camp fire, or your caravan under attack -there is always room for conflict to arise in every scene!

campaign.story:
Welcome to Alley-Oop! a game of Hoops and Heartthrobs: a rules-light TTRPG book about a fantastical basketball tournament and the hijinx of the players both on and off the court: the romance, the rivalries, the SLAM DUNKS!! Inspired by Blaseball, Jelle's Marble Runs, Space Jam and, of course, the WNBA, Alley-Oop! turns the joy of rolling a fistful of dice into exciting collaborative storytelling.
A preview of the zine, layout and text not final.
Let's talk rules!
You and the other players will each represent a basketball team that has made it to the championships. Each player on your team is represented by a polyhedral die. When it's time to play ball you shake your players and ROLL! Depending on the results, cards are drawn to discover what amazing feat of basketball your players accomplished. You narrate the action, add absurd details, provide sports commentary, and act out player interviews. The outcomes of the game may be left to chance, but whether you are playing a legion of all-stars or a scrappy bunch of rookies, you control how you tell the story of the game and its players.
An example of Kat's art, our internal illustrator!
After every Game Day there is an Off Day. This is where we get to see the players lives unfold off the court. From training montages, to chance encounters in the cafeteria, to filming commercials, this is your chance to open the story beyond basketball and learn more about the lives of the players.  Inevitably, Game Days affect Off Days and Off Days affect Game Days. By the end of the championship you've not only found who has won the championship but how the players lives were changed in the process.
Basketball at the Limits of Your Imagination! The world of Alley-Oop! is not set in stone because we want to help you imagine new and amazing scenarios each and every time you play. One time, you might be a group of aliens and cartoon characters, in another game you might be a group of sea monsters blowing off steam. As long as your world gives them plenty of chances to interact and the players are open to the characters developing romances and rivalries, you're good to go.
We include prompts for developing your own setting, but the book will have additional starting scenarios in the back. Layout and text not final.
Not a fan of basketball? Don’t have time to invent a whole scenario? Don’t fret! We’ve put thought into the types of folks who would enjoy this game and have made sure to make a level playing field (pun intended) for basketball experts and power gamers alike. The game includes a glossary of basketball terminology and slang to help spice up your narration, as well as ten starter scenarios in case you want to kick-start your game. 

The game, the glossary, the seed scenarios, the tables, and the beautiful art will make this a nearly 40 page zine!

We need your help!
Alley-Oop! has been fully designed and play-tested but we need your help turning it into a beautiful zine that is easy to read, and exciting to page through.
We have a layout artist, a few illustrators, a copy-editor and printing press lined up. All of these amazing collaborators need to be paid for their hard work turning our Google Doc into a fantastic zine for you to behold. Then we need to print and ship our game to you. All of this takes both time and money.
A sample of Molly James' work, our cover artist!
Once you've helped us fund this project, we'll spend the next 3 months working with our collaborators to perfect the pages and then the following 3 months getting the zine printed and shipped to you, our backers. This is a generous estimate because this is our first time running a Kickstarter. We believe this will be enough to get all our ducks in a row but in case of any delays we, of course, will keep you updated every step of the way.

Co-created by gay wife team Kaysy Ostrom (right) & Legendary Vermin (left), the inspiration for Alley-Oop! came after we watched a full season of WNBA together in quarantine (Go Seattle Storm!) Vermin, an accomplished game designer (What's So Cool About Giant Robots?, Skirmish, BEACH EPISODE, Æthernet) approached Kaysy with the idea of turning a basketball championship into a trpg. Kaysy, a newbie game designer but an avid role-player, theatre artist and award-winning playwright (Devushka & the Cat, Plant & Her, Sweet Sweet Justice), was eager to bring her passion for theatrical storytelling into her first game. Together, our love for role-playing games, women's basketball, and queer storytelling is at the heart of Alley-Oop!
Maria Mison is a piece of queer filipina sunshine from manila who loves anything slice-of-life, catharticly vulnerable, everyday lyric magick performance dream game stuff. She really likes collages & layout lately.
Kat Taylor is a nonbinary artist from Boston by way of the PNW! They love drawing action poses, girls, and gay stuff, so they’re super excited to lend their talent to this amazing project! When Kat isn't drawing, they like to enjoy a good (or bad) monster movie, eating delicious food, and absorbing any kind of comics they can get their eyeballs on. When they *are* drawing, their art explores the many faces (literally!) of humans as well as monsters. You can find them on most social media as @katatomicart, or their website.
Lexi Antoku is a professional Oxford comma advocate and casual cat advocate. They respect English in the same way one might respect hot stoves or wires with frayed insulation.
Molly James is an artist living in Seattle with her partner and a growing collection of Magic cards. When not drawing monsters, she makes comics about delinquent robots.

Budget Breakdown
Why $1,500 you ask? This is a hefty zine and we want to pay all of our artists and collaborators what they are worth while being cautious about fees and unexpected costs. Anything that does not end up costing what we expect will be reinvested in our artists and collaborators and of course the zine itself. Here is our budget breakdown:
Art - $150
Layout - $300
Printing/Shipping - $150
Editing - $500
Kickstarter Fees/Taxes - $200
Uh Oh Fund - $200

Stretch Goals
If you help us move above and beyond our goals we have some exciting ideas to make this project even better!
At $1,700  we will be able to pay our artists to double the amount of art in the zine. Double the art, double the fun! 
At $2000 we will be able to make custom team-tracking sheets that help you organize play.
Any additional funds will be invested in our artists and collaborators and of course the zine itself! Thank you for your support!

What the what?! We've had to write and delete this update THREE TIMES today because every time we look back at the page, you wondrous, generous people have pushed us past YET ANOTHER STRETCH GOAL??

campaign.story:
Build a magic school of your own design...
promotional art by @dancynrew
Walk through a day in the life of a student at a magical school in each session that you and friends play together of this GMless tabletop roleplaying game for 2+ players. You will collaborate to gradually fill out just what sorts of wonders and mysteries abound, both on campus and between each other as companions.
Build your campus, deciding not just its architecture, but also just how reality-warpingly magical it is. Is your school located among the clouds, underwater, in a modern public school's classrooms, hidden in a shoebox, or even just the village midwife's cottage? 
Your own player characters, or Companions, form a closely-knit friend group. You are also invited to populate the school with peers, rivals, friends and tutors. Once these elements are introduced, they remain persistent across sessions thanks to a handy stack of index cards that grow into a detailed Reference Deck.
Character traits and school lessons are both organized around the same set of five attributes, detailing the traits that your academic studies seek to inculcate and cultivate within your Companions:
Esoterica: Your grasp of complex mathemagical theory, and capability to express it in evocations of power.
Craft: Your skills of maintenance, repair, and creation across a broad suite of tools, reagents, and skills.
Drive: Your motivation and perseverance, permitting you to push through any obstacles between you and your aims.
Attunement: Your perception of and connection to your surroundings, permitting acts of adroit intuition and disarming empathy.
Wit: Your nimbleness of deed and tongue, suitable for getting you both out of and into absolute heaps of trouble.

The Day's Long Arc
Play proceeds through several phases over the course of a day of school life
Each plot arc of Arcane Academia represents one day of classes, from the groggy, yawning morning all the way through to the late-night escapades that will leave you just as sleepy tomorrow. Each arc is meant to occupy one session of play, though there aren't any particular consequences if you break it up over multiple sessions. If desired, these arcs chain together neatly into an extended campaign with a growing continuity, but the game also performs admirably as a standalone one-shot!
A core, repeating element of play repeatedly is congregating to share meals together. Breakfast, lunch and dinner here serve as regular check-ins with each other, opportunities to take a break, and chances to steer events and tone into more exciting and/or comfortable territory. 
In the course of your studies into the strange and magical, you will earn the plaudits of your peers and humiliations from your tutors, and vice-versa. These provide your Companions with the motive and means to roll with the circumstances and make the best of them--or give you ample room to burn goodwill and leave yourself more desperate.
Choose how you spend your precious free time, whether that means taking some time alone to clear your head, making up for past messes, or starting a whole new mess of drama.
After dinner, sneak off on daring escapades. Will you wreak mischief upon rivals whom the day's events have brought you into conflict with, or discover the deeper secrets and mysteries of your campus?
What sorts of teachers will you create for your own school? How will you characterize them?
$3000 - Stretch goal #1: Alone In My Ancient Tower
All backers will receive a free extra game! Digital pdf copies of the author's one-page game Alone In My Ancient Tower to all backers, and an additional printout copy to all physical zine-level backers and above. 
AIMAT cover art by @sasha_reneau
This solemn and melancholy meditation takes place at the opposite end of a magic-wielder's lifespan than their halcyon school days: venerable and ancient, you wander your empty fastness and dwell upon artifacts and memories of times past. It is written in the mode of the Alone games, as codified by Takuma Okada.
This stretch goal will allow me to replace my aging laptop, ensuring fewer technical difficulties and risks during production as the author wrangles the layout staff, editing team and content-typewriting monkeys (read: as I wrangle me, me, and me) through production in Affinity Publisher.

$4500 - Stretch Goal 2: Free Time activities written by guest authors!
At this level, I will commission five fellow ttrpg writers $150 apiece to write me one-page minigames that will plump out the roster of possible activities that your Companions can stir themselves to, given the opportunity.
These games won't be strictly limited to one page. That said, these guest authors will be asked to turn in minigames that are close to 500 words long, which puts their rate of pay at approximately 30 cents per word.

$6000 - Stretch Goal 3: Coursework class alternates written by guest authors!
At this level, I will commission another five writers at the same rate to come up with one-page minigames to serve as alternative classes. These will optionally replace existing classes during the Coursework phase to allow for a more flexible curriculum, increasing replayability and providing variety for long-form campaign play.

$8000 - Stretch Goal 4: Lavish Feasts, illustrated by guest artists!
At this level, I will commission full-page art for Breakfast, Lunch and Dinner splash pages for $250 each from three artists. I would love to see what fun details these artists bring to the commissions, and to see their own spin on how a magical academy would feed such a chaotic, festive mass of hungry students.

$10,000 - Stretch Goal 5: pay guest writers more, and extra Challenges
At this level, all previous guest writers will receive a $50 pay bump. After this point, every stretch goal created will also include a further pay raise for guest writers and artists.
The Challenge phase of play represent the higher-stakes, more involved minigames at the end of the night. This is where you cash in your hard-won experiences throughout the day to earn a payoff. At this stretch goal, I will write an additional five Challenges for the game, providing a much broader range of scripted plot beats for you and your Companions to face together.
oh, what a cheeky scamp
Influences
Arcane Academia owes a great deal to the Firebrands Framework, as pioneered by Meguey and Vincent Baker. It also draws extensively from the structure of my previous game, Celestial Bodies, Orbital Mechanics, my entry into #ZineQuest2 last year.
Arcane Academia is inspired by a childhood spent immersed in fantastical stories. It is woven from a love of Discworld, Earthsea, Redwall, the Old Kingdom, Bartimaeus, The Once and Future King, The Name of the Wind, the Edge Chronicles, Discworld, and the Dying Earth, among so many others. To reduce it to any single influence would be reductive and insincere.
It also represents an opportunity to imagine our own worlds of magic, wonder and delight. It offers worlds tailored to whim and fancy. It permits worlds that suit us both as we are and as we dream to be. It can be an exorcism of old ghosts.
"as long as this catalyzes properly, there's only a slim chance that—uh oh, it's started smoking"
This project is a participant in #ZineQuest3, among good company.

campaign.story:
Story
Somewhere far, far away from the comfort of your own home, there’s a stretch of sea so vast it holds a million islands of varying size. The regions of this sea can be neatly divided by their Dooms; apocalyptic events that are threatening the very existence of not only the islands, but the world as we know it. 
Is it your job to stop the Dooms? I don’t know. Maybe. But regardless, this zine will function as a guide to one such region, its Doom, and the end of the world as we know it. Welcome, dear reader.
hex map
The hex map was put together in Cecil Howe's Hex Kit with Nate Treme's "Tiles of Xark" set. It features art from the amazing Evlyn Moreau, and an additional map from the illustrious Dyson Logos. 
It features 36 explorable hexes with a variety of interesting and weird encounters, including sky pirates, a strange crystal drug that lets you live inside someone's mind, and Doom Cultists who are trying to summon an ancient demon through a volcanic eruption. No big deal, really.
The most exciting part about this is that the adventure starts you off with a boat, dubbed "The Colossal Waste" with stats and all that good stuff. PLUS it has enough space for a 'Porco Rosso'-style biplane to take off and land, letting you engage with the sky pirates in their domain (or do some solo scouting, if you're feeling brave!).
Hexes
With a help from my co-author and friend, Batts, we have some preview images of the zine to show off some of the art & hexes involved! As a DM, they're aimed to hopefully get you as excited to run this as I am. 

Robin Berry, your friend in the islands!
Meet Robin Berry! She's everyone's friend, and she'd love to follow you along on the boat. She can be a very useful guide, even if she doesn't know everything about this place. Help her fulfill her dreams, or at least have a chat with her about...
Volcano, it's the DOOM!
The great volcano! The resting place of the great calamity, Garamond itself. Will it be the final resting place? Not if these cultists have anything to say about it. They're chanting, sacrificing, and praying to any dark power who will listen to them to help them awaken their burning lord of magma. Will you find a way to stop them; or perhaps find a way to join them? Either way it goes, there's plenty more to see in these islands...

A magnificent crab, and a magnificent beard!
When out sailing, it's very easy to run into strange things. A hermit, keeping secrets on a deserted island? Sure! The most beautiful and magnificent crab to ever grace the seafloor? Why not! They're simple enough encounters for any kind of party to put their own spin on. These two stand out as especially enjoyable for any fellow druids, to me.

The crystal drug, and the Dragon
This is a miniature view of the crystal meteorite, and what has grown from it. What you're not seeing is the page on the crystal drug effects, the two forested hexes above it, and the beautiful two-page spread of Blackbeak itself! I wrote a bit more about this particular piece of art as an update, but a computer screen hardly does it justice.

Meet all of these people, creatures, and travel to the beautiful locations soon, when you get your hands on this terrific island.

DOOM
The DOOM of this region is the volcano. Inside of it is the demon Garamond and his many, many faces. With each eruption a new face has been carved, and the cultists swear that this upcoming eruption (their 1000th) will bring about the final face and release Garamond for good. Well. Evil, but you get the point.
The zine comes with a tracker to measure the time until the next eruption, and the encounter and weather tables each have a second column for post-eruption options. All of this to say that the zine does not expect you to care about saving the world, in fact, maybe you can join the cultists and Garamond will reward you with a terrible, horrible, life-altering pact!
zine
The zine is sitting around 44 pages right now, it will be staple bound, and printed with mixam.com. Shipping will be collected after the campaign with backerkit so that we can make sure international shipping rates are up to date. It's possible the zine could grow during the funding and fulfillment period, but it will not get any smaller.
I am currently located in Sweden, but fulfillment is being done in the US through my coauthor and friend, Batts. Expect shipping to go through them!
All artwork was used with permission. Go become a patron of Evlyn's, support Cecil by buying Hexkit, buy the Xark tiles from Nate, and support the amazing work of Dyson.
team
This is where I would be describing the team, but in reality there are only two of us. Batts has helped with the writing, and will be handling fulfillment. I appreciate it with every heart I have since I'm still a fresh-face in the kickstarter world! You can count on the campaign going well with Batts at the helm.
I did a lot of the writing, and we worked on the light layout together, I've done a few previous projects, and I wrote an adventure for Iron & Lies. I firmly believe that you'll love what we've got in the zine for you.

campaign.story:
"It was a dive, same as any other I've seen, where the good people of the world while away their troubles.  The self loathing and decay of the city pushing even the best of people to the bottle.  Me? I can't stand the stuff, at least while I'm on the job.  The smoke obscured faces and the radio in the corner did it's best to muddy the voices too. It was about as close as you could come to being anonymous, at least without paying for the privacy.  As I found my way to the back booth, I was sure this client and case would spell trouble."
What is Hardboiled?
Hardboiled is a detective RPG zine with a noir edge.  Players take the role of a Chandler-esque detective  in the 1920's solving cases in the fictional city of Blackport.  This is a stand alone system and setting, but much of the mechanics can be used to add a hardboiled edge to other systems.  You can play the game as one shots or as a larger campaign with a broader narrative.
The game utilizes a narrative form of character creation instead of standard stat rolling.  Players also have input on each others characters during character creation and collaboratively design the group's detective agency.  The narrative creation allows for players to design their character through the use of a fill in the blank narrative paragraph, similar to a mad lib, that focuses on adjectives and imaginative descriptions to shape the character instead of randomly generated statistics.
The Narrative paragraph is a good place to springboard off of to more fully detail out NPC's and characters.  For example, rolling an NPC named Sven Jorgunson, the tables determine he is blonde, handsome, and seductive.  Once the narrative is filled in, a few little changes can yield something like this:
"Sven Jorgunson tapped lightly on the doorframe. I only knew his name from hearing him flirt with the secretary outside.  A habit for him, surely, as he was more blonde than she was.  Whatever issue brought him here didn't seem to weigh too heavily on his mind. A corporate interest, perhaps.  I waved him in and he smoothly disengaged from the secretary and took a seat. Ladies would be no problem for this guy."
The game also has a case generation system included.  This allows narrators to quickly roll and determine clues, crimes, and plot twist and then incorporate them into the game.  By using a flowchart for scenes and setting, narrators can establish what clues link various scenes together and then fill in details as needed.  This can serve as an excellent initial structure for more detailed and complex adventures, or as a quick way to generate pick up and play one-off cases.
These mechanics, the games narrative focus and case design, coupled with player facing combat and play help make the game dynamic and enjoyable for players of all experience levels. The rules light system is quick to pick up, but still memorable.  The game is also enjoyable over longer periods of time, and transferable to other mechanical systems.  There are game options for narrators running a single player as well.
The Hardboiled genre is often overlooked within the roleplaying game community, but it's wonderfully entertaining and full of memorable tropes.  The genre's focus on society's ills and political corruption makes it a good choice for adaptation into a role-playing game and a satisfying game to play and run.  There is a wealth of literary sources to draw inspiration from, each of whom have introduced variations on the main theme. All of these translate well to different character archetypes and group playstyles. 
Example of interior art
What's in the Zine?
The zine contains all you need to play Hardboiled.  The booklet includes:
*  Mechanics for character generation and agency generation
*  Mechanics for running the game
*  Generators for NPC's and locations 
*  Brief descriptions of some locations in Blackport and the different neighborhoods
*  Tips and tricks for running a detective RPG
*  A case generator   
In addition to the above, the game includes discussion of how to generate cases.  While a Narrator should spend some time thinking of the details of the case, the generator does work for creating quick adventures that can be run as pick up games, or it can be used to lay out the basic structure of a larger adventure.  The generator includes a way to create clues and help them link scenes together.
While Hardboiled is far along in its development, there is still a bit left to work with on it.  My aim is to have a 32-36 page zine + cover when the game is ready to ship.  The interior art is all black and white sketches from the same artist.  A stylized map of the city will also be included in the game booklet.
The Team
I am mainly working on this project by myself in my spare time as I work full time as a high school math teacher in Texas.  The game mechanics and design are all my own. While this is the first RPG I have attempted to publish, I have been fiddling around with similar rules for years and have 30 years of TTRPG playing under my belt.  I have wanted to put this sort of project out there for awhile and have finally jumped out to do so.
Funds raised from this Kickstarter will go primarily to printing copies and finishing art.  I have some art for the game already and the artist is ready to complete more work on the project.  The game has had some play testing already but needs a final round to iron out some kinks from the latest changes.  The booklet feels about 90% ready to me at the moment and I am proud of how smoothly it  has come together.  I have already priced printing costs and shipping so mostly just need funds to finish art and then produce the physical copies.

campaign.story:
You are Rowan. You are fat. Last time you knew your exact weight it was over 300 pounds, though that was over six months ago since you don’t make a point of using a scale. You have decided to spend today taking care of yourself.
You start by getting an early diner breakfast with a sweetheart that spent the night.
You and your special someone have a favorite place, where they know you and cook the best pancakes in town. You often find yourself here together after your more strenuous evenings together. The waiter brings you orange juice with your menus, and asks if you want the regular. What is the most indulgent item of your regular order? You nod and make small talk with them for a few moments about your plans for the day. While waiting for your food, your companion cozies up next to you in the booth. How do they express their affection for you? You exchange greetings with a few other patrons that recognize you. Your waiter brings you something extra that they prepared on accident. What is it?
Everything is delicious, and after this wonderful breakfast, you have an appointment to get to.
I am fat and I am loved.
I am fat and I invest in my heart.
Heart by Robohaven - A gray filligree design with a heart motif
What is Fat Self Care?
Fat Self Care is a solo journaling game where you play Rowan, a fat person, as they go through a day of fun and fulfilling activities. At each point during the day, you will have several choices of which activity you want to do next, and each activity will provide several questions for you to shape Rowan's inner life, relationships, and self-image. Each activity ends with two affirmations - reclaiming the word fat and giving you and Rowan a truth that is commonly denied to fat people.
Volume 1 will be a 24-page, 5.5"x8.5" staple-bound zine that includes at least 21 scenes like the one above, all written by fat contributors and designed to be gender-ambivalent - you can play Rowan as any or no gender with the body characteristics or your choice, aside from being fat, which is mandatory. The cover art for this campaign will be used as the cover art for the zine, and has been licensed from Maya Kern (@mayakern on Twitter, store.mayakern.com).
Rose by Robohaven - a gray filigree design with a rose motif
Who is making Fat Self Care?
The lead designer for Fat Self Care is Aven Elia McConnaughey (ey/em/eir, @transistence on twitter, transistence.itch.io for other work). Ey lives in Minnesota with eir partner, two cats, and soon to be new puppy. Ey is queer, fat, and disabled. Aven has received a Golden Cobra honorable mention, was selected as a 200 Word RPG Contest finalist, and contributed to the Silver ENnie-winning Kids on Bikes: Strange Adventures! Volume 2. Ey has just founded Tabletop Hotdish, an indie zine printing shop, which will be handling fulfillment for this campaign.

Additional contributors for Fat Self Care: Volume 1 - 

Olivia Montoya (she/her), 28, is a fat, queer, bi/pan asexual, latinx, Autistic, chronically ill femme. She is a graphic designer who spends her free time writing and creating tools for ttrpgs and larps. She also is very involved in the DIY zine community, is a hobbyist digital artist, and creates queer narrative video games. Find out more about her work and get her social links here: http://bit.ly/oliviamportfolio

Cat McDonald (they/she) is the designer at Peach Garden Games (http://www.peachgardengames.com), and the GM of the Actual Playtest podcast Sword of Symphonies, a test of their cozy fantasy game Heroic Chord. They also helped organize the Solo But Not Alone bundle (https://itch.io/b/770/solo-but-not-alone), a package of single-player TTRPGs benefitting suicide prevention org Jasper's Game Day.

Molua (they/them) is a nonbinary creator, originally from Belfast and currently residing in Kent. They produce both TTRPGs and Poetry, covering basically anything that catches their interest. You can find them at instagram.com/lughaidh_lamfada/ and https://moluayy.itch.io/

Ziva (she/her) is a queer, disabled TTRPG player, writer, and podcaster. She loves cats, unicorns, roller coasters, and playing disc golf with her partner. You can hear her play all sorts of TTRPGs with her friends on The Eternity Archives podcast. She wants to be the village witch when she grows up.

Ken Davidson (He/Him) is a married father of two residing in the San Francisco Bay Area (East Bay!). He designs games as well as structured performance art pieces. He has games that teach respectful and fun ways to flirt, games where you literally go yell at your representatives at their events until you get kicked out and games where you play someone working at a Megacorp in a cyberpunk dystopia. You can find his games at http://davidson925.itch.io he's also on Twitter @KDavidson925

Eva Schiffer (she/her) is a larpwright and tabletop rpg designer. She has been writing games for more than 10 years and playing for more than 20. You can find more of her game design work on her webpage: https://digitalchangeling.com/design/index.html

Jessie Rainbow (she/her) is a fat queer/pan writer, gamer, and cloud enthusiast. She lives in Olympia, WA with her sassy dog Grandma Waffle. She often works with Tim Hutchings and Jackson Tegu to help playtest games, compliment games, and talk game shop. Her life feels most decadent when it's filled with tea, story, and poems. You can find her game Our Shared Horizon here.

Other designers include Aura Belle and Ash Cheshire.

The stretch goal artists are Shelby Bergen and Jess Lome.

Shelby Bergen is an illustrator, designer and world champion cat petter from the frozen Midwest. Her work is full of fun shapes, bright colors and diverse bodies, particularly fat bodies. Shelby has worked with Virgie Tovar, The Body Love Box, and Rad Fat Adventure Camp; her work was also published in The Other F Word: A Celebration of the Fat and Fierce. She’s also co-curator of Fat Craft, a yearly spooky themed charity zine featuring fat artists drawing fat folks. When Shelby isn’t drawing fat babes, she can be found gardening, reading books and crocheting. Find her on Twitter and Instagram.
Wheel by Robohaven - a geometric filigree design a semicirclular wheen pattern
Why Fat Self Care: Volume 1?
The contributors to Fat Self Care all have their own reasons for contributing, For Aven, there are many scenarios in society where fat people are either explicitly made to feel othered and unwelcome, or do so internally because of this conditioning. Dreading medical visits because of how the doctor will inevitably tie any health issue back to your weight, avoiding changing clothes around others because you don't want to inflict yourself on them, not ordering the food we want, feeling unable to trust the relationships around us because of what people might be saying behind our backs or what they will eventually say to our face. The scenes in this game are our attempt to take these lived experiences and reimagine them in ways that turn them into positive, affirming moments. This is a non-exhaustive list of all the ways society is dangerous or hostile to fat people, but it covers some of the situations included in Fat Self Care: Volume 1. 

Creating this collection has been very rewarding and has shown how much potential there is for creating small, albeit imagined, spaces for us to exist and love and move and thrive in our fat bodies. This first volume will cover a variety of situations, but future editions will have themes - find more about plans for Volume 2 below!
Eyes 2 by Robohaven - a gray filigree pattern with a repeating eye pattern and leaf motif
What else can we get? (Stretch Goals)
In the spirit of Zine Quest, there are going to be limited stretch goals to keep the scope of the project manageable. There have been changes to these since the project launched due to conversations with artists.
$2000 - At this level of funding, we will be able to get custom cover art for Fat Self Care: Volume 1 and for the eventual Volume 2.
$3000 - At this level of funding, we will be able to set aside money to pay contributors for Fat Self Care: Volume 2, which will focus on relationships and intimacy. All backers will get a digital copy of Volume 2 when it is released.

Eyes 1 by Robohaven - another gray filigree pattern with an eye motif.
Where does the money go?
The money from this Kickstarter is primarily needed to fund the print run and distribution.  Printing and art costs will take up 30% of the funds raised of the initial goal. Kickstarter fees take about 10%. All contributors have already been paid $20 for their 200-word scenarios, and the remaining funds raised will be split equally amongst them as well.

updates.update_content:
Hi again everyone! Excited to share new information about the project with y'all - artists, new contributors, and more.

First, we reached out first stretch goal a few days ago, and first, I am so appreciative of the support that got us here. I'm very happy to announce the two artists we're bringing on board for the custom cover art. They are the co-curators of the excellent Fat Craft Zine, Shelby Bergen (she/her) and Jess Lome (she/her). Their art is so lovely, joyous, and fat and I'm so excited to have them on the project. Jess will be responsible for the new cover art for Volume 1 and once that art is finished, backers will be able to choose between the art from Maya Kern and the new art from Jess. Shelby will be making the art for Volume 2. More detailed bios for them will be added to the campaign page as I receive them.

Hi everyone, Aven here! I know it's traditional to send out an update once you fund, but it's 2021, we live in a society, life comes at you fast, etc. But we are for sure funded, which is very exciting! Just funding means you are putting more $$ into the pocket of some amazing creators contributing their voices and experiences to this project. BUT WAIT! There's more!

After speaking with some artists about doing the custom cover art, I lowered the funding goal for both of our stretch goals - partly because I based the initial numbers on estimates that turned out to be way off, but also, primarily, because I so badly want to get both the custom art and Volume 2 funded (and more money into our excellent writers' pockets). The interest in this project tells me that there are folks out there hungry for these stories, and there are so many more of them to tell! To recap, while Volume 1 does include some scenes involving romantic partners, Volume 2 will be dedicated to relationships and all different kinds of intimacy - romantic, platonic, and sexual - and will be offered to all backers at the $10 level or higher. That's right, for as little as $10, you get two beautiful, expertly-crafted games that provide comfort and respite and joy - but only if the campaign reaches $3000.

campaign.story:
Want to play the game now? Download the playtest rules!
Blood Feud is a role-playing game about toxic masculinity: certain common attitudes and behaviors among men, that cause great harm to them and to others around them. This is a game about people being nasty to each other and about figuring out why.
It’s also a game about vikings of pre-christian Scandinavia; about honor and blood feuds, courage and brutality, corruption and consequences. Above all it is a game about what it means to be a man in such a world—and what consequences that has on the communities they live in.
The goal of the game is to explore and experience toxic masculinity, while at the same time creating a thoughtful drama about relationships, competition and social consequences. With this game we want to make toxic masculinity easier to spot for a wider variety of people in our roleplaying communities—and encourage critical discussions about how men behave, and why.
The central theme of this game is power—specifically the power of men: How you earn it, what you have to do to keep it, and most importantly what you do with it.
To make power visible, we use a currency called Honor Tokens. Throughout the game these tokens  will get moved around between the players as their main characters interact with each other—depending on how “manly” or “honorable” their actions are.
Since there is no Game Master, all players must pay attention to the seven Moves that cause honor to shift. In this way, every player has to learn to recognize these behaviors and how they affect the power structures. The seven moves are:
Sharing someone’s bed
Giving someone a gift
Commenting on a woman’s appearance
Praising someone
Insulting someone
Escalating
Striking a deadly blow
Apart from moves, the game uses a concept called Narrative Freedom to handle questions of narrative authority. This means that every player has equal say in describing the fictional world and what happens in it—up until a move is triggered. Players may interrupt each others’ narration, but only to do one of two things: making an addendum or adding an obstacle.
An addendum is an extra detail added to what was just said.
An obstacle is a roadblock that explains why something that was about to happen, didn’t happen.
Addendums and obstacles allow for playing out scenes in an improv style, instead of using traditional resolution tools such as dice or cards.
There are also mechanics in place that deal specifically with the role of women in the game. The first one: there must always be at least one woman present in every scene. When the last woman in a scene leaves, the scene simply ends. We are only interested in what happens publicly when looking at honor, so what happens when women are not watching doesn’t count.
Secondly, at the end of each scene, the players who played women must decide which of the men in the scene was the least manly. That man loses one honor token. Hence, the men must always compete for the attention of the women and their implicit approval.
The printed zine will be a ~50-page A5 saddle-stitched booklet, with a sturdy paper cover.
The game is illustrated by Ronja Melin, with rune carving ornaments by Jonas Lau Markussen.
“I loved how Blood Feud was both a serious game and a game filled with relatable comedy. It was liberating to embody parts of the patriarchal male gender norms that I still encounter in my life today. The best thing about the gaming experience was not play itself, but the discussion that the experience prompted afterwards—about our characters’ choices and motivations. Another thing that sticks out is the power the female characters had in forming the narrative. It is an intelligent game design that shines a light on gender structures in a natural manner.” – Siri Sandquist, playtester
“Blood Feud is an intelligent and thought-provoking role-playing game. It charmed me with its mechanics and made me invested in its narrative tools. Most importantly, it gave me the one thing I wanted: A great story with compelling characters.” – Emil Hannu, playtester
"An interesting twist on the Dream Askew engine. More interested in what's actually in the Icelandic sagas than other viking games. Excellent instructions for establishing relationship maps, and making them useful in the game. The honor system is a great tool to discuss how we see each other." – Pontus Kjellberg, playtester
“The story and the gaming experience were unlike anything I have played before. The game explores a very difficult topic that allows for some really dark experiences—provided your group is comfortable with that. The game has several mechanics to ensure a safe and respectful gaming environment. Everyone who plays Blood Feud will gain new knowledge about themselves and their surrounding world—what it is depends on the player and the group. I realized how quickly an insignificant dispute can escalate into a blood feud, bringing down the whole community with it.” – Anna Sandberg, Svartviken Rollspelspodd 
"No Game Master, no dice resolution mechanics. Just a narrative SJW circle-jerk is what this game is—if you want to call it a game even. This is right along the lines of precisely why SJW games and gamers suck and are so pathetic and terrible. They are always trying to turn RPG's into a shitty pseudo-psychological therapy session." – Redacted, Internet forum
"A fun freeform game that makes you reflect afterwards. One of the best gaming experiences I've had in a long time. Role-playing that allows for an interesting exchange of thoughts and ideas." – Micael Fryksäter, Mindy bräd- och rollspelspodd
"A game that focuses on a constantly relevant topic. Rules-light but content-heavy. One of my better gaming experiences in a long time." – Kristoffer Hermansson, Spelsnackarna

Bläckfisk Publishing is a collective of brainstormers, dreamers and hard workers. We want people to feel, create stories and explore the unknown. Therefore, we focus on developing tools for empathy, improvisation and community—usually in the form of role-playing games.
The company was founded by independent game creators. Previously we developed games individually, but since we share both basic approaches and ambitions, we joined forces—to increase our capacity and competence.
Amos Persson is one of the authors and the primary source of gender studies and feminist knowledge for this game. They have been designing games since 2014 and organizing queer and activist spaces since 2018. Amos has been the RPG and LARP coordinator for the award winning Swedish convention QueerCon two years running and is the current chairperson of the national committee of QueerNördarna—a Swedish organization dedicated to providing nerd friendly spaces on LGBTQIA+ people’s terms.
Peter Malmberg is the second author of this game, and has been designing role-playing games since 2014. Lately, his game design ideas have pivoted towards GM-less collaborative storytelling games, along the line of Fiasco, Fall of Magic, Follow, Dream Askew, and so on. He is the creator of the safety tool Traffic Lights and the Swedish RPG Fornsaga. Apart from editing, Peter is also in charge of the business administration and accounting at Bläckfisk Publishing.
Lucas Falk is one of the editors, as well as the one in charge of the game’s layout. His background is in information design—editing, copywriting and layout for books and brochures. He’s the author of the Swedish RPG Vindsjäl and the manual Rekommendationer för rollspelsregler (RPG Rules Recommendations), co-author of the RPGs Godtale and Thespian, as well as host of the Swedish podcast Fummelpodden.
Kristoffer Warnberg is also an editor—and the one in charge of distribution. He works as a librarian and is the author of the Swedish RPG Skrômt and co-author of the RPG Godtale. Kristoffer is also a host of the Swedish actual play podcast Svartviken Rollspelspodd.
Vindsjäl is a Swedish adventure role-playing game, focusing on freedom, joy of exploration and camaraderie. It’s set in a vibrant, optimistic and atypical fantasy world. 
Skrômt is a Swedish horror role-playing game, focused on relationships and drama. It’s set in an alternative present-day Sweden—where creatures from Nordic folklore dwell in the darkness of the forest and in the shadows of civilisation. 
In Godtale, you portray aesir, asynjur and vanir of your own creation. Together, you go on adventures in the Nine Realms. But each of you wants to be the deity who earns the most glory—not infrequently at the expense of your companions.
Fornsaga is a modern take on the traditional role-playing game, set in the Norse Iron Age. Together, you explore who your characters are, their destinies, their relationships—as well as a world that civilisation has not yet subjugated.

campaign.story:
A monster has overtaken the city. Massive, it smashes through buildings and destroys everything in its path. The two of you have escaped it thus far. There is every possibility you will die in the next 5 minutes, but before you do, you have a secret to tell....
 Crush is about getting what you need to out in the open before being crushed by a kaiju.
It's two micro RPGs in one! The Single Player component is a solo journaling game and the Multiplayer can be played by 2 (or more) players. The physical rulebook is 16 interior pages, covering both games. The multiplayer game requires a tumbling wooden tower game and the solo requires a journal or notebook to collect your adventure as you write it.
Inspired by the kaiju/monster genre of cinema, disaster fiction, and the chaotic competitive board games of the 1980s and 90s, Crush can be either a game about coming together and moving forward or winning- it's all up to you!
Backers will receive the rules to both games and handouts with kaiju designed by artist Joey Weiser. These can be printed, colored, or cut out for pop ups at home.
PLAY

 Crush has two modes:
Photo by Mike Baumeister
The ground rumbles and the building shakes around you. You look into your companion's eyes and know this might be the last conversation you ever have. You have to tell them... but maybe just hear what they have to say first...

Two player games will take place over mere minutes, or can last an hour. It all depends on your skills. Players have something dire to tell each other. There is a secret they have carried for years, and have sorely regretted not telling it. In these dire circumstances, players feel the urge to tell the truth, but are still afraid of how their companion will react.
As players have what might be their final conversation, they pull from a tumbling wood tower. Adding to the stress of the situation are the rumblings of the creature raging through the city. The vibrations of its rampage can be felt within the room, and take the form of a vibrating timer (or cell phone alarm), set to disrupt the conversation and possibly upset the tower.
Your goal is to not have your secret told first. Whoever has their secret told first, either by them or through the other player guessing first, loses the game. If the tower falls, the monster has found you and you both lose. If one person guesses another’s secret before they can tell it, they are the winner.
Photo by Katie Smith
You wake up with rubble piled around you and dust clogging the air. You are alone. Where have your companions gone? How will you find them again? Things are quiet, now, but is the creature still talking the streets, looming above and waiting to strike?

The single player mode of Crush is a solo journaling RPG. For each day, you receive a prompt. With the help of random tables of events and descriptions, you will start to build the narrative of what happened after the creature came. You will answer questions like what was destroyed, how has it affected you, and what have you had to do to survive.
Most importantly, you will search for the companion who was with you when it all started, and over the course of a month, determine their fate while defining your own. The journaling component takes the form of a choose your own adventure narrative with prompts shifting as the days continue based on decisions you have made before. This makes it a replayable solo RPG!
Photo by Ke Wen
The Single Player mode is played with a pen, paper, and prompts. Occasionally the aid of provided tables to randomize the story may be used to move things along. It is a month-long project you will complete by writing once a day, or at your own pace. This is a solo journaling RPG that may be incorporated with a game of Multiplayer Crush, or stand on its own.
The Multiplayer uses a tumbling wood tower and vibrating timer (like that available on most cellular phones) and something to record your secrets with. Players will take turns speaking and pulling a brick from the tower until one has revealed their secret, or the tower falls. Environmental effects in the form of the timer will also effect the difficulty of the situation. Multiplayer games are typically shorter affairs, where rushing or delaying too long may just cost you.
The world of Crush is kept intentionally vague. You can explore it and describe it in-depth in Single Player mode, or you can keep it a light, city-shaped idea while you try to win Multiplayer. The kaiju themselves are also kept abstract and atmospheric until you decide to talk about how they look- if you've even seen them.
An early version of the zine alongside handouts designed by Joey Weiser.
 Zine Quest backers will receive the following in physical or digital format:
Rulebook containing both Crush Multiplayer and Single Player
Color Handouts designed by Joey Weiser
Black & White Handouts designed by Joey Weiser
Photo by Daniel Hooper
This game is inspired by movies, but it also came from mashing all my action figures and Barbies together for ultimate monster movie mayhem in a city crafted from my blankets and blocks. Crush is not just about big, possibly goofy monsters. It's about imagining, exploring, and, most importantly, playing.
Films like Ishirō Honda's Godzilla, Matt Reeves' Cloverfield, Guillermo del Toro's Pacific Rim, and Bong Joon-ho's The Host, gave us terrifyingly large horrors to face off with and run from. They also built characters and relationships that have stuck with us for decades. Each film about monsters extends its themes to societal issues, environmental concerns, political maneuvers... and at their core leave us with characters who resonate with us in cities we recognize. They help us better understand where our home is, and who makes that home.
Photo by Teo Zac

campaign.story:
Collecting seashells along the rocky shore, you stumble across a battered video game cartridge half-buried in the sand. Waterlogged and corroded, there's no chance it still works, right? Still, once it has fully dried, you blow into the bottom of the cartridge, stick it into your ghost of a console, and press the POWER button...
Title Screen
The Barrier & the Sound is a 1-player tabletop game about the beauty and strangeness of the coast. It's inspired by the storm-tossed barrier islands of Pamlico Sound, the rugged evergreen coast of the Pacific Northwest, and the crumbling sandy cliffs of Southern California. In terms of media, it draws on the haunted oceanside of Oxenfree and Bones of the Coast, the dreamlike islands of Link's Awakening and Oracle of Ages / Seasons, the surreal lighthouse shores of the Southern Reach trilogy and Song of the Sea, and the lonesome ruins of Monument Valley, Journey, and Sky: Children of the Light.
Booklet Cover (draft) -- original photo by Philipp Pilz (Unsplash)
The game itself is a 5.5x6.5-inch saddle-stitch booklet, designed to resemble a video game cartridge. Inside, a step-by-step guide supports the player's exploration of an imaginary coastline filled with the perplexing "ruins of the future." Aside from the cover, the interior maps and illustrations are made of 1-bit black & white video game sprites, hand-drawn and arranged by the author. The booklet will be at least 32 pages long, possibly more.
Example Image 1 (draft)
Why 1-bit sprites? First, they're really fun and visually arresting, despite being even simpler than the Gameboy's four-shades-of-green graphics. It's a fascinating challenge to work within their constraints. Second, their two-color nature makes them arguably the best pixel graphics format for zine printing.
Example Image 2 (draft)
The rules are simple and gamebook-like, but require more meaningful input from the player -- answering open-ended questions, deciding where to go and what to do, and determining how things feel. My design approach is weird and experimental, but I'm also building on a well-developed game design tradition that includes recent indie TRPG hits such as Avery Alder's The Quiet Year, Laura Simpson's Companions' Tale, Meguey Baker & D. Vincent Baker's Firebrands, Hannah Shaffer's 14 Days, Ross Cowman's The Fall of Magic, and Alex Roberts' For the Queen, among others.
Example Page with Game Instructions (draft)
The poster map (see the higher pledge level) is not at all required to play the game, but is an homage to the fold-out map that came packaged with the original Legend of Zelda cartridge. It will not actually be folded, but instead shipped flat or rolled, depending on what seems safest.
Initial sketch of poster map (minor spoilers!)
I have some ideas for extra touches that could improve the project. Now that we're into Week 2 of the campaign, I'm ready to announce more details about those.
If we sell out of all 200 print copies, then I will add a "DO NOT OPEN UNTIL INSTRUCTED" card or envelope to all of the print copies. This will contain hidden information & content that you can uncover later on in the game, opening up new possibilities. For digital backers, this will be included as a separate "DO NOT OPEN" PDF file.
For every 50 digital-only backers we get, I will add +1 track to the CHIPTUNES SOUNDTRACK for the game, which you can listen to while playing or just by itself. I'm already working on the title track, so all backers get that one for free (including crunchy noise-channel waves).
Once all print copies are shipped, I will RELEASE THE GAME'S SPRITE SET under an open-source license so that other game designers -- both analog and digital -- can use and adapt it. The project's already been very successful, so this is just a general "thank you" to everyone for helping make it happen, and passing along something that might be useful to others.
This is a solo creative project by just me, though I will hire someone to edit and proofread the text, as well as recruiting a handful of folks to playtest the final draft. I also plan to make the PDF version available early to backers, since that seems to be a useful way to crowdsource last-minute typo-spotting before it goes to print.
As for myself, I've been involved in indie TRPG circles since ~2002, but most of my games have been released informally or with relatively little fanfare, occasionally becoming cult classics or -- more often -- obscure curiosities. I'm probably best known for the early GMless survival horror and map-drawing game Geiger Counter, the urban planar freebooting Planarch Codex supplements for Dungeon World, the apocalyptic subway board game Metrofinal, the IndieCade-featured zombie card game Restless, the freeform larps Tomb-Priestesses, The Lofty Beacons, and Tacklebox, the demon-whaling Leviathan Song supplement for Blades in the Dark, and for shepherding the venerable game jam Game Chef from 2009-2012.
I'm currently a parent, instructor, grad student, and critical scholar (of interactive media and science & technology studies), roughly in that order. I am also an incorrigible designer of weird indie games. My favorite digital platform is the Nintendo Gameboy. I like long walks on haunted beaches.
Zine Quest 3 logo
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
While this is my first solo Kickstarter, I've been an active part of the indie TRPG publishing circles for nearly 20 years and have backed over 200 Kickstarter projects (mostly indie games). For better or worse, I've witnessed or directly experienced many of the problems that can potentially arise.

Printing, shipping, and unexpected costs & delays are often the biggest hurdles.

For printing, I plan to work with Smartpress -- who I've worked extensively with before -- or Mixam, both of which are online printing services with fairly solid customer service. If problems come up in the printing process, I'm confident that I can deal with them. If this project is incredibly successful, I might switch to printing with Scoutbooks, a specialty printing co-op in Oregon, but their minimum orders are much higher (250+ print copies). I am a giant nerd about layout and printing, so I'll be carefully watching to make sure things turn out okay.

While shipping is a nightmare for most print projects, the zine format makes things significantly easier because I can mail them in a sturdy envelope using standard USPS postage. Additionally, I've planned for a relatively modest number of shipments, limiting the printed zines to 100 and the posters to just 10. If these sell out quickly, I might expand the numbers, but not by too much. I want to get a couple small Kickstarter projects under my belt before I try something ambitious.

Unexpected costs & delays are seemingly inevitable. That said, this is a very modest project in the grand scheme of things, without much risk of major trouble. I can absorb additional costs if I have to, since there is flexibility built into the budget, and most backers are very gracious about delays as long as communication is clear.

updates.update_content:
The funding campaign wrapped with 333 backers and a little over $3,500, which is phenomenal for an intentionally small-ish project like this one. Now it's time for me to get back to work, chipping away at the tasks ahead so I can send copies of the game to you soon.
Bonus: Four-track Chiptunes EP

Wow, we're almost to the end! This whole experience has gone so fast, though in some ways it's only getting started, in terms of the work I have lined up for me.

More Blips & Bleeps!
We're at 76 PDF backers now, which means at least 2 -- and maybe 3 or more! -- tracks in . I'm honestly thrilled that I get to show off my musical side, since it's something I've done for a long time but don't get to indulge very much.

You did it! The last few print copies were snatched up last night -- roughly 200 total, give or take a few extras from overprinting. Once I finish shipping things out, I hope to be able to make any extra copies available to backers first, in case you want to give one as a gift. But, for now, print copies are sold out.

The Secret of the Secret Info

First, let me say thank you to all the supporters who've backed The Barrier & the Sound since the previous update. Welcome to the project! We're so happy to have you aboard, and I can't wait to show you more of what I've been working on.
When I started writing this update, we'd just surpassed 175 backers and $2,300, so things keep moving along at a moderate clip, consistent with the U-shaped pattern that many Kickstarter campaigns follow.

Wow.
My sincere thanks to everyone who's supported The Barrier & the Sound so far. Even though I've been making games for 20+ years now, this is my first solo Kickstarter project, and I wasn't sure how it was going to go. I'm not one of the big names in indie games, and many of the platforms I would have once promoted this project on don't exist anymore (alas Google Plus). Despite that, we're off to a flying start, and I'm really happy that something I've been tinkering with has caught your interest too!
