campaign.story:
Okay folks, there was a time in my life when I was all about zines.  I still love the things but hate figuring out how to store 'em.  From where I write this I can see a giant tub of zines dating back to the 80s and 90s, and shelves awkwardly stuffed with game and art zines.   Silkscreened and risograph zines just put me over the moon.  
Zine making, though, sort of fell away.  I made a zine as part of an artwork at Socrates Sculpture Park in NYC.  But it's not something I do anymore.  Why not?  WHY?  
Okay, I will.  I will make a zine.  I want to do this.  I am excited. 


(three hours pass) 


I Made a Zine
And I am zining the fuck out of this zine.  
Back in my day, I hoarsely declaim while waving my cane, zines were quick and dirty and often embarrassingly personal.  Inside that majestic blue tub there is a possibly -infinite- number of diary zines detailing the random thoughts of punk rock teenagers in small towns in the midwest.  And that, THAT, that is what I am decanting into this thing I am making you.
It's a zine that I never made back when I was in high school, a fantastic imagining of what I might've done.  And it's a game.   A game for three players.  
Nay, not just a game, a simulator.  A teenaged Tim Hutchings almost-virtual-reality experience in which you and your two brave companions  (I am actually choking with laughter as I write this) get to be me for an evening.  And I tell you how to play D&D, among other things.  In fact, the name for this zine was originally Tim Hutchings Tell You How to Play AD&D because it's true and it's an homage to Rodney Anonymous Tells You How to Live, a music program hosted by the lead singer of the Dead Milkmen--my favorite band at the time described in this zine.  
There's a Gimmick?
This zine is being printed in three colors--red, blue, and yellow and the colors that blur in between.  It will come with three pieces of plastic gel--red, blue, and green.  When you hold a plastic piece to your eye you will experience ZINE MAGIC as the colors are, more or less, separated out and hidden drawings emerge!  Complementary colors turn black and the others (mostly) disappear.  Magic.
So the top image here is the opening page spread in the zine.  The three images below it are the same spread viewed through different colors of plastic.  I took these photos of the screen through a piece of plastic.  These are early test photos and I've improved the system since then.
I'll say this again in a different way:  There'll be a mess of blue, red, and yellow lines, look at the pages through various colors of plastic and some lines will disappear while others emerge.  PLAYERS SEE DIFFERENT INFORMATION ON THE SAME PAGE THROUGH THE COMBINATION OF MAGIC AND SCIENCE THAT IS COLOR THEORY.  LIKE THIS.
FYI this was stupidly hard to figure out, even with the groundwork laid down by Carnovsky and other sources.  I 
Disclaimer:  This is going to work, more or less.  The blues are pretty dark and you'll need a bright place to play.   But it should work.  But maybe it will fail?  Probably not.  

This is one of the three colored layers that make up one page spread.
Are There Two Gimmicks?
Sort of.  Maybe the second isn't a gimmick so much as a stance.  This is a zine in concept and making.
This isn't really a gimmick as much as my commitment to the format:  I don't know if this zine is any good.  I am making it in character and that character is me.  I'm channeling young Tim and, to be frank, young Tim was an idiot.  He makes dull old Tim look like a genius.  
Zines are messy, they are poorly thought out, mistakes are fixed with white out and anger and the anger gets worse because the white out wasn't given enough time to dry and fuck I've ruined my pen.  Zines are shat out quickly and you don't look at it because it's gross, you just stuff it all into envelopes and mail it to other people like yourself and get things sent to you in return.
This zine is messy, its poorly thought out.  I had no white out so I only had anger to fix mistakes with and that doesn't work at all.  
I sat down and wrote this zine in two or three hours, starting at 11pm.  I was bleary and confused by the end.  I worked like a teenager whose about to lose his access to free copies when his buddy goes off shift in half an hour.  
In short, it's a zine being a zine.
Are You Being Some Sort of Elitist Grump About What Zines Are?
No!  Well, yes, but NO.   I'm telling you what zines mean to -me- and what games mean to -me-, and how my experience within the medium affects what I am making for you right now. 
But for me a zine is something different.  The word 'zine' fires my blood in a way that ain't like most other folks making things here.   I don't want anyone to be disappointed because the thing I'm delivering has fundamentally different goals than  most of the ZineQuest 3 projects.
Okay, Okay, Give Some Specifics.
Okay, I guess I can do that.  
You're getting THREE digest-sized, sixteen page zines (they are all the same zine).  It'll be full color, probably printed by McNaughton Gunn--those are the same folks that printed Thousand Year Old Vampire.
You'll get three small squares of plastic with the zine which will allow the eyeball magic to emerge.  Probably they'll come in a little envelope that'll be tucked into the zine.  
This is a sort of game for three players.
I am timing this so that the zine will come out of the printer at the same time as the secret TYOV companion book.
UPDATE:  In the interest of gaming on the cusp of post-covid I am providing THREE copies of the zine to Kickstarter backers.  That way you don't have to hunker around one book and breath up each other's air.  You're still only getting one pack of plastic viewing bits though.
Secret TYOV companion book?  
Yes, it's an add-on you can get when you Kickstart this project.  You'll also be able to pre-order it through the regular thousandyearoldvampire.com site.  Let's maybe talk about that in the faq or something.  
So There Are Add-ons and Stuff?
Yeah, that's new to me to.  Kickstarter has it set up now so that you pledge for a reward tier and then there are add-ons that should appear beneath the pledge.  You can add on copies of Thousand Year Old Vampire, the companion book, some pins (including a new one!) , and another zine game I'd made.  
Again, while one person is seeing this image the other two players are seeing coexisting images that are completely different.
All Right Then, So Tell Us About The Game.
Can't you just trust me?  No?  Well, that's sensible I guess.  
The game is pretty light.  Three players peer through their plastic pieces and see information that is unique to their colored piece of plastic, more or less.  The players tell the story of a slightly idealized, barely remembered amalgam of summer evenings of youthful freedom when I could drive but still have no responsibilities.  And I go play AD&D with friends.  
You negotiate the story together, each player operating from a different body of information.  You might find a use for dice for part of the game, but they aren't required. The authorial voice in the zine flickers between the viewpoint of Young Tim, the memories of Old Tim, and a sort of dispassionate aping of zine makers I've absorbed into my being.  
Is That Really A Game?
Oh don't be that fucker.  I mean, it doesn't really have rules or goals or even a real structure but neither do zines.   There's just an amorphous knowledge of how it works, an arc of excitement and disappointment.  
Couldn't This Just Be Three Separate Booklets?
Oh jeez, you're right.  I, uh, guess that it wouldn't be as clever?  
Actually no, I'm going to double-down on the color thing.  It's important to the structure of the experience that you are given a messiness of information blended together on a single page and each player looks at that mess through a different lens and pulls out strings of meaning.  It's like a memory, which this game is about.  And it's like being a person who is a child and an adult and smart and an idiot all at once, flickering constantly between states as you move between different social spaces and nodes of responsibility.
But I guess that'll be the PDF format.  Three separate PDFs, one for each player to allow online or print-and-play.
Were You Serious About This Being Made Quickly Or Is That A Fake Authenticity Thing?
The authenticity and roughness of the work process on this is me being true to my own understanding of what zines do in the world.  It's also me working off some of the hyperpolished perfection of that vampire game.  
It's an homage to John Porcellino, Funkapotamus, punk zines, and all the little diary zines with drawings of suburban landscapes that I do so love.
Anything Else We Should Know?
I'm excited about this!
And don't poke yourself in the eye with the corner of a piece of plastic.   Seriously.  Do this at your own risk.   Wear safety glasses or something.   I'm going to put that on the book, no shit.
You Should Probably Say Who You Are.
Oh, yeah.  My name is Tim Hutchings.  I'm a game maker and a college professor and used to be a reasonably accomplished fine arts guy.  If you are here you probably know the game Thousand Year Old Vampire--I made that.  It won four big awards and I'm very proud of it.

I think I have this one under control. I'm working with a trusted printer, a very competent fulfillment shop, and have enough back up money to patch over any awkwardness. 

The bits of plastic are the only outlier here. I'm working with a lighting company here in town to get the gels matched exactly (they have a special gel scanner, of all things). The gels are expensive but not that pricey once they are cut down to small pieces. 

I'm feeling pretty good about this, folks.

If I was looking for failure points I'd be afraid that something might be screwy with the gels (I'm working with recommended pros), that there is some color error with the printer (they are super competent), or that there is some idiotic layout error (the printer is good at catching this stuff, but there are bound to be some tiny issues that are my fault). 

I think it'll work, though.

campaign.story:
Hello! My name is Andrew, and I created Occupied Hex games. I am a passionate game designer as well as player, and STREETS is my first Kickstarter for #ZineQuest! STREETS is a tabletop role-playing game where players take on the roles of stray dogs and cats in a rules-light game that anyone can grasp quickly and have a blast playing.
If you don't even know what a tabletop role-playing game is, it's simply a story the players and game master tell together, and dice are used when risky situations pop up to add suspense and unpredictable results.
The game engine is built around simplicity-- you only need one or two regular ol' six-sided dice to play. When you run into a challenging situation and need to make a skill check, you roll 2d6, add them together, then add whatever skill modifier you might have. If even that sentence sounded overly complex, I promise you the game is easy to jump into.
There are no hit points or armor classes, but there are still consequences for risky actions that fail! If you get hurt you roll for the body location and then take an injury, which impacts your skills and can lead to even more dire consequences!
If you'd like to see the game in action, here is a full game we played! *NOTE this video contains R-rated language at times)
There are a LOT of dog breeds out there to choose from, but I wanted players to feel like they had unique, customizable stats for their dog, regardless of what breed they chose. I devised a 'class' system using the seven AKC breed groups so whatever dog breed you decide to play as, you'll have an easy source for your stats.
You can also play a mixed breed! Mixed breed dogs have even more customizable stats, plus an extra point for their hardiness.
You can even play as a cat. Cats have slightly worse stats than dogs, but a lot more luck, which enables you to re-roll failed skill checks! 
But your character doesn't just have their stats at their disposal, they also have two unique talents, which give them special abilities, such as Houdini: You can open doors with your paw or teeth. These talents give each character even more depth but are immediately easy to understand. 
•A player section for creating dog or cat characters, as well as the game basics.
•A simple, easy-to-read character sheet.
•A game master section for running games, along with tips in case it's your first time.
•A scenario generator so you can just roll dice and come up with the ingredients for running the adventure.
•An alternate 'hard mode' aimed at adult players, that trades some of the lighthearted tone for real stakes.
•Specific one shot adventure snapshots to use or inspire you.
•PLUS a one shot adventure written by ace game master Jared Logan from Stream of Blood.
•PLUS a campaign adventure for an epic story that spans multiple game sessions.
•PLUS the expansion module IT FELL FROM THE NIGHT, which gives your dog or cat superpowers!
•PLUS a map by Josh Smith!
STREETS is designed to make the fun, communal storytelling of an RPG easy for everyone. Players do get the satisfaction of their dog or cat's unique stats and talents, but the gameplay is very smooth once you set sail. 
I originally created this game after being stymied trying to play D&D remotely with my daughter's middle school RPG Club.  Not only did the kids love it, they can run the game! 
Whether you're a battle-hardened RPG veteran or you're so new that most of what I've said here is nonsense to you, STREETS is for you!

updates.update_userinfo: Hardcopies shipped and PDF now available!
updates.update_content:
I shipped the hardcopy zines yesterday! Two backers have yet to update their surveys with a mailing address so if you are reading this D. Davis or H. Howard please let me know where to send your games! As anyone who has used the usps recently knows, the mail is slooooooooow. I mailed a letter to someone in California and it took two weeks! So please be patient as the zines crawl their way across the country to you. I will post an update when people begin to receive them so we can have some reference. 
But you don't have to wait for the zine to start playing, the PDF is ready and live! Simply visit our spiff new site and the password is . You will be able to download both the full page PDF and the landscape PDF versions. There is no limit on the downloads for you. I'll leave that page up for a month, and after that if you need a copy just contact me and I'll send it direct.

Well, a few things DID go wrong in the printing process, but I learned a lot.  For example, did you know your layout needs to be LARGER than the intended book so they can trim it down? I had no idea. 
Anyway, good news I signed off on the proof, and they're being printed up (or already have been) and will go into the mail in the next day or two. If you are expecting a physical copy and have moved since filling out your survey, please update the address! 
PDFs will be available when the physical copies are mailed. There will be two versions, one in full page layout and one condensed in landscape to save your home printer some ink, if you want to print it out. I'll post an update with a link to download both versions. If for some reason you do NOT want to download the PDFs from my site, let me know and I can email you directly.

Good news! Got the final layout and the book has exploded from the initial 26 pages I estimated to 52 pages! Double! Barring any issues with printing, the turnaround should be quick and then they go sailing off in the mail. Once the zines have mailed the PDFs will be available for download. 
Thanks again, everyone!

campaign.story:
Horrors of the Sepulchre is an old-school RPG zine adventure created in the tradition of the classic module Tomb of Horrors, but it's made for the B/X "sweet spot" of player character levels 4-7. 

So what does Horrors of the Sepulchre have within its evil pages?
One-page Introduction? Check.
Wicked traps to avoid? Check.
A fearsome bad guy? Check. 
Monsters to hack or outsmart? Check
Awesome treasures? Hell yeah!
A chance for glory or infamy? Most definitely!
But you mentioned THAT module above. Is there even any hope of survival? 
Of course there is! Be smart about it. This is OLD-SCHOOL, you gotta step up your game! Horrors of the Sepulchre gives you the glorious opportunity to take on a horror themed deathtrap dungeon with menacing monsters and substantial reward. 
Are you daring enough? Or are you gonna slink back to Ye Olde Tavern in town like some pansy-ass bard and sing grand tales of what OTHER adventurers do?
Horrors of the Sepulchre cover art by Del Teigeler
What are people saying about Horrors of the Sepulchre?
Horrors of the Sepulchre is brought to you by Hog Town Games.  It is an Old School Essentials (OSE) system compatible adventure, and so is also easily playable with most other OSR style game systems. The zine is written and produced by Steve C of Dice Roll Zine; the maps, layout and original dungeon concept are by the legendary Matt Jackson; and the illustrations are by none other than Del Teigeler, one of the best and most prolific old school-inspired artists around. 
Bat Door Chamber illustration by Del Teigeler
Horrors of the Sepulchre map preview by Matt Jackson
More testimony for Horrors of the Sepulchre
Here is a very rough layout sample I have done. Matt's actual finished layout will look so much cooler, but this gives you an idea how the text will likely be done. You can click here to download this if you like.
WIP Layout Sample
Horrors of the Sepulchre currently stands at 28 pages, zine-sized (8.5" x 5.5"), with a black & white interior and full color cover. The zine will be professionally printed and staple-bound on premium paper, with a removable two-sided printed card-stock cover and separate 4-page illustrated mini booklet.

STRETCH GOAL
If we hit $2,500 (CAD) in funding, the illustrated mini-booklet will be 8 pages instead of 4. Which means ... EVEN MORE awesome Del Teigeler artwork!

Video Music Credit: Tune clip of "Recoil" by my old death metal band Xecution.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I ran a successful Zine Quest Kickstarter last year (Dice Roll Zine #3), so I have that valuable experience under my belt. Plus, I know how costs and timelines can be challenging when dealing with writing, editing, art, layout, printing and shipping. The funding goal for Horrors of the Sepulchre is not cheap, so that is probably my biggest worry. However this zine will be well worth it - there is a lot of amazing art, the dungeon is really cool, the writing and layout will be well-crafted and easy to use, and it will be printed and produced with fine quality materials.

campaign.story:
You've always felt...you've always known that you were different. Not entirely of this realm. Now, you can confirm it, and strengthen your ties to this other realm. 
This collection of instructions, suggestions, poems and writings will immerse you and allow you magick to reconnect with your true form.
In the forest, in the country, in the city, you can always connect. Find the beauty, be the beauty. You are the magick.
You're half awake, half in a dream: one form, in two places. You are from some other where, some other how.
There is enough violence in the world; we have been filled with sadness and despair and terror. We wanted to bring something different to Zine Quest 3, something magickal, something personal, something reflective.
This experience is a challenge to you, and perhaps your friends. Go out into the world and be magick, live magick, spread magick. We believe in you. We believe the world needs more magick. You can be that magick. Lyrical, journal, live-action, solo, group.
How do you, how can you, exist removed from your ethereal home?
REWARDS
A .PDF copy of the game.
A pocket-sized black and white zine.
A pocket sized journal, for your game thoughts, plans, and doodles.
A microbook of poetry.
Dance Till Dawn, with a custom scenario and playlist.

$400 - Swag! We love getting some small item of swag for our games, stickers, pins, etc. Swag is included with every print version.
(other unlockables will be announced, as relevant)

updates.update_content:
Zine Quest 3 has really taken off!
Your support means so much.
This project has been very important to both of us during this past year, and is giving us hope and strength and joy in these difficult times.
We are excited to get it in your hands, and working hard to make that happen.

The bump at the end of a Kickstarter is real! We are almost to the end and you’ve made swag possible, and we love swag so that is awesome.
If you got any snow, go build a snowman somewhere public.
Or, write a poem.
Close your eyes and think back to where you came from, what makes it special? Bring that magic into this reality.

Coming up on one year of isolation, many of us have had to pivot how we game and approach gaming. Games moved from "must-play" to "must-read." Many tabletop gamers have found virtual alternatives, but those who thrive on LARPs are likely having a more difficult time. We would love for all of you to check out this Kickstarter by Make A Scene! Scenario Festival, a LARP organization in Minnesota that was unable to host their annual event in 2020. In its place, they have compiled the original scenario LARPs created for both the 2019 and 2020 events into a beautiful anthology. If you're thirsting for original LARP scenarios, please consider supporting a scene that is vital to so many:

Hello all,
Thank you for the support. Our goal was intentionally modest as this is shaping up to be a very personal project.
If you celebrate such things, go out into the world today and enjoy Valentine’s Day. If you don’t, you should still go out and create some magic. Grab some chalk and make art, write a poem, take a photograph, try a new recipe to share with those in your pod, make a snowman, sing a song.

campaign.story:
If you don't mind unpleasantness, I have a quest.
Firstly, thank you for checking out this project! I’m DW Dagon and I’m a table-top role-playing game creator. Over the last two years, I’ve produced art and written for several TTRPG projects that have since gotten Electrum, Gold, and Platinum bestseller awards from DM’s Guild; and one Ennie award for a collaboration product. So! Let me tell ya a little bit about this project!
  What the hell is ‘YOU REPUGNANT HUNTERS’
‘YOU REPUGNANT HUNTERS’ is a system-agnostic zine that has rules and some sticky flavor for running a dark/metal fantasy campaign where players acquire hunting seals which allow them to hunt monstrosities too putrid for the average hero.
Hunters undergo a ritual to a Hunting Insignia which will determine their style of hunting and type of prey their Insignia. Hunting down and ceremonially eviscerating prey will lead to appeasing a Hunting Insignia, and gaining occult powers.

Compatability
'YOU REPUGNANT HUNTERS' rules only need d6 dice and lust for filthy, gory bounty hunting. This rule system is designed for MÖRK BORG however can be run in pretty much anything.
 Running a MÖRK BORG campaign? No worries! Just throw it in there! It even has Omens!
 5th Edition D&D? Pick some horrible creatures to hunt and get it started!
 Mothership? Add ‘space’ in front of random nouns and you’ll get stuff like “Space-Templar of Torment”. Players will be none-the-wiser!
 Quest RPG? I mean, you could, but I seriously question your theme choice...
  Why Hunt?
‘YOU REPUGNANT HUNTERS’ began when I had watched about 15 hours of Bloodborne lore on YouTube and then read through the MÖRK BORG rulebook. The world of TTRPGs like MÖRK BORG, Shadow of the Demon Lord, and Trophy are harsh and doomed places, and though I love that kind of universe, something in me wanted to create a supplement that gives some element of control and side-questy purpose to campaigns of such damned existences.
Hunter's Seal
The ‘Zine
‘YOU REPUGNANT HUNTERS’ is currently a 16-page zine featuring rules, flavor/lore, hunt rewards, and player handouts for five hunter types. Once the project is fully backed, stretch goals for extra random tables of items, variant prey features, and other goodies will be added to the project; thus extending the page count but not the cost to back it!
Content has already begun being created and come completion of the Kickstarter, the project is on track to be complete and ready to send off for printing.

Limited Basic Hunting Seal
I'm one of those GMs and players who is a sucker for props at the table. That's why I thought "wouldn't it be fantastic to have one of the seals to pass to players who are rolling a meditation roll (when a character meditates on a seal to gain visions of their next prey)?". So I went ahead and created a prototype of a hunting seal prop for a limited amount of pledges (and let's face it, for me to use at the table). The prop is calico canvas, ink, and the wax seal is 3d printed PLA painted red. I thought to make an actual seal but for longevity and repeat use, I didn't want people having cracked and broken wax all over the shop. Prototype of the hand distressed hunting seal is below!
Prototype of hand distressed, Limited Edition Basic Hunting Seal prop

Stretch Goals [Update: NEW SOCIAL STRETCH GOAL!]
The following stretch goals will add to the zine if achieved. The zine and pledge costs won't increase at all. It'll just be added value and content. :)
UNLOCKED! $450 - TROUBLE BREWING: +1 hunter type; the alchemist
UNLOCKED! $500 - DESPICABLE YOU: despicable variant prey features
UNLOCKED! $550 - REPUGNANT TRAITS for REPUGNANT HUNTERS: repugnant trait chart
UNLOCKED! $600 - LOCK'N LOAD: hunter load-outs
UNLOCKED! $650 - RUTHLESS REWARDS: ruthless insignia faction rewards
UNLOCKED! $666 - BLOOD-CLOTTED'N CURSED: everything printed in a blood-clot ink
UNLOCKED! $1266 - PUS PAPER COLOUR: Softly yellowing, creamy, paper colour to compliment the deep blood-clot red writing and art.

SOCIAL STRETCH GOAL #1
LOOT! The current ruthless rewards are a Roll 1d6 table of rare items that can be bestowed. This social stretch goal will increase the number to 20 foul-yet-desirable items and a rule where the higher the Advanced Seal Rank, the higher the roll and rarity. 
To achieve this social stretch goal target will be 66 posts on Twitter about what you would love about hunting horrid and unholy entities with the below link and the hashtag of: #YouRepugnantHunters
Link: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/dw-dagon/you-repugnant-hunters?ref=project_tweet
Keep in mind that no one likes spam so only tweet something interesting; even your own thoughts on what your hunter vibe would be. I won't be counting spam tweets coz, y'know. That's just not sporting. Not very hunter-like..

DELIVERY
The content has already begun being designed and I'm estimating that it will take a month for art, editing, and layout (as I'm doing most of this by myself and art takes longer than I always think).
Postage is not included in the pledge cost and will be added on when checking out in the pledge manager once the campaign finishes.
Once the product has completed its printing phase (two weeks maximum for a small run of meeting the Funding Goal), it will be mailed out by standard post. Due to COVID, internationally posted products are expected to take roughly a month to be delivered. To keep track of estimated delivery times, one posted product from each country will have tracking so I can update backers on when to expect their countries' deliveries to begin arriving.
  Budget
For such a small run of zines the production costs, tax, and Kickstarter project fees will be eating up most of the budget at the current Funding Goal. The Funding Goal works out that I can print a run of this zine and won't be at a loss for estimated damaged stock and (gods forbid) missing deliveries. If the project exceeds the funding goal, extra funding goes to the artist (me, operating at nothing per hour at this stage) and a bonus for the contributors which is an extra 66.6% (🤘) on top of their hiring costs (editors and layout folks deserve their weight in gold). All contributors are paid hiring costs up front and the bonus after the campaign has been funded.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Working a full-time job and doing TTRPG creation on the side means that my main risk is taking longer to do art and layout due to emergencies or general life stuff. If there is anything that causes the production part of the project to go longer than usual, backers will be briefed as such. Worst case scenario, I'm prepared to pay some of my fellow TTRPG artists to create art for me to free up time on writing and layout.

campaign.story:
Soft Chaos member, Allison Cole is known for creating quirky game-things with queer themes. This Zine is no exception. She reached out to the corners of the internet (okay, her trashy lesbian girlfriend, her DMs and one really really gay message board) and rallied a ragtag bunch of creative mavericks to pull off what can only be described as the bestworsttrashy lesbian romance novel: the game.
Remember those kids in the class that complicated your group projects? You know the ones. Instead of just making the thing in the assignment they wanted to make:
the world the assignment would live in
the characters in the world that would make the assignment
the marketing campaign for the assignment
the assignment itself
  We were those kids. We are those adults.

Make up an author. Make up the author's trashy lesbian romance novel. Make up the characters in the trashy romance novel. Act it out.

This Could Be You


Ever wished you were a character in the novel you were reading? Yeah. This is for you.
 As a lover of all things queer, you, dear reader, have a calling in literature. Like so many writers before, your great novel—the one that aches in your soul—isn't ready. And you have bills to pay. For fear your toast will never meet an avocado again, you turn to mass market, specifically romance novels. (Write what you know, they say.)
 Create a trashy lesbian romance novel! BUT WAIT, you won't just make a trashy lesbian romance novel. You'll also make the author that writes it. Still with me? Excellent! 'Cause, there's more.
Once made, you'll play the part of one of the romantic leads! This is the Russian-dolls of role-playing games. Or, like going a few levels deep in Inception without the headphones and the falling—Scratch that. There will be falling. Falling in love!

 (What You're Getting)
You will get:
32-page zine
Storytelling game
No Game Master Required
No prep time (Read the rules and have at it!)
Playable in an evening (2 - 4 hours, though it may take longer if you make the novel cover a true work of art)
No role-playing experience is required.
If you've read a romance novel, you can play this game.

Includes:
Ruleset
Character Sheets
Glossary of Terms
Create Your Own Leading Lesbian (Sketches are in Progress)
Character Creation

We will get in touch to personally help you prepare a date night centered around a session of Denial & Yearning. We’ll be your personal love advisers to help create a perfect night (we’re very romantic). One of us will be virtually present on your special night to facilitate a game for you and your guest.

*Lesbianism not required. Date night is prepared by trashy lesbians.

State of [the Game]:
Can't wait to have your trashy lesbian romance? We've been toiling away, so you won't!
One of the great things about backing Denial & Yearning is that the game is mostly done! It is designed and playtested. The rules are sitting nicely in an InDesign layout. All that awaits is the last editing pass and some finalized art assets.
Meaning if our project gets funded, we'll be able to send you your digital copy right away when the campaign ends!

The sentiment behind Denial & Yearning is lighthearted fun and we are very excited to share it with the world! But whenever we have the opportunity and platform to share our values in a public way we take things a little more seriously.  We'd like to take this time to draw attention to some values that are very important to us (that informed game design & writing).

Safety and Consent
Denial & Yearning is a game about romance, physical intimacy, and perhaps even sex. These are powerful and potentially difficult topics, and your safety, and the safety of your partner, are always more important than the game. With that in mind, Yearning and Desire includes a discussion of consent before play begins.
Many romance novels are joyously dirty and erotic, but others fade to black when things get sexual, or portray romantic relationships that aren’t sexual (Pride and Prejudice is tragically straight, but it’s still pretty good). Your in-game novel can fall anywhere on that spectrum. Make sure that you only portray things in your game that both players are excited to explore. And of course, anyone is allowed to change their minds at any time during play.

Gender and Pronouns
This is a also game about lesbian romance. The lesbian community is diverse, and it includes people who experience gender very differently. There are butches and femmes who find those identities profoundly healing, and other lesbians who find those terms alien. There are people who have lived as straight men until they come out as trans women, and people who have lived as lesbians and then come out as trans men. There are non-binary people with all sorts of experiences.
We celebrate the diversity of lesbians, and we are not here to tell you who is not a lesbian. We often use she/her pronouns to refer to our characters and players, but this is a game for anyone who wants the trashy lesbian romance novel experience and your characters might not use she/her.
[Will continue to be updated throughout project]
As the campaign progresses we'll be updating with fun behind the scene moments, and the design process. It will include pictures of our discord goofing, pictures of our test prints, early art assets, as well as true process gems like this mockup Allison made for Micah:
And behind-the-scenes discord moments, like when Dee found her true calling:

Concept Art by Micah. Swoon with us, won't you?

campaign.story:
Tooth & Claw is an in-depth fantasy field guide that takes real world zoological concepts and - with a dash of pseudo-science - uses them to re-imagine fantasy creatures. From dragons melting gold to armour themselves to lemur inspired wyven social dynamics.
Each creature entry will have in-universe field notes on aspects such as behaviour, physiology, and ecology. Entries will also have notes on things like their habitats, diets, and useful tips for adventurers like how to tell the age of a dragon by the purity of its scale armour.
The level of realism in creature design is inspired by the Monster Hunter games which do an excellent job at creating fantasy creatures that feel believable.
For every £100 - Unlocked -   over the stretch goal, I'll add another 2 pages which will either expand on an existing creature or make space for a new one. We've managed to reach the maximum of 56 pages!
At £600 - Unlocked - an entomology mini-zine with various strange insects for your campaigns will be included inside each zine and as a printer friendly PDF
At £1500 - Unlocked - I'll create another mini zine  similar to the entomology one focusing on Dungeon Creatures! It's going  to be a fun challenge to justify how a mimic could evolve!
At £2000 - Unlocked - I'll collaborate with Anna Blackwell to create quest hooks for use in stories and RPGs featuring the  creatures in Tooth & Claw. These will be available as a PDF to all  backers.
At £3000 - Unlocked - I'll be able to make these as more than just a hobby and will release a second zine with at least 24 pages which goes in depth on specifically aquatic creatures taking inspiration from games like Subnautica (And to be honest, the underwater world is weird enough in real life!). This will be sent out along with the main zine.
Digital
Backing at this tier gets you a PDF copy of Tooth & Claw and all stretch goal rewards.
Physical
Backing at this tier gets you a Print copy of Tooth & Claw as well as a PDF and all stretch goal rewards.
Discovery
Want to work together with a zoologist to create your own custom creature. Want in-depth detail on one of the classics? Or have a creature of your own creation? If you back at this tier, you will get a Print and PDF copy of Tooth & Claw, any stretch goals we unlock AND I will create a field journal excerpt for a creature of your choice or design that will be printed out and sent along with your rewards.
Delivery fees will be collected after the campaign through a pledge manager (most likely Backerkit) and will have @BlackwellWriter to help me pack and post everything and make sure it's all going according to plan.

campaign.story:
The Vitacernis is a third-party zine for the Mausritter RPG containing a settlement and adventure ready to slot in to any hexcrawl or be run on it's own. It centers around Ruby Grove, a mouse settlement built into the treetops of a peaceful grove surrounding a large, perennially red-leafed maple: The Vitacernis. Inhabitants of Ruby Grove revere the great tree, and believe that the sacred red sap it produces has divine curative powers.

Inside The Vitacernis, players will explore the hollow tree, find the ruins of an ancient settlement tangled in its roots, meet a rat necromancer and the results of his experiments, and learn the secrets of the mysterious maple and it's life-giving sap.
Cover art not final, but close!
The Vitacernis is a 20-page zine containing:
 Ruby Grove - A mouse settlement with 16 locations and 20+ NPCs to meet
 4 major NPCs with backgrounds, behaviors, and open-ended plot hooks
An adventure that sees the PCs delving inside the tree, uncovering ancient ruins, meeting its new inhabitants, and discovering the strange tree’s origins
A 14 entry bestiary, 2 new spells and conditions, and a 40+ entry treasure table
A separate cut-out item sheet containing the new conditions, spells, and a selection of 11 detailed items
A set of tools for GMs to integrate Ruby Grove and The Vitacernis into an existing campaign including: a table of both local and hexcrawl-level rumors, a table of location/NPC features to easily plug in alternates from an existing campaign, and aftermath prompts to guide what happens in the world following the adventure
The Four Major NPCs in Ruby Grove
Mausritter is a rules-light fantasy adventure RPG where players take up the sword and don the whiskers of a brave mouse adventurer.

It’s a huge and dangerous world out there, and it does not look kindly on a small mouse. But if you are very brave and very clever and just a bit lucky, you might be able to survive. And if you survive long enough, you might even become a hero amongst mice.
 Brian Stauffer (Writing/Sketch Art): That's me! I am an RPG enthusiast and amateur writer.  I got started in RPG writing by contributing the Mothership adventure The Incident at Muto Station to Dissident Whispers. Outside of writing, I also developed "Shifting Sands", a generator for Dave Cox's ZineQuest 1 project: A Rasp of Sand. The Vitacernis is my first independent project, and I'm super excited to share it with everyone!
Evlyn Moreau ("Inside the Vitacernis" map illustration): Evlyn is an illustrator from Montreal, she loves to draw strange creatures and to craft zines. Her work mixes illustrations and gaming materials in a whimsical way.  She is the author of the blog "Le Chaudron Chromatic" and she recently contributed to Dissident Whispers, Hivemind, and Retropunk.

Monsters! Items! Spells!
The Vitacernis's manuscript is written, art is nearly complete, and the zine is already ~80% through layout.  A conservative timeline for the remaining work:
 February 2021 - Kickstarter campaign
 March 2021 -  Map art complete, other sketches finalized, layout/editing complete

 June 2021 - Physical fulfillment begins 
Digital distribution will be done through itch.io.
The print version will be a Mixam 20-page A5 zine.  Physical fulfillment will be handled by:
Games Omnivorous (who published the beautiful new edition of Mausritter) for European backers.
Exalted Funeral for US, CAN, and rest of world.
Shipping partners!
There's always uncertainty with shipping, now more than ever, but the schedule is purposefully conservative to absorb potential delays.

Shipping will be collected after the campaign prior to shipment through BackerKit to ensure accurate shipping costs.  Current estimates are subject to change:
The Vitacernis is an independent production by Brian Stauffer and is not affiliated with Losing Games. It is published under the Mausritter Third Party Licence.

campaign.story:
You have no home.
You have no job.
You have no friends.
You have no family.
You have no prospects.
What you do have are a particular set of skills, the kind that make respectable folks avoid you, a handful of pennies, and a suitably blithe disregard for your own life.
Out there, beyond civilization, lies danger: monsters and magic and ancient ruins pregnant with treasure. Death is likely, but what did you have to live for anyway? At least out there is the chance to make something of yourself, and maybe even get back at those who wronged you.
Surely, this is no life for decent folk. But you’re not decent folk. You are an Errant. 
Errant is a classic fantasy role-playing game in the vein of the first few editions of that role-playing game and its many imitators and descendants such as Knave, Into the Odd, and The Black Hack. It is freely compatible with material for all those games as well as the newest edition of that role-playing game, with conversion guides provided within.
Errant is designed with the following principles in mind.
 Keep it Simple, Stupid – No math above a 2nd grade level necessary.
 Cut to the Chase – The procedures in Errant are designed to create a gameplay experience in which the smallest possible time between meaningful decisions is maintained.
 Active, not Passive – To that end, player abilities are designed around the player making active choices, not receiving passive bonuses. Even using armour to defend is a choice!
 Options, not Proscriptions – All rules and procedures in Errant are intended as guidance, to provide a toolbox for play. Rules are written to be open-ended, extendable, and use natural language wherever possible. We trust you to make good decisions.
So why drop your hard-earned dollars on yet another fantasy heartbreaker retroclone? What makes Errant unique?
Errant is rules light, procedure heavy.
What does that mean? Well, it means that the rules you need to play Errant are simple to understand and minimal. At its core, the basic mechanic is to simply roll a twenty-sided die and try to get a result that’s in between two numbers (“roll high under” or “blackjack”) to resolve tasks.
However, Errant has a number of procedures that are designed to help you navigate different play situations in fair and interesting ways. Want to know how to run an exciting chase scene, or establish a fried cockatrice restaurant, or sue a demon for emotional negligence? Errant has procedures that can help you do that!
Procedures are not rules, but neither are they vague, general guidance. They provide a framework to structure the game, and can be adjusted, ignored, hacked, mangled, broken, stolen, or seasoned to taste.
While designed to be more comprehensive than the lightweight rulesets of many newer old-school role-playing games, all the rules and procedures of Errant are streamlined for ease of use and understanding. They have been hammered into shape by five years of rigorous playtesting; every rule or procedure within the book has come into contact with a live player, and has changed as a result. 
Clickthrough for higher resolution.
Don't take my word for it. Check out a preview of the game right now at https://errantrpg.carrd.co.
Errant comes in two volumes, both 64 page 5.5" x 8.5" saddle-stitched, black & white zines. The PDFs will be hyperlinked and bookmarked.
$10 gets you both volumes in PDF form.
$20 gets you both volumes in Print & PDF. 
Fulfilment of physical orders will be handled by Exalted Funeral. U.S. shipping is $5, Canadian is $14 and international is $16. Digital files will be shared via itch.io.
Profits from the Kickstarter will go towards paying the hardworking people who made Errant a reality. We’re keeping stretch goals limited for that reason.
 UNLOCKED: $1750 – Illustrated character sheets and a printable Guide's screen done by D.L. Johnson, will be made available to all backers as digital PDFs.
 UNLOCKED $2000 – A short adventure module illustrated by Ramonkey will be made available to all backers as a digital PDF.
 UNLOCKED $2500 – A suite of digital tools will be created, including a digital SRD, a character generator, automated event dice, and more!
 UNLOCKED $3500 – An additional digital zine will be produced, intended for use as a worldbuilding toolkit for Guides. It will feature five new Covenants for The Zealot Archetype, five Settlements with fleshed out NPCs, five Threats, five Rival Companies, and more!
Ye wretches have glutted your fill, and now it is time for us to receive our due!
There will be no more stretch goals past this point; every extra bit of funding from here on out goes towards improving the product. That means more art, increasing the accessibility of our PDFs and webtools, and paying the contributors more.
Please note that the PDF adventure and worldbuilding toolkit may be delivered to backers at a later date than Vol 1 & 2 of Errant itself.
Ava Islam, writing and design – Ava Islam is a fool, a wretch, a rogue, and a rapscallion. She has done nothing of note to date. You can start fights with her on twitter.com (@yungdumbitch) or read the ravings of her brain worms at permacrandam.blogspot.com. She’s not your mom, so you don’t have to listen to anything she says.
Chris Mennell, campaign management – Chris Mennell is a dreamer and maker of things and very much a work in progress. He co-founded In Search of Games which has published the Ennie-nominated module Santa is Dead, as well as running the seminal RPG blog Beyond the Weird. He recently published a zine of the same name, and has  since partnered with Ava to launch a new endeavour, Kill Jester. All this is very impressive since Chris is, in reality, a manatee in a people suit.
Nick LS Whelan, layout – Nick LS Whelan has somehow gone unpunished for his litany of book crimes. His works include such unwholesome publications as Miscreated Creatures, Deadly Dungeons, Faux Pas, and The Bloodsoaked Boudoir of Velkis the Vile. This rampage of mangled word wrangling will never stop until someone has the courage to take away his keyboard. When not doing words badly, he can usually be found washing dishes, taking himself too seriously, or failing to understand jokes. Most of his work can be found on PapersPencils.com.
Joseph H. Vilas, editing – Joseph H. Vilas is absolutely unqualified to do anything at all. He has been known to pick nits, pet both foreign and domestic animals, and drink glasses of water for entertainment. He lives in Durham, NC, and likes the crispy feeling of line-dried cotton clothes.
Ian Hagan, cover illustration – Ian Hagan is a hermit whose day job involves collecting bits of colored paper with numbers on it as well as shiny bits of round metal. When not doing that other stuff, he uses electro-magic to make pictures that are not based on reality. You can see theses strange creations here. 
Alex Demaceno, cover illustration – Alex is a gnarled monster who makes his living by drawing creatures and maps for the errants wandering the underworld. After hoarding enough gold, he dreams to become the overlord of his own dungeon. His work can be found here.
D.L. Johnson, interior illustration - D. L. Johnson is a miscreant illustrator and game designer living in the mountains of Montana. After blackmailing Pelgrane Press into letting him draw for Ken Hite modules, he vomited forth books like Gathox Vertical Slum, Quake Alley Mayhem, and Grandpappy Cromdar's Whizbang Zoo! Portfolio work can be found at ironimagestudios.org.
Jester by D.L. Johnson
Morrie B, interior illustration – Morrie B wishes she was a beaver. Can you imagine how wonderful life would be as a beaver? You get to build your own home and paddle around in your personal lake you made to be safe from nasty things. In the winter, you don't have to hibernate. Instead, your cabin is heated and you're free to swim in the water under the ice. What an ideal life.
Bird Traveller by Morrie B
Gus L, interior illustration – Gus L is a distempered recluse living in the wilds of the Western Shore. He writes about Owlbears and is furious about the great chain of being. Rex anseris aequabis non potest peccare...
Goose King by Gus L
Lazy Litch, interior illustration – Lazy Litch is a slothful undead who spends most of his time chilling in the dungeon watching whatever is on the scrying orb. Once in a blue moon he will draw a picture.
Death Knight by Lazy Litch
Veronica Vance, interior illustration – Veronica Vance absolutely requires adult supervision. But being the only adult in the vicinity she often finds herself free to impose upon people’s eyes her filthy arts and wicked crafts. Sometimes a writer, sometimes an artist, always tired. She often reveals herself on twitch, and from there attempts to expand her salacious social media presence.
The Fool by Veronica Vance
The final draft of both volumes is on track to be done by the end of February 2021. After that, they’ll go through their editing passes and into layout. Our estimated delivery date of February 2022 is giving us all an ample amount of time to get these books done and provide a buffer against any unforeseen circumstances, but we should hopefully deliver earlier than that.
These first two volumes are just the start. After Volumes 1 & 2 have been completed and delivered, we plan on developing Volume 3, which will be a book full of advice for the Guide, as well as oodles of random generators, monsters, and magic items, and Volume 4, which will be a full length introductory module.

campaign.story:
What is The Journal of Fantastic Linguistics?
An RPG Zine. More to the point, it's a Zine full of different columns and articles presenting different aspects of languages and linguistics, and how you can incorporate them into your game.
Why?
Language in RPGs is usually neglected or handwaved, beyond maybe an accent here or there, even then missing out on many of the finer aspects one can include in an accent. Languages are complex and multifaceted, and an integral part of our existence as human beings. Every aspect of language, from syntax to pragmatics to sociolinguistics, is rich with content that can be mined for an RPG campaign. Whether you want to make a unique accent, or differentiate cultures by the nuances of their speech, all of this and more can only be achieved by delving into the inner workings of language.
What's in an issue of The Journal of Fantastic Linguistics?
The Zine is built of columns and stand alone articles: Columns present a topic through a different lens each issue. Stand alone articles are pieces that present a single topic, whether a specific aspect of language, different tables for inspiration, or a short plot hook (all related to languages, of course). Each Zine is comprised of four columns and one stand alone article.
In Issue #1 you can find
Accents 101 - A guide to the various elements that an accent contains, and how to use them in your own accents.
Anatomy of Accents - A column examining how the anatomy of different species could affect how they communicate.
Lost in Translation - Various plot hooks revolving around miscommunications and faults in languages and their uses, each issue provides hooks related to some aspect of society.
Creature Communication - A bestiary containing one or two monsters that affect, or are affected by, language.
Talking with Taboos - A stand alone article examining how cultures can use language to mark their taboos - and the people who break them.
A human(oid) and a dragonborn articulatory system side by side
A note on accents and linguistic prejudice
Many tables just pick several real world accents and stick them on the various cultures or races in their campaign. Not only does this perpetuate harmful stereotypes, it also limits the representation of your in game culture. Constructing accents isn't difficult, and you can build accents that are easy for you to use and remember, not limiting yourself to the handful of impersonations you know.
The Budget
A picture is worth a thousand words:
Though in this case it's only worth around twenty: The budget accounts for art (250$), Kickstarter fees (200$), Printing (210$), and shipping (1000$), leaving a buffer (340$) for unforeseen problems.
The budget is planned around the most costly scenario - the project succeeds with exactly 2000$, all coming from 100 backers backing at the print level. In this case the budget should just cover everything. Any extra funds will go towards art for future issues (and maybe printing if all goes really unexpectedly well), as well as maybe buying me a few energy drinks.
The Team
Ziv Plotnik (He/Him): A linguistics grad student with a burning passion for both linguistics and roleplaying games - who finally hopes to combine the two in a way that can be spread to as many people as possible.
Alyssa Schein (She/Her): A freelance artist and roleplaying enthusiast, you can find her works here.

campaign.story:
A Loud Noise in a Quiet Place is a tabletop roleplaying game about my experiences with temporary hearing loss, and about how it affects my perception of the world around me, my relationships with friends and family, and my enjoyment of the things that are important to me. I wrote it in 2019 after a particularly bad spell of hearing loss, as the first RPG which I wrote and published, and this Kickstarter will be the first time it has been in print.
This is a quiet, reflective, and introspective story game for two people to play together in a single session. Simple and easy to play, it's great for newcomers to roleplaying games and experienced players alike. 
What to expect from the game
A Loud Noise in a Quiet Place is a tabletop story game inspired by games about the lived experiences of real people, like Hannah Schaffer's 14 Days, and by games for small groups, like Shawn Tomkin's Ironsworn.
Temporary hearing loss changes how you perceive the world around you in profound ways, because we rely on the subtle balance of our senses. The sudden shift in this balance is a powerful source of introspective drama: the condition is always inconvenient, usually difficult, and sometimes painful. This is true both for me and the people around me.
The game itself is an asymmetric game for two players, with one player taking the role of someone who has temporarily lost their hearing to some degree. Through short scenes, they play out seven days in the life and relationships of their character, with each vignette culminating in a defining sound, heard or misheard, and a single die roll which resolves the scene.
The other player takes up the mantle of these heard or misheard sounds, but throughout the main part of the game, they avoid speaking. Instead, they listen carefully, responding to the other player's narrative by setting the difficulty of the dice roll.
The consequences of failure or success are immediate and lasting, showing the randomness and difficulty of adjusting to a radically different sensory experience of the world.
If you back the game at any level, you'll get immediate free access to the first edition of A Loud Noise in a Quiet Place (available at Marx of High Water on Itchio).
What to expect from the zine
The finished zine will be a 16-page booklet, printed on recycled stock using a Risograph copier and inks. The cover will use black and one additional colour, and be printed on coloured, heavyweight paper stock. Inside, the text will be in printed in black ink on off-white paper. There will be a digital version of the zine published in PDF format.
Early mockup of the printed zine
The zine text will be laid out to be as accessible as possible for low-vision and dyslexic readers, and the PDF will be as accessible as possible to users of screen-readers.
The game is mostly complete; my original game has been through development editing and playtesting, which have led to a few changes to the base mechanics which need to be implemented. After that, the game text will be laid out and illustrated by me with kit-bashed stock art. For everything else, I've swapped favours so far, but from here I need to actually pay people. 
What this Kickstarter is funding
Your money will be funding the work of an accessibility designer who'll be working to make this game as accessible as possible to blind and low-vision players. I'll also be hiring several sensitivity readers and consultants so that the experience of deaf and hard of hearing people feed into the game.
In addition to this valuable and important labour, your money funds the production of the zine at my local printshop, whose specialty is zine printing. They focus on providing environmentally friendly printing and distribution, and also operate as a cooperative, a mode of collective production which I support and practice.
Gaining funds beyond my funding target will allow me to put more money back into the hands of some of my favourite creators in the indie TTRPG community: professional artists, graphic designers and copy editors.
This project is done out of love, and I won't personally profit from it. Should I greatly exceed my expectations, I'll take a little money to cover the time taken to deal with the logistical work involved. Otherwise, money will be going to my friends and collaborators, and to other parts of the indie scene.   
What more money means for the project
£1,275 - Professional cover art - UNLOCKED!: At £1,275, I'll be able to pay Bri de Danann, a wonderfully talented artist, to create a professional two-tone cover for the zine.
£1,550 - Professional touches - UNLOCKED!: At £1,550, I'll be able to pay for professional services including copy editing by Nynphaiel, proofreading, graphic design by Facu Kaper and book layout by Francita Soto.
£1,850 - Internal comics: At £1,850 I'll be able to commission Bri de Danann, who is also an accomplished comic artist, to produce two full-page comics to act as examples of play, expanding the zine to 20 pages.
£2,150 - More comics: If we can get £2,150, I'll commission Bri to create three more comic pages, expanding the zine to 24 beautiful pages. 
How we can help promote others
I'm a diehard indie TTRPG enthusiast. I want every creator to get as much exposure and promo as they need, and Zinequest is the perfect opportunity for that. Through February, my indie TTRPG interview podcast Yes Indie'd Pod is running at least 18 short interviews with amazing creators from other Zinequest campaigns. I'm encouraging backers to go and listen to these interviews, and follow Yes Indie'd Pod on Twitter, as well as the interviewees.
50 New Followers - Audiobook: If the Yes Indie'd Pod Twitter account gets 50 new followers before the campaign finishes, I'll use my quality recording equipment and editing experience to create an audiobook version of the game text, for people whose learning preference is auditory.
If you'd like appear on Yes Indie'd Pod, to talk about or just advertise your TTRPG project, there are two reward tiers for that, both of which include a signed copy of the zine, delivered free worldwide.
The creators behind this project
Marx Shepherd (author) is a game designer and editor for the San Jenaro CoOp and the in*die zine, as well as host of the Yes Indie'd indie interview podcast. They're an all-round indie enthusiast, in between trying to create quiet, non-violent and thoughtful story games. They're unashamedly narrativist and lean strongly towards exploring social issues through play.
Rhi (accessibility consultant) - RPGs are her favourite hobby, and web accessibility is the focus of her career. She found a way to combine them with Skill Check, where she helps game designers ensure that their documents are accessible to all. She can provide guidance on a developing project or help revise existing documents to be accessible.
Shay Erlich (accessibility consultant) is a hard of hearing, multiply disabled, and genderqueer child and youth care practitioner, wheelchair dancer, and circus artist. Shay holds a MA degree in Child and Youth Care from Ryerson. Shay is the co-founder of The Cyborg Circus Project, a trans and disability led arts collective offering arts education, performance and social support to disabled young people aged 16-35 in Canada, centred in the Greater Toronto Area. Working through arts engagement, the Project endeavours to empower disabled people to live as disabled artists in their communities with the tools and support they need to thrive and make art. Furthermore, Shay has extensive experience working as an accessibility consultant in many settings including academic, artistic, and frontline services. They have spent the last ten years advocating for better inclusion and services for young people with disabilities, and currently work as an independent consultant assisting frontline service organizations and arts institutions in creating more accessible programs and productions for the diverse people that they work with through their business Shay Erlich Consulting. Shay also provides training and support for frontline practitioners who wish to improve their practice with disabled clients. Shay strongly believes in a social justice and disability rights approach within a child and youth care relational context. Shay’s vision for the future is one where disabled people have the support and resources that they need to thrive, and to fully participate in all areas of their lives, without having to constantly fight for resources.
Bri de Danann (artist / comic artist) is an illustrator and comic artist working in the Comic and Board Game industry. She is best known for her work on The Phoenix, a science fiction adventure comic, Elemental Spark, a fantasy brawl board game released in August 2020, and Articles of the Arcana, a tarot inspired TTRPG. She primarily works in the digital medium, bringing otherworldly characters and landscapes to life with her bright, dynamic style. You can find more of Bri's work on her website, her gaming and art Twitch channel, and on Twitter.
Jon Garrad (development editor) does independent bookselling, research, and RPG design, working with the San Jenaro Co-Op, the FKR Collective, and under their own imprint as Malediction Games. Jon was responsible for Aces High, All Your Houses and The Hitch Hiker’s Guide to Elfland, and is currently preparing the extended edition of Bloodspell for eventual re-release. They have published poetry, short-stories and academic criticism, are unashamed by their fanfiction, and are committed to open-access, no-paywall research publication for a lay audience. In other lifetimes, Jon taught English and Drama to 14-19 year olds and adults, fundraised and co-ordinated street teams for the Green Party of England and Wales, and was “something in marketing” for four years.
Vicka aka Nynphaiel (copy editor) is a game designer, editor and artist from Argentina. She has been part of her local community for a decade, and joined the international TTRPG scene last year. They are a part of the San Jenaro CoOp and the in*die zine community. She also cohosts a podcast in Spanish about game design, Éxito Parcial. She writes games about revolution, domestic witchcraft, communities, and feelings. Always trying to develop new skills, they enjoy immensely working on collabs. You can find more about their multiple projects and shenanigans on their Twitter, the Volvodja Press label, and their ko-fi.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is my first Kickstarter campaign, although I have followed and backed dozens of projects in the last few years. I am familiar with the process of campaigning and fulfillment, and my work in the indie TTRPG space has helped me get to grips with running a creative project. Managing complex projects is also a part of my day job. All-in-all, I'm pretty qualified to run this project. That said, there are always challenges and risks, and I'll address the biggest of these below.

Firstly, Brexit. This project is conducted in British Pounds, and the effects of the UK leaving the EU still aren't certain. As most of my collaborators take payment in US Dollars, their cut of the funds in pounds might be higher than predicted. This will be covered by a small contingency allowance, and won't affect delivery.

Secondly, postal services. My local supply chain is small and stable: I collect the zines locally and use one of the longest running postal services in the world to deliver them. However, there is still uncertainty in overseas delivery, due in part to the pandemic and in part to the United States Postal Service, the state of which affects many other countries. As such, international delivery may be delayed or have other issues. I will replace any copies lost or damaged in the post once the expected delivery window has past.

Thirdly, managing freelancers. Some of my collaborators do this work as a sideline, and the ongoing pandemic affects their regular employment prospects. This may mean that their personal circumstances may add delays to the project. If this becomes a problem, I will seek other freelancers instead. Any additional costs incurred will come from the contingency pot.

Fourthly, me. Most of the delivery of this project is on me personally, which carries the biggest risk. Whilst I am committed to delivering this project, should my personal circumstances change dramatically, I may have to pass on the responsibility of fulfillment to someone else.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
campaign.env:
Environmental commitments
Visit our Environmental Resources Center to learn how Kickstarter encourages sustainable practices.
Long-lasting design
I'm using heavier weight paper and card stock than books and zines typically use. This will reduce wear, allowing for a longer lasting product.
Reusability and recyclability
The zine will be made from recycled paper, and aside from the spine staples, it will be fully recyclable. Shipping packaging will consist only of paper and card.
Sustainable materials
Using recycled paper reduces the use of virgin materials, and in addition, I have specified uncoated paper, which is a more environmentally-friendly option in terms of carbon emissions and material use.
Environmentally friendly factories
The zines will be printed by a local printing co-operative who are committed to sustainable, low impact business. I trust them implicitly to do this right - beyond any of my expectations, they have suggested the sustainable materials, paper treatments and printing techniques outlined above.
Sustainable Distribution
I'm using local businesses, so I'll be collecting the printed zines on my pedal cycle. Likewise, I will take the zines on foot to my local Post Office. This will reduce the carbon impact of delivery as much as is possible.

Unfortunately, fast international shipping generally relies on airmail. However, after funding, those from outside the UK or EU can opt for International Economy delivery, which is a "surface mail" option using ships and trains. This helps to reduce the carbon impact of delivery.

Many of the project backers will choose to receive the zine in digital form only. This results in less carbon emissions and material usage compared to printing and shipping a booklet.
Something else
As an engineer I regard sustainability holistically, encompassing environmental, economic and social aspects. In terms of sustainable economies, I'll spending money in local businesses, minimising profits and contingency, and providing hardship pledge tiers for those in need. For social sustainability, I'll be commissioning marginalised creators, and focusing on document accessibility for sensory impairment and neurodivergency.

Within just a few hours of that special 48 hours email going out, we were straight through the £1,275 mark, meaning we'll be getting professional cover art from my amazing friend, the wonderful and talented Bri de Danann, an illustrator and comic book artist. Hey wonderful backers,

For starters, that's when that magic reminder email goes out, which from experience is when people remember this cool campaign that they totally meant to back. There's usually a pretty good upsurge in backers from this time, which will hopefully take us over the line to get Bri de Danann onboard for getting new cover art, and maybe a bit extra too!

Hello gracious and generous backers!
We're nearly at the finish line. In a marathon, we'd be saving energy for the last little sprint. Not here, because Zinequest is more like a mid-distance run, but there you go.
/a loud noise in a quiet place/ is a game that's meant to take place over seven in-game days. Why? Because when I have hearing problems and I call the doctor's, they tell me, yep, we can try to help you with that, but you have to try and treat it yourself first (narrator voice: this never works) for seven days. campaign.story:
What's It All About?
As a part of this year's Zinequest, I'm launching the first volume of my tabletop gaming zine, "Harrowed Grounds," which will focus on OSR RPG materials, in particular resources for running hexcrawls in a gritty but fantastical fantasy setting.
Who Am I?
My name is Todd. As Hexed Press, I've spent the last few years producing videos on tabletop gaming with an emphasis on OSR gaming, hexcrawls and sandbox play, and other TTRPG topics. It's always been a part of my plan to create materials in addition to talking about them. This is step one in that process.
What is Harrowed Grounds?
Naming things is hard but I think I found one that fits (I like it, anyway, so don't @ me). The focus of this zine is on OSR materials for running the kinds of games that I like, featuring hexcrawls, open sandbox campaigns, etc., in a setting that I use for my home game that I'd like to share.
For this first volume, I'm aiming for:
32ish pages of old school inspired mechanics, setting, and other content along with accompanying art, maps, diagrams, and ephemera in dazzling black and white
Rendered as a fresh, crisp PDF and digitally delivered directly or printed locally and hand-shipped by me
What Are the Particulars?
For this first volume, I'll be laying the groundwork for everything that follows, so you can look for:
hexcrawl basics';
setting overview and cosmology;
character class options;
a couple of monsters; and,
a starting location and surrounding areas to explore.
About this Setting You Speak Of...
I'm not a gonzo kind of guy and this setting isn't that. It's going to resonate with you if you enjoy the sort of weird sword & sorcery fantasy girded by a gritty, relatively grounded world such as the classic tales of Conan, Farfrd, and  others. Now I'm not saying there will absolutely, positively never be any crashed space ships and malfunctioning laser-swords, but those would be exceptions, not the rules.

campaign.story:
Fantasy gods made easy
The gods, spirits and religions of a fantasy world should be a vital and exciting part of its culture. But how do you create a pantheon that feels rich and real without having to do a lot of time-consuming prep work?
The Pamphlet of Pantheons is the lazy GM's solution to this problem: a workbook zine that helps you create a pantheon for your fantasy RPGs, focusing on the bits of the iceberg above the water -- the bits that your players are going to interact with. 
The Pamphlet contains 16 major Divine Archetypes for you to choose from, each with customisation tables to give the gods more character, plus tables and lists to generate gods with multiple divine roles, minor deities, temple features, rituals, and more. Go through the simple step-by-step creation process or just use the book to inspire your own creations. The goal of the Pamphlet is to make creating fantasy religions simple and enjoyable.
What you'll get
Pledge for the physical copy and you'll get a 20-page black and white zine with a full-colour cover. Untreated paper stock makes the Pamphlet ideal for making notes or filling out the pantheon sheet that makes up the centre of the zine. You'll also get a digital version of the pamphlet so you can print out as many pantheon sheets as you like. If you prefer, you can pledge for the digital reward and just get the PDF. 
Stay tuned
Over the two weeks of the Kickstarter, I'll be providing periodic updates including samples of the text, worked examples of Pantheon creation, and more.

Hi everyone,

I have most of the interior pages done at this point, but there are a couple that I think are going to take a little longer; I want the central spread to be a fun worksheet, so I first have to design it, taxing my minimal art skills to the limit. 
I mentioned in my last update that I was struggling with the free-but-maybe-not-made-for-a-beginner-like-me publishing program Scribus. After an evening of particularly slow progress, I suddenly realised "wait a minute! My generous backers wildly exceeded my funding goals!" So I bought some more accessible publishing software and it's been going a lot more smoothly ever since.

updates.update_userinfo: One week on and working on the text. Plus: an archetype!
updates.update_content:
Hello, backers, and thanks again for your support for the Pamphlet of Pantheons. I wanted to make sure that I kept everyone up to date on the progress of the Pamphlet. I'm currently working on revising and editing the text just to make sure it's clear and enjoyable to read. The descriptions are all pretty short, so it's important to me that they be evocative. 
Anyway, it's not the most exciting process in the world, and it's been slowed by the need to catch up on things that I put aside while the Kickstarter was going, but it's rumbling along.

Thank you so much, generous backers! I've been surprised and humbled by the response the Pamphlet has received. 
The next steps
In terms of creating the Pamphlet, nothing really changes, since I was already hard at work on the editing phase. I'll post frequent updates here, and as I get some pages laid out (or even some test ones) I'll post them as well so that you can see what I've been working on.
