campaign.story:
Welcome to Project 8Ball
Project 8Ball is a highly secretive government organization founded in the year [REDACTED] by [REDACTED]. Though the organization’s original purpose was [REDACTED], the mission evolved over time, gradually developing into its current agenda.   
The [REDACTED] in charge of Project 8Ball know that the world is a shadowy cesspool of mystery and madness. Aliens, cryptids, parahumans, time travel, space gods, angels, [REDACTED], all of it is real, but none of it fits into the average person’s view of reality. In fact, normal people who encounter the paranormal tend to go insane. Project 8Ball is dedicated to dealing with this threat by maintaining baseline consensus reality. Dangerous esoteric elements must be investigated and resolved.
To this end, the Project employs a team of highly-trained [REDACTED] agents. At any given time the majority of these agents are in deep cover, living mundane lives and working mundane jobs. Thanks to the Project's memory manipulation technology, they have no recollection of their previous lives and no idea that their current identities are artificial constructs. When a threat appears, the Project reactivates a team of agents. 
Their mission: keep the world normal, even if they go mad doing it.

The Game
Project 8Ball is a role-playing game of mystery and weird conspiracy inspired by the works of David Lynch, Grant Morrison, and Philip K. Dick. Like the novels of Philip K. Dick, Project 8Ball revolves around two questions: What is Real? and What is the Nature of Identity? Players explore these questions by playing mentally-altered, existentially-damaged agents of normalcy in a world of endless weirdness. Project 8Ball uses game mechanics designed by Steve Johnson, the designer behind the QAGS and Cinemechanix systems, and will be published by Hex Games. 
While many games build a wall between players and Game Masters, Project 8Ball eschews the auteur theory of RPGs and tears that wall down. The old hierarchies are flattened. One member of your gaming group will be the GM for your first session but for the second session someone else will take on the role. You will continue to rotate, with everyone getting an equal chance to manipulate the game’s reality. That reality is subjective--by drawing the map, you create the territory. Working together, you and your friends weave a web of mystery and wonder. 
The game includes:
*An overview of the premise;
*Rules for character creation, including sample character archetypes;
*Rules for action resolution;
*A full adventure, "The S.T.A.B. Imperative";
*Rules for the rotating Game Master system; 
*Useful tables and appendices. 

Frequently Asked Questions
What is a Role-Playing Game? 
A role-playing game (RPG) is a magical mechanism whereby you and a small group of colleagues can transport yourselves to a land of imagination, leaving behind your worldly cares for a few sweet hours. 
What kind of dice will I need for this game?
Project 8ball uses 6 different types of dice: 4-sided (abbreviated “d4”), 6-sided (d6), 8-sided (d8), 10-sided (d10), 12-sided (d12), and 20-sided (d20). 
What is an appropriate number of players? 
3-6, depending on the scenario and your playing style.
What is the core game mechanic?
Roll two dice and try to hit a Target Number. What type of dice they are will depend on your character's skills and specific situation.  
Why Is there a rotating GM?
This system encourages every player to take equal ownership of the game and to contribute to the reality in which the characters exist. There are specific rules to facilitate the process, about which plot details are set in stone and which can be overturned. 
How do we decide who gets the first turn as GM?
As reasonable adults, you should be able to decide amongst yourselves. Failing that, the person who bought the game gets to go first. 
What if I don't have time for a campaign? 
There are a lot of games out there and only so many hours in the day, so I understand if you're not ready to commit to a full-on campaign. You may also choose to run Project 8Ball as a one-shot game. I have run the included adventure “The S.T.A.B. Imperative” as a one-shot at various conventions and I'm confident it can provide a satisfying evening’s entertainment for you and your friends.
What happens when I die? 
Reply hazy; try again later.

Format
Project 8Ball is part of the Zine Quest 3 initiative. In accordance with Zine Quest guidelines, Project 8Ball will be an 8.5” x 5.5” staple-bound zine printed in a single color. It will be illustrated throughout. I estimate it will end up being around 60 pages long. It will be printed by Mixam, which has a proven track record of quality printing with excellent turn-around times.

Art
In addition to writing the book I will also do some of the illustrations. And, thanks to your support, I will be able to commission some amazing artists to provide artwork, specifically Diogo Nogueira and James Hornsby.  
Diogo Nogueira is well known in the RPG community for writing and illustrating dozens of games. I previously worked with him on Leopard Women of Venus, and the results were spectacular. Here's his illustration of the Science Robots from LWOV:  
I have worked with James Hornsby many times over the years, and his artwork never fails to delight. Here's a drawing he did for the Hex Games release Sharktoberfest:
And here's a drawing I did for my previous zine, Akashic Titan: 
Stretch Goals
If I get enough support, I'll be able to add some fun extra features to this zine. 
$500 - The project is funded. 
$1000 - More artwork! Instead of James and Diogo contributing two drawings apiece, they will each do four drawings! Imagine the beauty! 
$1500 - Art bonanza! In addition to James and Diogo, I will bring in extra bonus surprise artists! The book will be filled with luscious, glorious artwork! 

What Is Hex Games?
Hex Games is a beloved indie game publisher that has been putting out games since 1998. Highlights include QAGS, M-Force, The Adventures of Sindbad, Weird Times at Charles Fort High, Spy Racers, Roller Girls Vs., the ENnie Award-winning Hobomancer, American Artifacts, Sharktoberfest, GILGAMESH!, and Laser Ponies. Hex Games was founded by Steve "Elvismancer" Johnson and me, Leighton Connor. You can learn more about Hex at www.hexgames.com.

Who Am I?
Who are any of us, really? When I become aware of myself as a distinct individual alive in this specific moment in history, I identify as Leighton Connor. I am a son, a brother, a husband, and a father. I have been publishing RPG content for more than 20 years. I co-founded Hex Games in 1997, where I co-created QAGS (the Quick Ass Game System), worked on the ENnie Award-winning Hobomancer, wrote Laser Ponies, and more. With Josh Burnett I co-created the feverish sci-fi game Leopard Women of Venus. In 2019 Josh and I ran a successful Kickstarter campaign for a new DCC edition of Leopard Women of Venus. In 2020 I ran successful Kickstarters for my DCC zine Akashic Titan and a new edition of Laser Ponies. 
I wrote and drew the web comics Laser Brigade and Fuzzball & Scuzzball and co-wrote The Electric Team. I illustrated the books The Twible: All the Chapters of the Bible in 140 Characters or Less! and Fierce: Women of the Bible and their Stories of Violence, Mercy, Bravery, Wisdom, Sex, and Salvation.  I was one of the three artists on the Seeing Calvino project. I also self-publish short stories, I know, I’m all over the place.
You can follow me on Twitter at @johnnyampersand, or sign up for my mailing list here.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is a low-risk project. Last year I completed and shipped my Zine Quest zine Akashic Titan in a timely manner. Josh Burnett and I completed our Kickstarter for Leopard Women of Venus and are in the final stages of getting the book to the backers. That one took longer than anticipated, but that was largely because we ended up adding more material than we originally planned and the book ended up being larger than we expected. I learned a lesson from that, and while I will be tweaking and improving the text for Project 8Ball, I will not be adding any new sections. 

I have written a draft of Project 8Ball which is 95% complete and which still needs to be edited and revised. I have lined up editors who will give me feedback. 

The biggest potential delay I foresee is that personal issues could arise with one or more artists that might delay them in turning in the remaining pieces of artwork. I have worked with these artists before, though, and they have always been professional and hit their deadlines. I believe they will complete their illustrations in a timely manner. 

I should be able to finish the book by the end of June. To make sure I have enough time, however, I have built in two extra months. Barring any unforeseen catastrophes, I should have no problem printing and shipping the zine by August.

updates.update_content:
Hello, friends. In my last update I told you that I was finishing up work on my game Laser Ponies and I would begin to really focus on Project 8Ball in June. I have good news on both these fronts.
Laser Ponies is finished, and on sale now! It's an all-ages game of adorable ponies who shoot lasers from their eyes. It is . . . very different from Project 8Ball. I am a man of many facets. It's a good time, though, and if you have kids, know kids, or were ever a kid, you might want to check it out.

Hello, friends! Sorry about the silence, I know it's been awhile since I updated you. I've continued to revise the 8Ball text when I have time but I don't have a lot to report currently. 
A couple of things have kept me busy: 1. Finishing up my game Laser Ponies, which had a successful Kickstarter campaign in late 2020, and 2. My job. I have good news on both those fronts. We're finishing up the final stages of layout on Laser Ponies as I type this, so very soon I'll be able to get those to the backers and focus my creative energies on Project 8Ball. As far as the second goes, I'm a teacher, so while May is a very busy month, once school ends (May 28!) I will have a lot more free time. This was always part of my plan for this project--last year I did the bulk of the writing, art, and layout for my book Akashic Titan in June. is much farther along than AT was so I don't foresee any problems getting it done by the end of June. Though I do need to check in with the artists, thanks for reminding me.

My friends, we made it. Project 8Ball is funded and we hit the first stretch goal. Give yourselves a round of applause! 
As I write this, there are only four hours left in my friend Steve Johnson's Kickstarter for Elvismancer, the zine that dares to answer the question, "What if Elvis impersonation isn't just a weird entertainment niche, but a full-fledged magical tradition?" If you haven't backed that one yet, I highly recommend it.

Hey! This Kickstarter ends at midnight tonight, Monday the 15th, and as I write this there are only TEN HOURS to go! We're at $1368, which is great, but I would still love to hit that second stretch goal at $1500. I've reached out to all the people I know, so if you get a chance, please reach out to anyone you know who might be interested and tell 'em about Project 8Ball. And do it soon! TIME IS RUNNING OUT. 
Thanks! I appreciate your support.

Hello, backers! We are in the home stretch now--as I write this, there are only 56 hours to go in the Project 8Ball campaign! We are substantially past our initial goal, and we've hit our first stretch goal, but there's still one more stretch goal to go!
A reminder of those goals: 
$500 - The project is funded.

ONLY FOUR DAYS TO GO! And it occurs to me that I have not shared any content from the game. Oops, I'll get right on that.
Project 8Ball, you may recall, is a secret government agency that works to preserve baseline consensus reality by investigating and dealing with weird stuff. Most of their agents are in deep cover, living assuming lives with implanted memories. The game includes a complete adventure, "The S.T.A.B. Ultimatum," as well as suggestions for creating your own adventures. There's a list of 20 story ideas to get you started. I wrote about 17 ideas and then asked my friends Steve Johnson and Josh Burnett if they had any. Between them they sent me about six, and they were all good, so I cut some of mine to squeeze in theirs.

Friends, Zine Quest changed my life.
My friend Steve Johnson and I co-founded Hex Games in 1997 and over the years we've published over 50 books. I illustrated a few, co-wrote several, and edited most of them. But by 2017 or so, I was burnt out. I no longer ran or played in games, except a couple of times a year at conventions. I felt like the gaming part of me had shriveled up and died. I could not figure out how to even begin writing a game project. Hex still put out books periodically, but it was a struggle for me to even edit, much less write anything.

Woo hoo, Project 8Ball hit the first stretch goal! We've passed the $1000 mark, which means I can now commission twice as much artwork from Diogo and James! That means four full-page illustrations from each of them, which will make the book so much lovelier. 
Last time I focused on Diogo's work, so let's take a moment to talk about James. James Hornsby is an uber-talented comics artist who has drawn the comic strip Botched Spot for years and is now working on a graphic novel called Ruthless Rex on the Ceratopsian Circuit. It's about dinosaur wrestlers and it looks amazing.

Hello, backers! Things are going well--as I write this near the end of Day 3, Project 8Ball has 62 backers who have pledged a total of $882, which puts us at 176% of our funding goal. That's awesome! Now we can turn our attention to the wondrous world of stretch goals. 
I originally planned on doing all the artwork for Project 8Ball, like I did for Akashic Titan, my Zine Quest zine from last year. When the prospect of illustrating Project 8Ball started to feel daunting I realized, hey, I don't have to do it all--I can raise money to hire awesome artists. I talked to a couple of my friends and brainstormed what artists would be best suited for this project and ended up with two names: Diogo Nogueira and James Hornsby. I approached them and, happily, they both said yes.

campaign.story:
In the Shadow of Tower Silveraxe is a classic old-school fantasy sandbox adventure module.
There could be several reasons to seek adventure in the Gemthrone Wilderness. It is a region that is often the subject of speculation on cold nights in the glow of a tavern hearth. Some may talk of the treasures that have laid untouched for centuries in dark dungeons, just waiting to be pilfered—which is then, almost without fail, followed by another who interjects with the dangers of such notions, were the legends even to be believed.
There are, however, those who do believe such tales—wizened adventurers who know there is always some truth to even the most unbelievable stories. One just has to know what rumors to listen for...
A chaotic leader of a group of outlaws and mercenaries, Duard Silveraxe, has braved the Labyrinthine forest and taken control of the ancient ruined Tower of Shadow from the elves. Duard seeks power here—legends say that the elves of the tower keep a dark power hidden there—immortality and weird magical abilities granted to the one who performs the rituals to unlock them. 
For centuries, the elves of this region have been custodians of the Tower of Shadow. Their charge has been to keep its ancient magic hidden from those who might use it in the name of chaos—the ability to harness the powers of the Shadow Plane. To become shadow itself.
Since the assault, the denizens of the surrounding forest, including the more monstrous creatures—trolls and giant spiders— have fled from the vicinity of the tower and into the nearby mountains, causing problems for settlers of the region—including the residents of the peaceful dwarven town of Karn Buldahr. The town council has sought aid from any willing adventurers to help deal with the attacks.

Bugbear Attack!
In the Shadow of Tower Silveraxe is a 52 page (not including cover) adventure module zine designed for use with the Old School Essentials or Basic/Expert classic fantasy rules. It's old-school in both flavor and design mindset—weird and fantastic pulp adventure. Not all encounters are balanced and survival is not a guarantee. 
The zine contains a detailed map of the Gemthrone wilderness, seven dungeons, and four settlements including the dwarven town of Karn Buldahr— which can serve well as a starting location for lower level adventurers. Each settlement has its own list of rumors, hooks, and NPCs.
It is designed as a module. Use it as a standalone campaign, graft it onto your existing campaign wherever you find mountainous wilderness, or drop in any of the dungeons as a one-shot. 
Also, the layout is designed with clarity and usability in mind. Dungeon maps are easy to read and their corresponding room descriptions and relevant monster stats are placed so that they are all on the same spread—less page flipping, less time prepping!
tldr:
52 interior pages 
Topographic wilderness overland map
7 dungeon locations
4 settlement locations with hooks and NPCs
Setting and local faction lore
Additional rules for more simple and dynamic weather
Below are a few examples of what's inside.
Cover mockup
Mock up of a 2-page spread of one of the dungeons in the module.
The Dwarven town of Karn Buldahr.
The contour overland map for the Gemthrone Wilderness region.
Closeup view of a section of the overland map
The map is done in the style of a topographic wilderness hiking map, complete with elevation, contours, vegetation density, relief shading, water features, and trail mileage noted to the 1/10 of a mile! All this detail is so the referee can accurately describe the surroundings, precise travel times, and adjudicate exploration should the players decide to take a different route. In addition, a 6-mile hex grid overlay will help if they want to go off trail or if you prefer running a hex-crawl  style games. 
Crab Spider Attack! Art featured in the zine.

All of the art, cartography, and layout design are done by me. The only art left to complete is the interior art which will come as either smaller filler art and a couple (maybe more) larger full page pieces in black and white. The art will be thematic to the content of the zine and invoke older-era RPG-ness in my style. I usually work traditionally with pen (and brush) and ink—except for the cover art, which I digitally painted. 
 My Instagram 



I have set July as the expected delivery date, but I expect to have it out sooner than that. The bulk of the production work is complete and all that is left is interior art, playtesting, editing, and revisions.

campaign.story:
100% funded! Stretch goals now available. 
 Stories from the Slough is a compact adventure Zine for any fantasy or post-apocalyptic RPG. It is a weird swamp filled with strange mutated monsters, people, and diseases. Its origins are unique in that we knew that we wanted to make an adventure in this particular format, but we had no idea what exactly we were making. So, we started with a monster. From this one image of a monster and a long discussion online, the rest of the game idea was developed. Here is that beauty:

 For years, I have been off and on exploring a particular format for adventures. None published until now, but I believe I have perfected the format to a point I am comfortable putting it in public view. This format is a hex-crawl adventure where every hex takes a page (or two) of information. Each hex has its own unique random encounters and "search" encounters. Through these 12 different unique encounters, each hex might take up an entire session. Multiply this by over a dozen hexes, and you have a full campaign full of interesting things to explore, treasure, and nasty monsters.

Stories from the Slough is a rules agnostic adventure. Any classic fantasy game will work from Dungeons and Dragons to Oldschool Essentials to Knave.

The product itself is a 50 to 60-page, A5-sized Green and white zine. It will be spine stapled with a color cover and shipped to you in the mail. The PDF will be available on drivethruRPG, published by Stormforge Productions. 
What's in the adventure?
 19 Hexes to explore: Each hex is a mile-wide stretch of swamp, and requires one hour to trudge through.
 2 Dungeons: Each takes only a page for the map, and a few pages for the content. A witches cabin larger on the inside, and a gaping wound that leads into the behemoth that rots under the swamp.
 6 Special NPC Stories: There are more than 6 characters in the adventure, but these six are special. They have their own story to explore, their own goals and quests, and really make the adventure feel alive.
 Several factions: Factions ranging from the strange but peaceful villagers to blood worshiping cultists to followers of a plant god.
Example Page
Stretch Goals
REACHED: We are giving away an 11"x14" poster map of the overland hex-crawl to all who are receiving a physical copy of the zine.
REACHED: we will also be giving away a PDF of a separate zine called "Slough: Beauties and Beasts" A collection of many of the monsters and plants in the slough, their extended lore, and illustrations. We cannot promise every monster will make it into the book, but many of the most interesting will.
REACHED: we will include a physical copy of the "Slough: Beauties and Beasts" with all backers who are receiving a physical copy of the "Stories from the Slough." We will also release the PDF of the "Slough Survival Guide."
REACHED: we will give physical copies of both extra zines to those who are receiving a physical copy of Stories from the Slough.
What's Next? 
After this project is complete, we are going to host another Kickstarter for a game called Tales of Dungeons Deep. A dark fantasy OSR RPG. It is mostly complete and needs editing, art, and support. Keep up with us @DapRabbitGames
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is the first Kickstarter we have ever run, so the risks of failure are not negligible. However, this project is somewhat small and, regardless of the results of the Kickstarter, it will be done eventually. We do our own art, writing, and layout. Printing is cheap enough. campaign.story:
Anarchy!
Oi! It’s the year 1983, and the world is gone! Well gone… You see, the big three (Reagan, Brezhnev, and Thatcher) decided that it was a great fucking idea to start poking bombs at each other, and then BOOM! One day in October, it all goes to shite! It was nothing like that late-night movie said it would be. The radiation brought about something they call Dark Mana; it was worse than anything we could imagine. You think a bunch of yuppie fascists were bad when they were swilling imported beer, try imbuing them with dark magic, then all hell breaks loose, literally!

Now they try to rebuild their capitalistic utopias with fanatical cults, CEO demons, and a well-armed police state trying to oppress our music and freedoms. Well, not if we can help it! The underground is alive and fighting back. We have also gathered the power of this dark corruption to throw it back in their faces. They call us the Anarchists, those of us who have sworn to fight the power in a whole new way. They may have the armies of the damned at their side, but we fight back with our music, courage, and anarchy!
Growing up amongst the San Francisco punk scene, I got to see all the amazing poster art, and punk shows the city had to offer. It was an amazing time with interesting people and great music. When I heard about ZineQuest, it immediately made me think of all the cheap zines I would buy at Rough Trade Records like Maximum RockNRoll. I wanted to pay homage to my teenage years, the wonderful SF punk scene, and my love for role-playing games. Anarchy is a #zinequest passion project based on an alternate, "No Future," that happened after the bombs fell. The radiation brought about what some call the Dark Mana, but what we call Anarchy. The ability to alter the reality around us, drink cheap beer, and play some hard tunes. Sure, it's a silly concept, but very Punk Rock!
The game has two modes of play, softcore and hardcore. Simply put, you will grab a s**t-load of dice based on your traits, roll them, and add up the successes. Simple tasks need no die roll. Drinking a cup of coffee, putting on a pair of Doc"s, lighting a cigarette fall into a simple task. Drinking a cup of coffee with your feet, putting Doc"s on a gorilla, or lighting a cigarette with a flamethrower these tasks would be complex. A complex task is something that has a chance of failure.
The Softcore Method
Grab some dice equal to your relevant Trait and compare the highest die rolled to the chart.
6 = You f**ked up!
5 = Failed, and you looked stupid.
4 = Loser.
3 = You did it, but still quite sloppy.
2 = Not too shabby.
1 = Look at you!
Not much else, this game was meant to reflect the culture of the San Francisco Punk scene of the 1980s, the massive fear that we're all going to get bombed by Russia, and the best place to buy wine before the bands started playing. If anything, put on a playlist of The Dead Kennedys, Fear, Exploited, Black Flag, Angry Samoans, Social Distortion, Circle Jerks, and the Sex Pistols. Please pick up a bunch of d6s out of your old board games, and play the game (or at least look at it).

campaign.story:
The mayor of Dragon Town, who just so happens to be an enormous gold dragon, has gone missing! A group of ransacking goat people have taken over Grandpap’s magical apple farm. Thieving catfolk have set up shop in the town’s bakery and are planning some sort of elaborate heist. The castle is surrounded by mysterious living vines. The dead are rising up from the graveyard and puking all over the place. And every night slimes flood the streets, looking for their next juicy snack. Without the dragon’s help, the townsfolk are in desperate need of some adventurers to save the day!
Flik Silverpen’s Guide to Dragon Town is a 32 page (ish) zine, color cover, black and white interiors, filled with everything a Dungeon Master will need to run the town, as well as a fun, low-level adventure that’s compatible with 5e, OSR, or any fantasy RPG system.
The adventure should take between 3 and 6 sessions to run. Players can experience Dragon Town with or without combat. So if your group liked to fight monsters, there’s plenty of undead bones to break. But if you’d rather run a game that’s more about using wits, stealth, and charisma, that’ll absolutely work too!
There are lots of curious places to explore, interesting NPC’s to interact with, and some delightful magical items to acquire. Dragon Town will be filled with illustrations, maps, and hand-drawn type! All organized into an easy to use format!

You can follow along with the development of Dragon Town here!

Let’s keep this simple!
 $5 PDF Only: Get the digital version of the Dragon Town zine, plus digital versions of any stretch goals!
   $12 (plus shipping) Print + PDF: Get a physical copy of the Dragon Town zine, plus physical versions of all the stretch goals. An exclusive to Kickstarter sticker and 1” button. And digital versions of everything too!

 UNLOCKED 11" x 17" Dragon Town Map: Double sided map of Dragon Town and the surrounding area. Digital version comes with all pledge tiers. Printed map comes with Print + PDF tier. 
 UNLOCKED Mini Zine Adventure: A tiny 6 page, plus cover add on side quest adventure. Digital version comes with all pledge tiers. Printed mini zine comes with Print + PDF tier. 
 UNLOCKED Printable Paper Miniatures: A digital set of paper miniatures you can print and use on your table while playing Dragon Town. Will include around 20 unique miniatures in an easy to print and assemble PDF. Included in PDF and Print pledge tiers.
 UNLOCKED Virtual Table Top Tokens: 20+ NPC and Monster digital tokens, ready to import into your Virtual Table Top! Included in PDF and Print pledge tiers.

Flik Silverpen is a world-renowned bard, an authority on adventure, a connoisseur of chronicles, a traveler of tales, a fable finder, and a notorious note-taker. If he finds himself someplace interesting, he talks to everyone around, takes in the sights, and compiles a comprehensive guide book!
JP Coovert is Flik Silverpen’s assistant. A freelance illustrator from the fantastical land of Cincinnati, OH. JP’s job is to help Flik get his guide books made! Whether it’s taking numerous notes, illustrating elusive beasts, or finding the perfect printer, JP gets it done!
For more info about Dragon Town follow JP on Instagram and Youtube, where he posts drawings (daily) and videos (weekly!) 
The zine is written but still needs to be edited for maximum usability. Lots of illustrations and maps still need to be made as well. All of that will take a couple of months, then time for printing and shipping. I’ve set the delivery date for July 2021, but I’d like to be done sooner! Expect monthly updates here on Kickstarter (and even more frequent on my Youtube channel) about the zine’s progress!

The bulk of the funds raised will be spent on printing, mailing costs, taxes, and Kickstarter fees. I’m doing the writing and illustration myself, so any extra profit will help me finish the zine faster.

A note on shipping: When the zines are ready to be mailed, they will ship USPS first-class in a chipboard mailer. Unfortunately, international shipping is crazy expensive. Thanks in advance for understanding!

campaign.story:
The Merovingian Hack takes a fantastical, adventurous approach to the 6th century in Western Europe, a time of climate calamity, plague, conquest, social change, and religious consolidation. It was a time when the west was trying to figure out just who it was, taking inspiration from its tribal and Roman roots under the burgeoning influence of the Catholic church. In this world your characters can take on many roles with the help of your referee, the impartial arbiter of the action at hand. Politic with the nobles, fight with a warband, move goods as a trader, or try to get rich off the many hoards and ruins dotting the land.
The Merovingian Hack uses a simple 2d6 roll-over mechanic married to the principles of the Free Kriegsspiel Revolution. Inspired by modern OSR, fiction forward, and classic-era roleplaying games but claiming to be none of those, The Merovingian Hack offers its own, if familiar, take on roleplaying. The Merovingian Hack proposes sandbox improv play and features random tables and resources to help power your campaign. It is quick, loose, interpretive, and brutal. This is a Zine Quest project like no other.
This is a raw zine, without an editorial process, with writing and layout (and some illustration) by me. It's designed to look like a zine of old, banged out on a typewriter with some hand-drawn images to add flavor. This is absolutely a conscious affectation; I used a word processor and a modern printer/scanner, but I guarantee you those writers of yore would have done the same in my shoes. The end product will be printed double-sided on 8 or 9 sheets of 24# Bond/90 GSM US Letter paper, folded in half to QUADRUPLE the page count, staple-bound by yours truly, and shipped to you in a brown envelope for a very low price. Because this is a labor of enthusiasm and fun. And hey, at the very least maybe some of these tables can provide inspiration and content for your own game.
Mock-up product with 9 pages US Letter. Not the actual thing, but close enough.

campaign.story:
Old School, rules light, tables heavy GM'less RPG
I have been trying to find that same sort of mysterious feeling I had when I was six and  played my first pen and paper RPG.  It was tense, I was afraid of dying.  A twelve-sided die was an awe-inspiring and esoteric object.  There was loot and I wanted it but the monsters were in the way.  Thirty years later I find myself wanting more than the "see monster, kill monster, reward" play style.  I want to get nervous, run away when its the smart thing to do, and feel like success is an accomplishment that is nowhere near guaranteed.   I also want a world.  One that is living, wild, and treacherous.  One that extends a call to foolhardy heroes willing to wager certain death in their noble attempt to save it.   And I want all of this to happen in 1-3 hours of game time with minimal rules.
12 Years prototype
I love hand-crafted limited edition objects.  Arcane and obscure, this hand-crafted zine will be limited to 120 copies so that I can guarantee it will become as lost as the majority of Vancian magic.  This hand printed cover with matching metallic green staples and die-cut cardstock play sheets is sure to become a rare artifact!
Update: The Rejuvenation tier added 60 copies due to requests after first 120 going so rapidly! Regardless of when these are gone, I will not be adding more.  If you want to stay in the know on future endeavors, playtesting opportunities, and more you can sign up for the mailing list.
Overview
12 Years pairs overland exploration and dungeon crawling by alternating between two game modes along your quest: Hexploring & Delving.  
You will assemble a party of adventurer's and send them off to their certain doom in an attempt to save the world from the wrath of the Lich King.  As the party traverses the wilderness, the world is randomly generated and explored with a variety of terrain and encounters.  Beware the fascinating draw of the Fae as one may easily become lost and find that years have passed in what seems to have been merely a day.
 The quest for loot, and more specifically a crown, will certainly drive any party Delving underground to explore the strange entrances that occasionally are uncovered above.  When Delving, the party will also explore randomly generated dungeons ranging form claustrophobic single rooms to sprawling cavernous complexes with multiple levels.  Delving brings a greater chance of reward than Hexploring but also far more danger. 
As failed parties parties perish, take the time you have left to assemble a new party to try again.
You have 12 years until the Lich King burns the known world.  Can you or anyone you know complete the coronation ritual and appease him?  Better yet, destroy him once and for all?
Multiplayer 
12 Years is designed first as a solo-game but also contains multiplayer rules giving it new life for those who have played through it solo.  Players do not take turns. Multiplayer is considered parallel and may be played competitively, cooperatively, or both.  A game of 12 Years can easily migrate between synchronous and asynchronous play.
Clairvoyant & Rejuvenation Add-Ons
Lich King Sticker - $2.00
Demon Bookmark w/Monster HP Tracker - $2.00
Cardstock Hexploring, Delving, Party, & Quick Play sheets (these are not die cut and may be on a different cardstock than the Fae-Touched reward) - $4.00

To receive add-ons, total the items you want and increase your pledge by that amount.  A survey will go out to backers at the end of the campaign so that you can identify the specific items you want.  At this time, no more than one of any specific add-on will be permitted per backer. 
Digital Bonuses
Due to the pandemic, I needed to find some creative solutions to test the multiplayer variants.  A surprising benefit was creating fun and easy ways to play virtually.  For 2-player games, I made a Google Jamboard template with tiles, tokens, and play sheet backgrounds.  This can be easily expanded to work for more than 2 players.
I also discovered that with a nice high resolution background and a decent drawing app you can have a blast playing on a tablet.
In addition to the PDF, backers of each rewards tier will receive:
High Resolution 12x24 inch background including essential play sheets
Google Jamboard template for multiplayer games including play sheet backgrounds, tile sets, and tokens.
Artifacts of Play
Here is a partial playthrough I recorded!
PLAY

Below you can see some of the artifacts of my first playthrough.  I lost 14 good adventurers and spent 11 years lost in the Fae only to have Thruttun, my last Giant, destroyed by the Lich King himself.  The world was not saved.  Maybe you will fare better.

campaign.story:
(Cette page est disponible en français par ici !)

TWO SUMMERS is a diceless tabletop RPG in which you play the same characters at two different time periods: as teenagers in the 1990s, living an unforgettable adventure, and as adults 30 years later, coming back to the same place and realizing the adventure is not over.
You'll need a GM and 3 to 5 players in order to play this game, for a campaign lasting between 6 and 8 sessions of about 3 hours.
You'll like this game if you enjoy light drama, sunny adventures and good-hearted nostalgia!

What's inside this zine?
The zine features a complete game system plus everything you need to build your own campaign within its 92 pages (page count is subject to change):
 Diceless game mechanics: it's always up to the players to decide whether they succeed at a cost or fail
A guide to create characters and a relation map through a "session zero"
A thorough guide helping you to create your own campaign of the game, including 25 semi-prepared subplots to insert into your story
A character sheet
You can gain access to a text-only version of this game (with no art and only a basic layout) by pledging at the €1 level!
The full version of the game will be available both in French and in English and will feature a clear and efficient layout by Nicolas Folliot, as well as illustrations by momatoes and Jan Van Houten (examples are included throughout this page).
You can also download a demo version that includes a one-shot adventure by following this link; it will also give you a comprehensive preview of the game's layout and system.

The game system
TWO SUMMERS is diceless and keeps things very simple; simple enough to be explained in a couple of minutes and summed up in a single page.
Characters are defined by four Traits for each time period and by personal Concerns they try to balance with the adventure they'll go through. When a player wants their PC to perform an action that has a chance of interesting complication, the GM determines a difficulty score of 1 to 5 or more and players have to line up as many Assets as this score. Assets include a PC's Traits, external help or advantaging narrative circumstances.
Should a player fail to line up enough Assets, they can decide to succeed anyway but at the cost of narrative complications—as many as they're lacking Assets. Thus, if an action has a difficulty score of 4 and a player only has 2 Assets, they can choose to succeed at the cost of 2 complications.
A player can also earn Tokens when their character deals with their Concern; Tokens can serve as Assets or be spent to earn additional Traits and other narrative perks.
And that's about it! Switching between the adult and the teenage timeline is done freely by players, at any time during the game, to avoid slowing things down and giving a maximum of narrative freedom to everyone. 
The printed zine
The PDF version of the zine will be a 92-page file (page count subject to change), indexed and hyperlinked. The print version will also be 92 pages in A5 format, with text and images printed in black & white on a 100g offset paper, and  a color cover printed on 250g coated paper with a mat finishing touch.
I will ship this printed version anywhere in the world. Shipping fees will be managed through Big Cartel after the campaign ends: expect an extra fee of 7.5 euros (about 9 US dollars) for the English version, meaning a printed zine in English will cost you a total of about 21 US dollars.
Stretch goals
This Kickstarter project has reached my minimum of 1000€: the game will be financed and everything mentioned above will be included... But I have more ideas still!

 UNLOCKED! The project reached 1500€: I will ask the wonderfully gifted momatoes, who drew the cover of the game, to create two more full-page illustrations for a total of four!
 UNLOCKED! The project reached 2000€: I will thus write a guide to hacking the game. What if you want to play a campaign with grittier overtones? If you want to play kids and 80-years-old in parallel? If you want to play characters and their ancestors? What if you want some supernatural elements in your campaign? If you want to introduce time travel or parallel universes into the mix? I'll provide ideas, guides and new rules for all of this and more!
UNLOCKED! The project reached 2500€: I will commission ten more illustrations from the great Jan Van Houten, who drew the inside illustrations of the game, some of which you can see on this page!
UNLOCKED! The project reached 3000€: I’ll turn the hacking guide into a proper supplement for the game, which I am tentatively calling “Other Summers”, and I’ll write a one-shot adventure similar to the one in the demo version of the game! It will come with guidelines to turn it into a campaign, should you want to play more than a few sessions with it.
For every 500 euros beyond 3000, I’ll write an extra one-shot adventure just like the one I described above, demonstrating the different variants “Other Summers” will offer: a time-travel one-shot, a “centuries apart” one-shot, and so on…
Every euro beyond 3000 will also be split four-ways between Jan Van Houten, Nicolas Folliot, momatoes and myself!
Who are we?
I'm Côme Martin; I've hosted a French RPG podcast for many years before switching to game creation, writing 32 mini-RPGs which you can find here. I've also successfully created Green Dawn Mall last year, during Kickstarter's Zine Quest 2!
Aside from crafting colorful and highly textured illustrations, momatoes also creates narrative tabletop RPGs, the latter being the wonderful ARC. Visit her website to learn more!
 Jan Van Houten trains future roleplayers and draws on Sundays. With a great layout artist, he published a real game, available here, and good-natured adventures available there.
 Nicolas Folliot is a counselor for promising games. He guides them through their development, helps them finding a voice, a style, holding their colors high and shaping them into the wonderful games they were destined to be. Some of these games, along with Nicolas' other activities (graphic designer, layout artist, proofreader…) are available on his website.

Hello everyone!

(Une version en français de ce texte est disponible ici)

This is (almost) it! We’re a little more than a day before the end of the campaign, and since I’ll be on a short Internet break when it all stops, I thought I’d say a big THANK YOU!!! right now!
We’re currently at more than 3600€ and I expect the amount to raise even higher in these last handfuls of hours. I’m beyond joy as to how well has been received and I will do everything in my power to give you your money’s worth!

(Une version en français de ce texte est disponible ici)

As we get nearer to the 3000 euros threshold—quicker than I had expected!—I wanted to write a few words about what inspired me to create Two Summers!

Starting all this was a project by French-speaking RPG author Cédric Ferrand to which I was supposed to participate: a discovery campaign to the French game Nephilim, in which players play ideal holidays in an archetypal village. I was hired to work on the game system, and I quickly tried to imagine a way to tell both the adventures of these teenagers and of their parents; then their parents left place to the teenagers as adults, because try as I might, I can't keep my love for time travel at the door, and this seemed to me an original way to explore themes which were already present in a lot of other RPGs!
